Populations from Abomey-Calavi, So-ava and Ze gathered in support of president Boni Yayi in a protest march in Abomey-Calavi
Thousands of youth from Benin joined a protest movement against the current government
A pro-government rally took place in Atakora
A rally in support of the president Yayi Boni took place in Cotonou
Members of the municipal police forces marched in the streets of ? In protest at the non-payment of their wages
Opponents of the new king of Parakou gatheres in front of the Royal Palace to contest his appointment. Police Forces intervened to disperse the crowd.
A crowd of supporters of the president of Benins former advisor gathered in front of the central police station to demand his release from custody
Protesters clashed with police forces following a protest against the closure of the tv station canal 3
Benin has charged President Thomas Boni Yayis' doctor, niece and an ex-minister over an alleged plot to poison him
People of the Red Wednesday movement wore red garments and protested against the constitutional amendment that would allow the president to run for a third term.
People of the Red Wednesday movement wore red garments and protested against the constitutional amendment that would allow the president to run for a third term.
People of the Red Wednesday movement wore red garments and protested against the constitutional amendment that would allow the president to run for a third term.
On their independence day, people of the Red Wednesday movement wore red garments and protested against the constitutional amendment that would allow the president to run for a third term.
Security Measures: The house of Gaston Zossou, former Minister of Communication, was surrounded by police to prevent him from participating in the Red Wednesday independence day demonstration.
Supporters of President Boni Yayi wear white garments and protest with White Friday - as a counter-action to Red Wednesday .

For fifth consecutive Wednesday in a row, hundreds of people in the capital have donned bright red T-shirts, caps and headbands to signal their solidarity with the so-called Red Wednesday movement, whose slogan is ""Dont touch my constitution.""

column7: FNEB: National Union of Students of Benin
column17: A riot broke out at Abomey Calavi University as students protested against double fees. The army dispersed the students with tear gas.

column9: ALCRER: Association against Racism, Ethnocentrism and Regionalism
column17: An assassination attempt was made against Martin Assogba, a human rights activist and president of the Association Against Racism, Ethnocentrism and Regionalism (ALCRER). Seven arrests made but no further details as yet.

column7: CSTB: Confederation of Trade Unions of Benin
column17: The police used tear gas and batons to disperse an unauthorised peaceful protest held collectively by several unions to protest against violations of trade union rights and to demand an improvement in their living and working conditions. 12 demonstrators injured.
Students from public universities protested in front of the Institut National de Formation dEducation Civique et Social Cotonou, calling for university classes to resume

Thousands of public and private sector workers, members of the opposition and civil society, have demonstrated to demand the resignation of the prefect of the departments of Atlantique and Littoral, believed to be responsible for the violence against protesters on December 27 of last year
Acts of vengeance and vandalism against people suspected of ""connivance with the occult world"" have occurred in Ouassa-Pehounco (the specific acts were not specified).
A large number of people, anywhere from several hundred (AFP) to 30,000 (Associated Press) ""demonstrated in Benins capital to back the oppositions call for local elections.""

column7: PRD: Democratic Renewal Party; PFD: Platform of Democratic Forces
column17: Thousands of members of opposition groups, including the Platform of Democratic Forces and the Democratic Renewal Party (PRD), took to the streets in Porto-Novo and Cotonou to protest against against the government.

column7: PRD: Democratic Renewal Party; PFD: Platform of Democratic Forces
column17: Thousands of members of opposition groups, including the Platform of Democratic Forces and the Democratic Renewal Party (PRD), took to the streets in Porto-Novo and Cotonou to protest against against the government.

column7: PRD: Democratic Renewal Party; PFD: Platform of Democratic Forces
column17: Tens of thousands of members of opposition groups, including the Platform of Democratic Forces and the Democratic Renewal Party (PRD), took to the streets in Cotonou in a second day of protest to demand local elections. Another march by government supporters also occurred at the same time but no confrontation resulted.
Fulani herders clashed with youth from a local farming community.
One person died and four were seriously injured in a clash between farmers from Gangban and Fulani herders in the Tohoue area.

column7: Forum of Workers and People for a New System of Governance; Journalists (Benin)
column17: Hundreds marched and held a sit-in against the president and his parties confiscation of public media services, especially the Office of Radiodiffusion and Television of Benin (ORTB).

Activists stormed the National Institute for Social, Economic and Civil Education and chanted anti-government slogans before retreating to the opening meeting of the National Standing Committee for Consultation and Collective Bargaining between the Government and Unions
The population of Dangoussar boycotted the general election to protest lack of electricity, preventing some from Barei village from voting as well.
An armed group from Barei attacked Dangoussar village in retaliation for preventing them from voting on Sunday. Two were killed and several injured.

After several police officers were seen outside the home of opposition leader Candide Azannai, several hundred young people stormed the streets, barricading the road towards Lome by setting fires and preventing his arrest.
Several hundred opposition protesters marched in the capital, throwing stones at the police who used tear gas against them.
Benin military shot and killed a soldier who was resisting arrest regarding recent UN soldier protests in Ivory Coast. A policeman nearby was also injured.
Security forces fired teargas and live ammunition at demonstrators in Bante (Collines department), leaving one person shot and killed and nine others injured.
Thousands held a sit-in in front of the Presidential Palace to demand public sector jobs.
Three dead and two injured in clashes between farmers and herders. Security forces restored calm.
Security measures: Security forces increased patrols and set up road blocks ""in the face of a threat from Islamist militants.""

At the end of June, students held a boycott at the University of Abomey Calavi to protest academic year structures. In late July, 21 of the organizers were expelled from the school for leading the boycott and for ""incitement to violence.""

On July 6, an agriculturalist and six Fulani pastoralists died amidst intercommunal clashes in the village of Kouara-Tedji, in Guene, Malanville district. The clashes erupted after the murder of a farmer by an alleged Fulani, prompting people from villages Soumbe Gorou and Sakawan Tedji to attack the Fulani settlement.

An unauthorized spontaneus demonstration occurred in Parakou, led by winners of the competitive examinations for the Ministry of Finance and Economy in protesting against the gov decision of cancelling the results of the flawed competition. The protesters have erected barricades while the police has tried to break up the demonstration with tear gas.

Security forces used tear gas and batons to disperse a peaceful demonstration by students in Cotonou in July, injuring at least 20 people. At least nine students were arrested following the demonstrations and detained for several weeks before being released. 21 students presumed to have participated were banned from registering at the university for five years. In August, the university decided to invalidate the academic year for all the students in the faculty where most demonstrators were studying. In October, the Council of Ministers banned all activities by student associations on campuses.
Multiple civil society sectors - including higher education, public administration, and unions - held strikes, marches and sit-ins over several weeks to demand better work and life conditions.
Unidentified gunmen shot at the vehicle of Djidjas Adjunct Mayor in Zou department, leaving him injured and the vehicle damaged.
Clashes between police and Muslim rioters at a mosque in Semere, leaving eight people dead and several injured.
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed two people in Djime, Zou department. They were found at two separate locations.

column7: SYNTRASESH: National Union of Human Health Services Workers; Health Workers (Benin)
column17: Members of the National Union of Human Health Services Workers (Syntrashesh) held a sit-in and a peaceful march at the health ministry in Cotonou, calling for improved dialogue with authorities over their rights.
Workers of the agricultural sector staged a sit-in to protest recent lay-offs.
Pirates abducted a crew of 18 Russian and Ukrainian sailors when they attacked their boat off the coast of Benin. They were released soon after and returned to Cotonou.

column7: CSTB: Confederation of Trade Unions of Benin
column17: Hundreds of public and private sector workers, led by five of the seven syndicate unions and confederations of Benin, including CSTB, protested in Cotonou against the governments decision to privatise four state companies.

Clashes between members of a congregation from Gbaname church and Vodou-cult followers on the Bohicon-Abomey axis in Djime after provocations left two people dead, several others injured and caused significant material damage.
Around a hundred specialised doctors held a sit-in at the national hospital and teaching centre of Cotonou to launch an unlimited strike calling for improved working conditions.

Hundreds of national and international media professionals held a sit-in in Cotonou, calling for the re-opening of four TV channels and a radio station shut down by authorities. Police intervened to disperse the protest.

column7: CSTB: Confederation of Trade Unions of Benin
column17: Couffo syndicates affiliated to the CSTB staged a peaceful march in Aplahoue to protest bad governance, particularly in response to the various strike movements held by teachers and doctors in the country.

column7: CSTB: Confederation of Trade Unions of Benin; FESYNTRA-Finances: National Union of Financial Workers
column17: The Confederation of trade unions in Benin (CSTB) and the Federation of Financial administration syndicates (Fesyntra-finances) staged a sit-in in front of the National Assembly in Porto-Novo to protest draft laws on recruitment procedures.
Students boycotted classes over three days at Abomey-Calavi university in Cotonou over an October ruling forbiding student syndicates to operat. The ruling was nullified on 23 March.
Students boycotted classes over three days at Abomey-Calavi university in Cotonou over an October ruling forbiding student syndicates to operat. The ruling was nullified on 23 March.
Students boycotted classes over three days at Abomey-Calavi university in Cotonou over an October ruling forbiding student syndicates to operat. The ruling was nullified on 23 March.

column7: FSP: Front for the Patriotic Awakening
column17: A new Front called the Front for the Patriotic Awakening (FSP) gathering around 20 opposition movements and syndicates, staged sit-ins on 23 and 24 March in Porto-Novo to protest president Talon's project to revise the Constitution without popular referendum.

column7: FSP: Front for the Patriotic Awakening
column17: A new Front called the Front for the Patriotic Awakening (FSP) gathering around 20 opposition movements and syndicates, staged sit-ins on 23 and 24 March in Porto-Novo to protest president Talon's project to revise the Constitution without popular referendum.
Clash between Nigerian herders and residents in Adakplame village, Ketou commune, left four people killed and several others seriously injured.

column7: UNAMAB: National Union of Magistrates of Benin
column17: Around a hundred magistrates led by their Union (UNAMAB) as well as other supporters marched in Porto-Novo to protest the president's project to review the Constitution, which they say would weaken judicial powers.

column7: UNAMAB: National Union of Magistrates of Benin
column17: Strikes: UNAMAB began a 72h strike to protest the president's project to the review the Constitution.

column7: FSP: Front for the Patriotic Awakening
column17: More than 10,000 people led by the Front for the Patriotic Awakening (FSP), which gathers around 20 opposition movements and syndicates, marched in Cotonou to protest president Talon's project to revise the Constitution without popular referendum.
Clash between cattle breeders from Benin and Nigeria in Benin's Malanville commune over damaging of crops, leaving one person killed and several others injured.
Clash between residents of Founougo, Banikoara commune, protesting the killing by eco-guards of a suspected poacher, and police, left at least one protester killed and several others injured.
Thousands of workers have woke down the streets to protest against the consociational problem-solving strategies of both the Labour Unions and the Government.
National Society of agricultural products protested against their through a sit-in
Transhumant Fulani herders aggressed local civilians within the context of land sharing between farmers and herders: six dead and several wounded in two attacks, on Monday and on Satudray
Transhumant Fulani herders aggressed local civilians: six dead and several wounded in two attacks, on Monday and on Satudray
CHNU (University medical centre) personnel demonstrated against the privatisation plan of the centre.

Over a thousand people took to the streets of Benin's economic capital to protest against President Patrice Talon amid growing unease with his government's economic reforms. A coalition of opposition parties and civil activists led the rally. On the same day harbour workers launched a two-day strike against the government's move to privatise port management.
Hundreds of persons took the street to protest against the FCFA in Cotonou, Dakar and Bamako.
Primary school teachers went to the streets claiming their bonus.
Bante public agents went on strike and set up a demonstration to protest bad economic conditions and mismanagement.
Hundreds of teachers organised a sit-in to protest the delay of bonus payments.

column7: FSP: Front for the Patriotic Awakening
column17: Hundreds of protesters gathered to demonstrate against President Talon's regime.
Justice workers went on a 48-hours strike and gathered in the court building, asking for the better work conditions.

Thousands of people took to the streets of Benin's commercial capital Cotonou on Friday to protest against President Patrice Talon's economic reforms and the high cost of living. One of the organisers said ""more than 10,000"" people turned out for the march to the trades union congress building. No official figure was immediately available.
Primary school teachers went to the street to claim the payment of their primes.

column7: FSP: Front for the Patriotic Awakening
column17: Thousands of activists of the Front for the Patriotic Awakening, went down in the street of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, to demand the improvement of living conditions of the Beninois.
Activists protested against the auction of African migrants present on the Libyan territory through a peaceful march.

Several hundred workers in public and private administrations, led by the secretary general's of Benin's seven trade unions and confederations, observed a sit-in at the Beninese Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development in Cotonou, demanding the immediate cessation of proceedings against the Acting Secretary General for Waters, Forests and Hunting, Captain Patrice Trekpo.
Security forces dispersed a movement of the population that descended on the streets in Cove to protest against the early start of transhumance in the Agonlin region.

An attack perpetrated by transhumant Fulani in Kinho, a hamlet in the district of Adakplame, commune of Ketou, resulted in a death and several wounded. According to reports, transhumant herdsmen stormed the town of Kinho around 9 pm, killing a man and wounding several others.

Landowners and buyers of plots of Glo Djigbe, disapproving the costs of selling the areas retained by the government in the framework of the construction project of Glo Djigbe airport, blocked the interstate road No 2 crossing the locality. They were dispersed by police forces.

Property destruction: Groups of transhumant herdsmen whose motives are unknown, have disturbed educational activities in the primary schools of the localities of Ihoro, Kpanyikpan, Illamon and Oko-Ilakpo in the municipality of Pobe, Igana district. Transhumant herdsmen make surprise raids in the public primary schools and remove students and teacher using threats of weapons (machetes, daggers).
Women of some civil society associations took the street to ask for the withdrawal of the judicial accusation against M Metognon Laurent.
Some Fulani herders attacked 3 civilians following a farmers-herders confrontation in Agbele: 2 people were heavily wounded.
On 11 February 2018, a farmer was killed by a group of herders after protesting against the devastation of his field.
On 11 February 2018, Sahe-Abigo people killed 4 herders as reprisal to the killing of the farmer.
Farmers-herders clashes continued: 2 herders were killed and one went missing.
As a reprisal, herders severely wounded three passersby.
Traditional hunters looted the NGO African Parks Network and blocked the road no 3 to protest the seizure of some of their motorcycles.
Teachers demonstrated in Pobe to claim the respect of agreements.
Teachers demonstrated to claim the respect of agreements in Oueme Department.
Students demonstrated to ask for the end of strikes paralysing the education system.
On February 25, unknown gunmen killed a Fulani man and butchered twenty-five of his livestock in the village of Atchonsa.
Transhumant herders wounded three civilians in Agbele who were taken to the hospital.
Police on Friday fired teargas to break up an anti-government demonstration by political opposition IN Benin involving thousands of people.
On 12 March, educational workers organised a sit-in to claim the satisfactions of their demands.
On 25 April, two Fulani herdsmen were killed as a clash erupted with local farmers in Igboiganan, Ketou.
On 26 April, Fulani herdmen attacked Igboiganan, Ketou, as a reprisal for the 25 April clashes. 5 civilians were killed.
On 30 April, townhall workers of Natitingou organised a sit-in to ask for the payment of their salaries.
On 25 June, some Fulani herdmen reportedly killed 2 civilians in Igbo-Igana, Idigny, after a cattle theft.
On 28 June, workers of a research centre in agriculture held a sit-in in Pobe to ask for better work conditions.
On 30 June, Tchanwasaga people raided and looted Fulani camps around Tchanwasaga, Tanguieta, wounding a baby and a women.

On 7 July 2018, suspected Fulani herders killed a farmer in Tchamonga, Cobly. People from Tchamonga retaliated the same day, killing 5 Fulani herders and 2 other displaced people near Tchamonga and burning down properties. 5000 people were displaced to neighbouring communes.

On 7 July 2018, suspected Fulani herders killed a farmer in Tchamonga, Cobly. People from Tchamonga retaliated the same day, killing 5 Fulani herders and 2 other displaced people near Tchamonga and burning down properties. 5000 people were displaced to neighbouring communes.
On July 20, two Fulani and two Pila Pila were killed amidst intercommunal clashes in Onklou.
On July 22, members of a neighbouring community attacked the Fulani village of Issa Manga (near Onklou), forty huts were reportedly set ablaze.
On 8 August, moto-taxi drivers protested in Bohicon, Zou, against the payment of ""taxi rights"".
On August 11, unknown individuals assaulted a Fulani man in Ouesse and reportedly because the victim not was indigenous.

On 25 August 2018, a vigilante group killed a man in Honmeho (Bohicon, Zou). The identity of the attackers is unknown, although local sources indicated that the man was known for thieving, implying that a vigilante group might have been involved. [size=no report]

On September 10th, protesters gathered at Toucountouna (Atakora), to demand the resignation of the mayor, accusing him of absenteeism since a majority of councillors voted to initiate impeachment proceedings against the mayor in August. The mayor refused to step down, and police blocked the protesters from entering the town hall.
On November 18th, a fist fight related to a local political dispute broke out in Saclo (Zou). Three local councillors were injured in the incident.
14 December. Mayors of Atokara, accompanied by citizens, protested in Natitingou and demanded action against the circulation of alcohol
On January 5, off the coast of Benin, pirates took six Russian crewmen as hostages from a cargo ship.
01 May. in Kandi acts of vandalism were recorded that are related to the legislative election held on April 28. Rioters burned down the cotton factory of President Talon.  [size=no report]

01 May. Rioters vandalized in Cotonou to protest the legislative election held on April 28 and the alleged arrest of former President Yayi. Private and Public property were burned or destroyed during the riots. The riots were sparked by rumours that the former President Yayi is to be arrested. Rioters threw stones at Police forces who responded with teargas. [size=no report]
09 January. Victims of the lCC Services hit the streets of Lokossa and marched peacefully to demand re-imbursements for their losses in the company
09 January. Farmers of Hetin Sota and Agongue clashed over a ransacked plantage. Four killed and at least seven injured

31 January. The Union of higher education teachers organized a sit-in at the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research in Cotonou to protest against the appointment of deans of faculties and directors of schools by the government.
05 February. A Fulani was shot by unidentified gunmen in Kinwo village, near Adakplame
17 February. Traditional hunters barricaded a highway in Tanguita with rocks and burning tyres to protest against the ban of motorcycles in parts of the Pendjari Biosphere Reserve

25 February. Protesters took the streets in Porto-Novo and Seme-Podji to protest for inclusive election. Police made arrests and dispersed the crowd as protest took place spontanously without permit [size=no report]

25 February. Protesters hit the streets in Porto-Novo and Seme-Podji to protest for inclusive election. Police made arrests and dispersed the crowd as protest took place spontanously without permit [size=no report]

25 February. Rioters barricaded the Cotonou-Parakou highway between Ouesse and Tchaouro with burning tyres and planks to raise awareness for the situation of opposition parties in April 2019 elections. Police cleared the road and re-opened it for traffic [size=no report]
25 February. Rioters barricaded an interstate in Allada and Tori to call for inclusive elections in April 2019. Police dispersed the crowd with the use of force [size=no report]
25 February. Rioters barricaded an interstate in Allada and Tori to protest for inclusive elections in April 2019. Police dispersed the crowd with the use of force [size=no report]

26 February. Police and rioters clashed in Kilibo. Rioters demanded the participation of opposition parties in the legislative election in April and blocked the road. Police dispersed the crowd with teargas. 10 security forces and three rioters injured. One rioter killed [size=no report]

column7: FCBE: Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin; USL: Social Liberal Union; PRB: Renaissance Party of Benin; RE: Restore the Hope; PLP: Party for the Liberation of the People; PCB: Communist Party of Benin
column17: 11 March. Opposition parties in Cotonou protested their exclusion in the upcoming legislative election [size=20000]
15 March. Detainees in Akpro-Misserete Civil Prison in Porto Novo vandalized and burnt rooms in the facilitiy to protest new regulations imposed by the prison administration [size=no report]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]

04 April. Protesters in Dogbo, Azove, Toviklin, Djakotomey, Lalo and Cotonou demanded fair and inclusive legislative elections. Protest in Cotonou was dispersed by Police forces [size=hundreds in total]
19 April 2019. Security forces used tear gas to disperse a protest in Cotonou. Former presidents Soglo and Yayi were involved in the protests. [size=no report]
23 April. Market women protested in Porto-Novo and demanded the participation of the PRD in the upcoming elections. Police forces intervened and stopped the protest. [size=no report]
27 April. Unknown actors destroyed election materials of the Autonomous National Electoral Commission (CENA) in Alafiarou ahead of the legislative elections.
27 April. Rioters blocked a road in Save to protest the legislative election. Police called for reinforcements to control the situation. Injuries on both sides were reported. [size=no report]
27 April. Unknown actors destroyed election materials of the Autonomous National Electoral Commission (CENA) in Akpadanou ahead of the legislative elections.
27 April. Rioters blocked a road in Tchaourou and burned down a police vehicle. Police forces later controlled the crowd. [size=no report]
28 April. Protesters against the elections and Police forces clashed in Bante. One person killed. [size=no report]
28 April. Violence erupted between rivaling party militias in Parakou leading to one death. [size=no report]
28 April. Rioters protesting the exclusion of opposition parties burned police vehicles in Save and clashed with Police forces. [size=no report]
28 April. Rioters that protested the exclusion of opposition parties in the legislative elections attacked a vehicle of the national television. One person sustained injuries.
01 May. An unidentified armed group killed a park ranger in Pendjari NP and abducted two french tourists. The tourists were later brought to Burkina Faso and rescued by French military.

02 May. Riots in the Cotonou neighbourhood of former President Yayi resumed. Roads leading to his residency were barricaded with burning tyres. Military forces used teargas and fired gunshots to calm the situation and disperse the crowd. Three people killed. [size=hundreds]
On May 3, two Fulani men were killed during intercommunal clashes between agriculturalists and pastoralists in the area of Ketou.
03 May. A group of youth fired into the crowd at the enthronement ceremony of a local chiefin Kerou. Police forces responded with gunshots. Six people were killed.
On May 22, local leaders along with security forces torched the belongings of pastoralists in the village of Akpakanme and forcibly displaced them toward Save.
31 May (or around). A local farmer and a pastoralist got engaged in a an argument over land in Akofofjoule that resulted in the death of the pastoralist.
02 June (or around). Fulani militias attacked Akofofjoule in Dassa-Zoume and killed four residents as reprisal to the death of a pastoralist a few days earlier.

10 June. Residents of Tchaourou barricaded a main road in the town to protest the arrest of suspected leaders of the riots during the legislative election end of April. Tires were burnt and a police station invaded. [size=no report]

11 June. Violent demonstrations. in Tchaourou resumed on Tuesday with police using live ammunition and teargas to removed the barricade on the road and disperse the crowd. Two people were injured. [size=no report]
12 June. Violent demonstrations in Tchaourou resumed on Wednesday with police using live ammunition and teargas to disperse the crowd. Two people were injured. [size=no report]

13 June. Following demonstrations in Tchaourou, residents of Save barricaded a road to prevent a military convoy from accessing Tchaourou. This resulted in a gun battle between Save residents and military forces, resulting in one fatality and several injuries.

13 June. Demonstrators in Tchaourou were reinforced by hunters from surrounding villages that engaged police forces in a gun battle. Security forces overpowered the groups and cleared barricaded roads . [size=no report]
14 June. Violent demonstrations continued in Tchaourou with new barricades erected by demonstrators. Gunshots were heard from the scene but there were no reports of an armed clash. [size=no report]

15 June. Security forces cleared barricaded roads in Tchaourou and used ammunition to disperse demonstrators. Two demonstrators were killed, 50 people wounded including 10 security forces. [size=no report]

On August 4, After a pastoralists was killed earlier in the day, traditional hunters (Ode Militia) organized a reprisal attack on the unidentified armed group in Ouesse. One person was killed during the clashes.
On August 4, unknown gunmen abducted and killed a pastoralist in Ouesse.

12 August. The arrest of suspected robbers led to violent demonstrations in N'dali. Demonstrators burnt tyres and blocked roads. Police forces dispersed the crowd with live ammunition. Three people were killed. [size=no report]
24 August. Police forces used teargas to disperse protesting teachers in Parakou. The teachers boycotted an evaluation exercise. [size=no report]
25 September. Teachers at CEG Oke Dama protested the bad state of the school infrastructure in Parakou. [size=no report]
20 October 2019. A farmer was shot dead by a Fulani militia in Aklankpa. The brother of the deceased sustained injuries.
02 November 2019. Pirates kidnapped nine Philippine crew members from a vessel close to Cotonou port entrance.

column6: Police Forces of Nigeria (2015-) Customs Clearing Agents
column17: On 16 November (or around), Nigerian Customs Officers crossed the border to Benin and destroyed rice shops in Igolo.

column6: Police Forces of Nigeria (2015-) Customs Clearing Agents
column17: On 16 November (or around), Nigerian Customs Officers crossed the border to Benin and destroyed rice shops in Pobe.

On 4 December 2019, the arrest of a suspected smuggler sparked violent demonstrations in Segbana in Alibori. Demonstrators attacked the police post and customs office to free the suspect. Police cars and property were destroyed. [size=no report]
On 5 December 2019, the arrest of a suspected petrol smuggler sparked a demonstration in Klouekanme. Police forces intervened. [size= no report]
On 17 December 2019, opposition parties united in the ""National Resistance"" staged a demonstration in Parakou against President Talon. [size=no report]
On 18 December 2019, suspected Fulani militias attacked Ouyerihoun near Cobly (no location found, coded as Cobly) and killed a resident. 185 people were displaced, cattle rustled and property stolen.
On 30 December 2019, workers of CONTRELEC demonstrated at the premises of their company in Akpakpa in Cotonou against their working conditions. [size=no report]
On 7 January 2020, Fulani and residents of Issaba got engaged in street fight and threw stones at each other over land use. Police forces intervened and calmed the situation. [size=no report]

On 9 January 2020, demonstrators blocked the Cotonou-Parakou highway at Save to oppose the arrest of a youth in their community. Police forces intervened and clashed with the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 15 January 2020, Police were attacked with gun fire after violent demonstrations against an arrest resumed in Save. Security forces responded with live ammunition and killed 2 people. 6 police officers were injured.
On 16 January 2020, violent demonstrations against an arrest continued in Save (Save, Collines). [size=no report]
On 18 January 2020, a supporter of the opposition was attacked at his home in Adjagbo (Abomey-Calavi, Atlantique) and died on January 19.

column16: Benin 24; Benin Times; La Nouvelle (Benin); Banouto
column17: On 21 January 2020, suspected Fulani militias attacked Ahogo, near Sagon (Ouinhi, Zou) and killed two residents.
On 1 February 2020, residents of Malanville (Malanville, Alibori) burnt a customs post to demonstrate over the arrest of a suspected smuggler. [size=no report]

column16: Banouto; Benin 24; Agence Benin Press; La Nouvelle (Benin); Benin Times
column17: On 9 February 2020, suspected poachers attacked a police station in Keremou (Banikoara, Alibori). 1 police officer and an unreported number of residents were killed and the station razed. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.
On 2 March 2020, residents of Dogbo (Dogbo, Mono) attacked a Fulani settlement in the area. The Fulani were accused of being responsible for the death of a boy found in the community.
On 4 March 2020, unidentified actors vandalised the home of the local treasurer of the Mouvement Populaire de Liberation in the Nikki area (Borgou).

On 4 March 2020 (or around), soldiers of the Benin Armed Forces and police officers were arrested by Benin Intelligence Services. The suspects are accused of buying weapons in Nigeria and planning a coup against President Talon.

column16: Banouto; Kisal; La Nouvelle (Benin); Benin Times
column17: On 3 June 2020, farmers and Fulani pastoralists clashed in the area of Goungoun (Malanville, Alibori), leaving at least four people dead.
On 10 March 2020, residents of Aplahoue (Djakotomey LGA, Couffo) demonstrated over plans to hold local elections for new mayor. [size=no report]
On 11 March 2020, students in Aplahoue (Djakotomey LGA, Couffo) demonstrated over the arrest of two fellow students. [size=no report]
On 23 March 2020, the Government of Benin banned all non-essential political, religious and cultural gatherings in response to the coronavirus outbreak.

column7: Students (Benin); FNEB: National Union of Students of Benin
column17: On 24 March 2020, the National Federation of Students of Benin evicted students from lecture halls at the University in Abomey-Calavi (Abomey-Calavi, Atlantique), after authorities refused to close the university due to coronavirus. Police forces used teargas and live ammunition against stone-pelting students. A student was injured by a bullet and later died died. [size=no report]
On 6 April 2020, people under coronavirus quarantine in a hotel in Cotonou (Cotonou, Littoral) staged a violent demonstration in the hotel lobby over their situation. [size=no report]

column16: Benin 24; La Nouvelle (Benin); Benin Times; Banouto; Agence Benin Press
column17: On 15 April 2020, a group of Fulani engaged in an argument about grazing land in Lou (Kalale, Borgou) and assaulted 2 farmers. The farmers mobilized youth from the community and attacked the Fulani settlement. 1 person died and property was damaged.

column16: Benin 24; AFP; Vanguard (Nigeria); Benin Times; Banouto
column17: On 18 April 2020, a container ship was attacked by sea pirates in coastal waters around Cotonou. Nigerian and Benin Navy boarded the ship on April 20. Pirates and 8 crew members were not found on board.
On 30 April 2020, suspected Fulani militias attacked Woroko in Kpankou community (Ketou, Plateau) and killed 6 residents.
On 6 May 2020, prisoners in Misserete (Akpro-Misserete, Oueme) demonstrated over a search of the cells by prison guards. Chairs were burnt and property destroyed. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, police forces used teargas to disperse a second day of violent demonstrations by prisoners in Misserete (Akpro-Misserete, Oueme), over a search of the cells by prison guards. [size=no report]

column16: Agence Benin Press; Banouto; Benin Times
column17: On 14 May 2020, unidentified gunmen robbed a police officer at Toui (Ouesse, Collines) and killed the victim.

On 19 May 2020, a number of residents, including women, severely assaulted two suspected motorbike thieves in the village of Sogba, in the area of Bohicon (Bohicon, Zou), reportedly leaving them in a critical state before being handed to the police. [size=no report]

On 24 May 2020, clashes erupted when the police arrived to disperse a number of Muslim residents in the village of Kassakou (Kandi, Alibori) gathered for Eid celebrations, enforcing measures to counter the spread of coronavirus. One policeman was wounded and material damages reported. [size=no report]

column16: Banouto; Agence Benin Press; La Nouvelle (Benin)
column17: On 30 May 2020, a number of residents equipped with sticks and stones in Zangnanado (Zangnanado, Zou) demonstrated against the mayor election in the locality, the demonstrators reportedly threw stones against the elected mayor delegation, the police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]

column16: Benin Times; La Nouvelle (Benin); Agence Benin Press; Banouto; Undisclosed Source
column17: On 30 May 2020, Fulani pastoralists and farmers clashed with firearms and machetes in the village of Goungoun (Malanville, Alibori), leaving four people dead.

column16: Agence Benin Press; La Nouvelle (Benin); Benin 24
column17: Around 31 May 2020 (between 31 May - 1 June), locals in Za-Sounta, Zakpota Commune (Za-Kpota, Zou) chased down and killed two men believed to have murdered the person responsible for a collective fund. [size=no report]
On 3 June 2020, a hunter shot dead another near the village of Koda (Tchaourou, Borgou) due to land dispute over the usage of hunting ground.

Around 16 June 2020 (as reported), a number of people chased down a motorbike thief in Cocotomey (Abomey-Calavi, Atlantique), the thief stabbed one of his pursuers before being overpowered and severely beaten by the mob until police came to his rescue. [size=no report]

On 19 June 2020, a number of residents youths threw stones against police during a security crackdown in Parakou (Parakou, Borgou). The police responded by firing teargas. Several people were wounded and 29 arrested. [size=at least 29]

column16: La Nation (Benin); Fraternite (Benin); Benin Times; Benin 24; Banouto; Benin Web TV; La Nouvelle (Benin); Actu Benin
column17: Around 20 June 2020, an unidentified group assassinated a policeman in the village of Founga (Djougou, Donga).
On 24 June 2020, sea pirates attacked a fishing vessel off the coast of Cotonou (Cotonou, Littoral), and abducted five South Korean nationals and one Ghanaian national.

On 29 June 2020, a number of residents in the Zogbadje quarter of Abomey-Calavi (Abomey-Calavi, Atlantique) demonstrated in front of the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) due to flooding caused by drainage from the facility. [size=no report]

Around 30 June 2020 (as reported), a number of residents in Kali (Nikki, Borgou) vandalized and burned houses of people they suspected of being behind the murder of a young man the week before. [size=no report]

column16: Agence Benin Press; Benin Web TV
column17: On 30 June 2020, residents from the villages of Belle and Kperankou-Baguiri fought each other in the area of Sakabansi (Nikki, Borgou), after a traditional court failed to solve a land dispute over farmland. 7 people were wounded, including 5 severely.

On 1 July 2020, a Fulani pastoralist stabbed a farmer to death after his herd damaged the camp of the farmer in the village of Gango (Tchaourou, Borgou). Later, the farmers responded by attacking a Fulani camp nearby in Boudo Bouda (exact location unknown), coded separately.

On 1 July 2020, farmers responded to an attack on one of their own by a Fulani pastoralist in the village of Gango (Tchaourou, Borgou) by attacking a Fulani camp nearby in Boudo Bouda (exact location unknown). A Fulani was severely wounded, 25 huts burned, and livestock killed.

column16: Benin Web TV; L'investigateur; Benin 24; Undisclosed Source
column17: On 9 July 2020, unknown gunmen entered the hamlet of Kekeleba (Ouake, Donga), fired in the air, abducted a Fulani man, and assaulted and wounded a Fulani woman.
On 13 July 2020, two individuals beat a woman to death who they accused of sorcery in the village of Pourniari (Materi, Atacora). [size=no report]
On 13 July 2020, a number of residents beat and captured a presumed motorcycle thief before handing him over to the police in Ahozon (Ouidah, Atlantique). [size=no report]
On 28 July 2020, a number of residents captured a burglar in Segbehoue in the area of Kinkinhoue (Djakotomey, Couffo) and burned him to death. [size=no report]

On 23 August 2020, a number of residents vandalized the vehicle of a customs officer in Ekpe (Seme-Kpodji, Oueme). The attack came in reaction to the customs officer chasing a transporter of smuggled fuel (kpayo), the customs officer fled the mob and escaped unharmed. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, a number of residents assaulted and severely wounded a customs officer in the village of Igbo-Ola, near Ketou (Ketou, Plateau). The assault came in reaction to the customs officer chasing a transporter of smuggled fuel (kpayo). [size=no report]
Around 26 August 2020 (as reported), unknown individuals equipped with machetes killed a woman in Kolokonde (Djougou, Donga).

On 7 September 2020, unknown gunmen fired gunshots at a government vehicle in Toui (Ouesse, Collines). The gunmen abducted a woman and the driver while an official of the ministry of education escaped. The abductors demanded ransom. Abudctees were later released under unclear circumstances.

column16: Benin 24; Banouto; Daabaaru; Agence Benin Press
column17: On 8 September 2020, unknown individuals equipped with machetes killed and mutilated a security guard at a farm in Pede (Kandi, Alibori).
On 14 September 2020, a soldier opened fire against two policemen searching for him in Pahou (Ouidah, Atlantique). The soldier was subsequently arrested.
On 27 September 2020, a number of locals assaulted and threw a mason accused of theft into a septic tank in Bohicon (Bohicon, Zou). [size=no report]
On 29 September 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed an economic operator at his home in Tanguieta (Tanguieta, Atacora).

On 30 September 2020, a number of hunters from Kilibo barricaded the road near Owolafe (Ouesse, Collines). The hunters were sent to the area to chase away hunters from Toui due to a dispute over land and tax collection. [size=no report]
On 7 October 2020, a number of people lynched and burned to death a presumed thief in Avrankou (Avrankou, Oueme). [size=no report]
On 8 October 2020, unknown individuals equipped with machetes killed a farmer in his field in Nikki (Nikki, Borgou).
On 12 October 2020, a number of locals beat and killed a presumed thief in the Nabissou quarter of Parakou (Parakou, Borgou). [size=no report]

Around 16 October 2020 (between 16 - 17 October), a number of residents captured, tied up, and burned alive a presumed cattle thief to death in Tchanhoun-Centre [Tchanhoun-Cossi] (Materi, Atacora). [size=no report]

column16: Benin Web TV; Agence Benin Press
column17: Around 19 October 2020 (between 19 - 20 October), unknown gunmen abducted and ransomed a male civilian in the Fulani hamlet of Moukokotammou, in the Chirimina quarter of Natitingou (Natitingou, Atacora).
Around 21 October 2020 (as reported), unknown gunmen equipped with artisanal guns shot and killed a farmer in Kaodji (Ketou, Plateau).
On 22 October 2020, about a hundred motor taxi drivers demonstrated after one of their colleagues was killed in a traffic accident in Parakou (Parakou, Borgou). [size=about 100]

column7: CPDS: Convergence for Social Democracy Party
column17: Equatorial Guineas main opposition withdrew its agents from polling stations to protest against irregularities as the country voted in a referendum on a new constitution.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-)
column17: Non-violent activity: Around 20 inmates, including army officers, broke free from Equatorial Guineas infamous Black Beach prison.

column8: Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Police forces shoot and kill a former army office and member of the presidential guard after he and 20 other escaped prison last week.

Police dispersed an opposition demonstration on Wednesday, arresting several organisers, who were protesting the authorities refusal to register a new political party in advance of upcoming elections.
On 5 March, students at the National University of Equatorial Guinea in Malabo protested against the non-payment of state stipends. The protest is violently dispersed by police.
On 24 July, around 50 students at the National University of Equatorial Guinea in Malabo protested against the non-payment of state stipends.
Police officers in Equatorial Guinea on Saturday beat up a Nigerian diplomat, Noah Ichaba, on the street of Bata. He was later taken to a hospital where he was treated and discharged on the same day

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.

Police arrested opposition party Union Centro Derecha campaign coordinator Rafael Mbela in Bata, while he was peacefully campaigning to promote his parties message. He was taken to a military base, where he was allegedly beaten and robbed.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Arrests: Police allegedly prevented opposition Citizens for Innovation (CI) party leader Gabriel Nse Obiang Obono and 200 of his supporters from leaving his residence in Malabo after an army assault on the property. As of 27 April, they were still under house arrest.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Soldiers and police launched an assault on opposition Citizens for Innovation (CI) party leader Gabriel Nse Obiang Obonos house in Malabo, using live ammunition against supporters of the party, allegedly injuring six severely.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: On 22 April, police used excessive force against CI members who had gathered peacefully in the party's headquarters in Malabo. At about 4am, police in helicopters and armed vehicles surrounded the headquarters and used tear gas and live ammunition to force the approximately 200 party members out of the building. Four people were injured by bullets and taken to hospital over 24 hours later, following the intervention of the US Ambassador. At least 23 people were arrested and taken to Black Beach prison where they were beaten. All were released without charge on 30 April. The police siege of the CI's headquarters continued until 4 May.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.
On 10 March 2017, a military officer shot and killed one person in Bata town (Bata, Littoral), following an argument on a unspecified issue.

On 10 March 2017, the police forces beat one young man to death in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), after they stepped in to resolve an argument between the victim and his girlfriend in a night club.
On 14 March 2017, a group of rioters beat up and injured a person that they caught stealing food in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte). [size=no report]
On 2 May 2017, security forces (assumed Police Forces) conducted a 'massive arrest' of taxi drivers in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) following a general strike.

On 3 May 2017, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) reportedly engaged in violence and torture against several striking taxi drivers in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), severely injured many taxi drivers. No demonstration activity was reported.
On 20 July 2017, the military forces killed two people in Biyendem village, Bata subdivision (Bata, Littoral). The reasons of this remain unclear.
On 18 Sept. 2017, a group of workers of the Androbras SL building company demonstrated in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), to demand the payment of salary arrears. [size=no report]

column7: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: CI activists and police forces clashed in Aconibe during the election campaign. Several police officers were wounded and several activists were arrested.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Police raided the opposition (CI) headquarters in Malabo. 200 opposition activists were arrested. Many of them were tortured. One opposition activist was tortured to death. The government claims he fell ill.

column9: Unidentified Armed Group (Chad); Unidentified Armed Group (Sudan); Unidentified Armed Group (Central African Republic)
column17: Government troops clashed with militants on the Equatorial Guinea-Cameroon border. They accuse the militants of plotting a coup. The government claims that the militant group is made up mercenaries from Sudan, CAR and Chad. One militant was killed in the clash.
Security forces shot a mercenary in the Ebebeyin forest. They believe that he is part of a force that the government is accusing of attempting a coup.

column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: 30 of the 150 activists on trial on Tuesday 13/2 had been tortured so badly that they could not stand up.

column8: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: Non-violent activity: The main opposition party in Equatorial Guinea, Citizens for Innovation, was dissolved by a court. 21 CI activists were jailed for more than 30 years in the same court case.

column6: Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
column9: Former Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-); CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: On 28 May, a former army captain and close relative of the Citizens for Innovation opposition party was reportedly murdered at the Malabo Central Prison. The leader claimed it was a state assassination. The ruling party deny the allegation.

column6: Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
column9: CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
column17: On 2 July, an Equatorial Guinean opposition figure who had been jailed for ""sedition"" was tortured to death in Evinayong Prison, according to his party, the Citizens for Innovation (CI).

column6: Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
column17: 21 July. Jose Esono Ndong Bindang, a magistrate judge, is arrested on charges related to misappropriation of funds, but dies in prison due to lack of treatment for diabetes.

column9: CEID: Center for Development Studies and Initiatives
column17: 27 October. Equatorial Guinea security forces take vice president of CEID, Alfredo Okenve, to a remote location and beat him at gunpoint before leaving the scene. He may have been mistaken for his brother, an opposition political figure.

column7: CPDS: Convergence for Social Democracy Party
column17: 30 January. Protesters with the CPDS hang posters and demonstrate in Malabo against the presence of Yahya Jammeh in the country and demand his return to Gambia.
27 February. A critical journalist, Paysa Elo Eyoto, is tortured in Malabo Detention Center of Bioko Norte by military forces.

column6: Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
column17: Month of March. Police forces torture a Cameroon business person, Joseph Nseke, to death in Malabo of Bioko Norte over collusion with Maria Teresa Obiang, Francisco Massie or Juan Francisco.
On 11 Feb. 2020, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) arrested the former president of the Supreme Court in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte). The reason of the arrest was unclear.
On 24 March 2020, the government of Equatorial Guinea banned the gathering of more than 10 people to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On 31 March 2020, the government of Equatorial Guinea declared the state of health emergency for 30 days, to combat the coronavirus, and banned the gathering of more than 10 people.
Around 9 June 2020 (as reported), the military forces beat up one person in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) while enforcing the counter coronavirus lockdown measure.
Around 9 June 2020 (as reported), five police officers violently beat up a woman in Bata town (Bata, Littoral) as they were enforcing the counter coronavirus lockdown measure.

On 9 July 2020, a group of 5 military and police officers assaulted a doctor in Loeri Comba hospital of Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), for refusing to give the priority to a young man that they were bringing to him, because of another emergency case he was treating.

On 7 August 2020, former workers of the Manso Express SL Company demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Labour in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) to demand the payment of their dismissal allocations and the real reasons for their dismissal. The police forces intervened to disperse them, and arrested at least one. [size=no report]
The OLA attacks government positions and kills seven troops.
The OLA attacks two government positions, killing six soldiers total.
The OLA attacks two government positions, killing six soldiers total.

A man is shot in the neck by the EDF after an emotional meeting discussing villagization and potential displacement. There were also reports of severe beatings by the EDF [Ethiopian Defense Force army] who accused locals of mobilizing farmers against the villagization process.
Tribal clashes kill 5, injure 11.
Government forces clash with the ONLF, accusing the group of ethnic cleansing in the region.
Ethiopian Oromo rebels kill over 21 government soldiers.
Ethiopian army reportedly kills 11 civilians in southeast.
Government forces kill five Afar pastoralists.

column8: ARDUF: Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front
column17: Uguugumo fighters clash with government forces, 45 dead.
Government forces kill a respected elder in a town 15km from Kebri.
OLA and government forces clash, 30 members of the army killed. 25 others wounded.
Government forces kidnap fifteen civilians from a town loyal to the OLNF.

column8: ARDUF: Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front
column17: Afar rebels clash with government forces, 49 dead.
Oromo Liberation Army fighters killed six Weyane soldiers and wounded over 18 others in an ambush at a place called Gara Walo in Gara Mulata, East Hararge Zone.
Oromo freedom fighters raided an enemy army barracks in Babile town, killing 14 enemy soldiers and wounding more than seven others.

column6: MEDREK: Ethiopian Federal Democratic Unity Forum
column17: 200 supporters of the opposition party Medrek are arrested for unknown reasons.

An Oromo Liberation Army commando unit killed a Weyane military officer in Dire Dawa city, at a place called Addis Ketema. The officer had been engaged in harassment against civilians in various locations.
Report of Ethiopian soldiers rape three young girls.
A bomb exploded near a court in the west of Ethiopias capital Addis Ababa on Thursday, wounding two people.

column9: Mursi Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Mekan Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Prisoners (Ethiopia)
column17: Federal military forces visiting villages have arbitrarily arrested and detained members of the Bodi and Mursi communities according to 10 witnesses in different villages. The interviewees said that the military personnel conducting the arrests gave different reasons for the arrests, but regularly mentioned opposition to the sugar plans as a contributory factor. Several villagers claimed that some prisoners were beaten severely while in custody and that their families were denied access to those arrested.
Beginning in April 2011, members of the federal military and police visited Bodi villages and arrested, beat, and intimidated villagers.
Police shoot and kill two students who were protesting mistreatment of ethnic Oromi at Tepi University.
OLA members kill a government soldiers named Wali Muhammad after he reportedly harassed civilians.
The OLA clashed with government forces, kills 14.
The OLA carries out an attack on a government position, killing one.
The OLA claims to have killed 13 government forces.

Rebel ONLF group claims the government army abducted to UN aid workers in an effort to silence them after they were believed to have witnessed the army killing more than 100 civilians in the Fatan Valley from the dates of May 10-15.
People assemble for an anti-regime protest.
June 1 2011, Ethiopian military personnel fire on a Mursi village during a displacement program to make a new wildlife gamepark. One man wounded.
Another Mursi villager told Human Rights Watch that the military used high voltage stun guns, or tasers, to assault villagers. June 4 2011.

Members of ONLF attempt to enter Ethiopia from Somalia but are intercepted by Ethiopian military and engaged. 15 killed, 6 captured, including 2 Swedish nationals. Clashes occurred in two locations. The group entered Ethiopia through the border town of Gaalkacyo. The two Swedish nationals traveling with the ONLF were later charged with terrorism.
""A UN national staff member was injured in a grenade attack in a restaurant in Kebridehar.""

column8: OFDM: Oromo Federalist Democratic Movement Party
column17: Arrests: Government forces arrest 29 members of opposition parties and charge them with terrorism. Both parties involved were members of the Medrek Coalition.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Several army brigades launch offensives on ONLF locations in several areas. The OBLF was able to push them back. No report of casualties.
Two colonial Ethiopian soldiers were killed and four others were wounded at a place called Habala Dabaqodhi in Degeh Madow District.
Arrests: Government forces carry out a mass arrest of ONLF members as well as civilians sympathetic to the ONLF in Fir Fir town.
Two colonial soldiers were killed and many more wounded in an attack in a remote town. A colonial military camp in the town was also destroyed.
Three Ethiopian soldiers were killed and four others seriously wounded at a place called Maramero in Garbo District, Nogob Province.
Three colonial Ethiopian soldiers were killed and four others wounded in a heavy attack that took place at Qiyad in Denan District, Shebele Province.
ONLF fighters carried out separate attacks on colonial forces in Anod and Galley in Fik District, Nogob Province, killing a total of 10 soldiers and wounding 14 others.
ONLF fighters carried out separate attacks on colonial forces in Anod and Galley in Fik District, Nogob Province, killing a total of 10 soldiers and wounding 14 others.
ONLF fighters killed four colonial soldiers and wounded three others in Bisid Bur in Warder District, Shebele Province.

ONLF fighters carried out a series of coordinated raids against colonial Ethiopian forces in Lab Irir, Faraqa Toli and Laba Gardey, killing five soldiers and wounding nine others. Full details of the battles could not be obtained, but preliminary information indicated that colonial Ethiopian soldiers suffered heavy casualties.
Military forces kill 10 ONLF members in the Fik Zone of the region.

ONLF fighters carried out a series of coordinated raids against colonial Ethiopian forces in Lab Irir, Faraqa Toli and Laba Gardey, killing five soldiers and wounding nine others. Full details of the battles could not be obtained, but preliminary information indicated that colonial Ethiopian soldiers suffered heavy casualties.

ONLF fighters based in Jerar Province carried out well-planned attacks against colonial forces in Kabala Ad, Bil Ilbur, Gus Awd and Ari Ajo, killing 19 soldiers and wounding 26 others. An assortment of military equipment, notably AK-47 rifles and a large quantity of ammunition, was captured.

ONLF fighters based in Jerar Province carried out well-planned attacks against colonial forces in Kabala Ad, Bil Ilbur, Gus Awd and Ari Ajo, killing 19 soldiers and wounding 26 others. An assortment of military equipment, notably AK-47 rifles and a large quantity of ammunition, was captured.

ONLF fighters based in Jerar Province carried out well-planned attacks against colonial forces in Kabala Ad, Bil Ilbur, Gus Awd and Ari Ajo, killing 19 soldiers and wounding 26 others. An assortment of military equipment, notably AK-47 rifles and a large quantity of ammunition, was captured.

ONLF fighters attacked colonial military bases in Degeh Bur town and Kabarroyan in Aware District, killing eight soldiers and wounding 12 others. Military warehouses were also destroyed in Degeh Bur town.

ONLF fighters attacked colonial military bases in Degeh Bur town and Kabarroyan in Aware District, killing eight soldiers and wounding 12 others. Military warehouses were also destroyed in Degeh Bur town.
An ONLF unit killed three colonial Ethiopian soldiers and wounded five others in a well-organized attack at a place called Marehan in Fik District, Nogob Province.
Four Ethiopian soldiers were killed and three others were wounded in Holo in Jerar Province.
Five colonial soldiers were killed and seven others were wounded after coming under a heavy attack in Babile.
OLA commando unit operating in central Oromiya killed four weyane police officers and wounded one at a cinder block factory in Finfine (Addis Ababa).
An opposition leader and journalist is arrested and charged with terrorism.
ONLA freedom fighters attacked a group of Ethiopian troops at a place called Hagion in Degeh Bur District, Jerar Province, killing two soldiers and wounding two others.
ONLF/A fighters attack military positions in Fik town.

ONLA units carried out a heavy attack on Chinese oil firm PetroTrans and Ethiopian troops guarding them at a place called Iley, near Obale in the district of Degeh Bur, Jerar Province, where they were conducting oil exploration activity. Thirty government troops killed.
Ethiopian troops go into a blind rage after and attack by ONLA, kill a civilian.

ONLA units carried out a heavy attack on Chinese oil firm PetroTrans and Ethiopian troops guarding them at a place called Iley, near Obale in the district of Degeh Bur, Jerar Province, where they were conducting oil exploration activity. Thirty government troops killed.
ONLA fighters carried out an attack against Ethiopian troops who were deployed at a place called Moyaha in Kebri Beyah.
An OLA commando unit ambushed weyane soldiers at a place called Salal Qala in Abote District, North Shewa Zone, killing seven soldiers on the spot and seriously wounding 12 others.
Government forces kill a boy and middle aged man in the southeast portion of the country.
ONLF/A fighters use a remote control explosive against a weyane convoy inflicting heavy causalities.
ONLF/A fighters rescue civilians from their weyane abductors, clash with them.
Weyane soldiers abduct Ogaden civilians, reports of mistreatment. The abductions lead to numerous clashes with the ONLA in following days.
Clashes between ONLF/A and weyane soldiers results in the death of 22, plus 17 injured.
ONLF/A fighters attack government soldiers, kill 85 and capture many AK-47s in the southeast.
At least one Ethiopian was killed and three other were injured as residents fought Ethiopian police forces in Bali-dhiig district of Togdheer Region in the breakaway region of Somaliland.
Arrests: A large group of police enter a mosque and attempt to detain religious leaders before armed residents resist.
Ogaden rebels capture a military base. The Ethiopian casualties in this operation are 12 dead and more than 16 wounded, some very seriously.

On the evening of 18 November 2011 at about 8:00 p.m. local time, an OLA unit of Northern Oromiya Command infiltrated into an enemy camp located in Kuyu County at a place called Malka Wachiti, killings even weyane (TPLF) troops and wounding more than 12 others.

The same OLA unit active November 18th attacked another weyane camp located in Yaya Gulele County at a place called Malka Mogor in a village called Arertu, killing five enemy troops and wounding, at least, three others. In these operations the OLA Northern Oromiya Command confiscated military armament and made them the property of the Oromo liberation struggle led by OLF.

February 2012, an Ethiopian Sugar Corporation truck ran over a pregnant Bodi woman, the sixth Bodi to be run over by a truck since work on the plantations began less than a year before. In retaliation, the family of the woman's husband shot up the truck, smashed plantation equipment, and had a shoot-out with the military. A few Bodi were injured, but they had to retreat to the other side of the Omo River as they ran out of bullets.

Dozens of university students protested in front of the US embassy in Ethiopias capital, demanding an end to police crackdowns. At least 25 were injured and 49 were arrested when police intervened to disperse them. 20 of the students were charged on charges of 'inciting the public through false rumors', and face up to three years in prison if convicted. Alleged members of South Sudans Murle tribe reportedly killed 208 civilians, injured 80 and abducted 159 children in Jakawa, in Gambela region. 68 children remained unaccounted for six months later and were believed to have been forcibly moved across the border into South Sudan. Ethiopian forces killed 60 of the attackers in the aftermath of the event.

column7: Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan); Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan)

Some of the deceased were members of the Ethiopian Anuak ethnic group. 23 South Sudanese refugees were charged with the murders on 16 August.

Four Nuer Ethiopians were killed in separate incidents on 23 and 24 April; they also attacked buildings and vehicles belonging to the United Nations and Doctors Without Borders (MSF), which they accuse of aiding Nuer refugees.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes erupted on the Ethiopian/Somaliland border when a dispute in Gashamo district in between Somali/Isaaq/HaberYouis khat transporters and Ethiopian forces (federal police, customs) attempting to control a vehicle transporting contraband. A series of clashes and vehicle chases followed ending with an attack by the Liyiu Police on the village of Jama Dubad. An SEMG investigation later indicated that 27 were killed, including 20 armed men, and reportedly, 3 women and 4 children.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police division in Somali region arrested and detained at least 32 people in retaliation for a planned protest by their relatives in Australia the same day. As of November 2016, most remained in detention, while some who had been released denounced daily beatings while being held in custody.

column16: All Africa; Atlantic Council; Eritrea Television; AFP; Shabait; Meskerem
column17: Clashes broke out between Eritrean and Ethiopian forces in the Tsorena front, along the two countries border. Both sides blamed each other for the attack. Eritrea confirmed that 18 Eritrean soldiers had died in the attack. In a retaliatory attack the fllowing day, Eritrea allegedly crossed into Ethiopia at Kudu Haiwa, killing 200 Ethiopian soldiers, injuring 300 and capturing 52. A more conservative estimate by Horn Affairs puts the casualties as 30.

Similar protests occurred in refugee camps across Ethiopia.

column16: Deutsche Welle; EBC; AFP; Addis Standard; ENA
column17: Police and soldiers exchanged gunfire with Amhara residents and activists of Gonder for two days after police had come to arrest 6 members of the ""Welkayit committee"" over alleged criminal activities. 16 people died, including 11 security agents, and at least 16 members of the federal and regional police were injured. Police later arrested four activists involved in the violence. Property damage was also recorded. Ethiopian government officials blame opposition groups based in Eritrea for the unrest in Gonder, while residents say ethnic tensions are behind the skirmishes. The Wolkayit committee has been protesting against the governments decision to merge the Wolkayit community and its land into the neighboring Tigray Regional State for over two decades, as they identify more with the Amharas than with the Tigrayans. Several internationals were evacuated from the town.
People protested against the government agenda at the funeral of a protester who died from injuries suffered during a protest in Adaba six months prior.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column16: Addis Standard; EBC; ESAT; Al Jazeera; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
column17: Unidentified group set fire to the Qilinto maximum security prison in southern Addis Abeba, after an alleged riot by prisoners. Intensive gunfire by prison guards and local police was reported following the event, to allegedly prevent any prison break. A later investigation found that 67 prisoners were killed in the event, including 23 who died in the fire and 45 who were killed by prison wardens while allegedly trying to escape. At least nine prisoners and police were injured. Authorities in December charged 37 inmates for the arson.

More than 400 shops and business centres in Gonder, the epicentre of recent political unrest and protests, were burnt down to the ground, causing significant property and material damage. Although the cause of the fire is under investigation, locals suspect military forces to have carried out an act of sabotage.

Teachers participating in a 10 day induction conference engaged in silent protests by refusing to ask or answer comments, and boycotting food provided by the regime. This comes as the government postponed the beginning of the schoolyear.
Soldiers allegedly beat a women in Deders Kufanzik village, East Hararghe, and later killed a man for showing an Oromo resistance symbol while they were beating her.
Residents of Bahir Dar went on a stay at home protest against the government agenda, leaving parts of the town deserted. The situation was reported to have improved by the end of the same week.

Amhara prisoners at Bir Sheleko military training camp are allegedly being forced to take drugs without professional medical expertise as a form of corporal punishment. A group of Amhara physicians have denounced the practice as torture. Reports alleged that at least 800 youth accused to have taken part in the recent waves of protests in Gonder, Bahir Dar and other districts were currently being held in the camp.
ONLF forces attacked a military convoy in Xamaro (Nogob), killing 3 soldiers and injuring another 4.

column16: Ethiomedia; Al Jazeera; HRW; Angola Press Agency; Oromiya Media Network; Sudan Tribune; AFP; AP
column17: Thousands of Oromos gathered in Bishoftu to celebrate Irecha festivities marched in the streets of Bishoftu chanting slogans and crossing their arms above their heads to protest against the government agenda. Elements among the protesters reportedly attempted to take over the stage where prominent religious leaders deemed close to the government were addressing the gathering, leading to a scuffle with security officers who were blocking them and throwing of rocks and plastic bottles by some of the protesters. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters, leading to a deadly stampede which left at least 55 people dead and dozens more injured. Opposition figures put the death toll to at least 678, and declared ""five days of rage"" following the events. Immediately after the incident, protesters reportedly began blocking roads on the way to Hawassa and Ambo, and clashed with the police. Human rights organisations have called for an independent investigation into the violence.
Soldiers in helicopters reportedly shot two people in Mojo town returning from Irecha festivities following violence.
People protested in Bishoftu against violence the day before during Iresha celebrations. Soldiers reportedly dispersed the protest violently.

column9: Students (Ethiopia); Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: Amhara and Oromo students at Hawasa University boycotted meals for two days to protest against the government agenda following violence during Iresha festivities in Boshoftu. Soldiers allegedly responded violently to the student boycott.
People in Incini protested against violence during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu the day before. The protesters set up road blocks in the town

People protested in Muger, Oromia against violence during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu the day before. The protesters set up road blocks in the town as well as burnt down a truck owned by Dangote cement.
People in Goro town, Meta Walkite district, West Shewa, protested against violence during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu the day before.

People in Ejaji, west Shewa, protested against violence during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu the day before.

Dozens of attacks targeting government-owned or government-supported farms and businesses have been carried out by Oromo rioters since violence occurred during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.

Dozens of attacks targeting government-owned or government-supported farms and businesses have been carried out by Oromo rioters since the violence occurred.

The riots were in protest against violence that occurred the day before during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu. This is the first foreigner killed since anti-government protests started a year back, claiming the lives of hundreds of protesters.
