column16: Oromiya Media Network; Addis Standard; AP
column17: Rioters burnt down 11 flower farms and textile and cement factories in Sebeta between 3-8 October to protest against the government agenda following violence during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October. They caused significant property damage and were also reported to have injured personnel working at the premises.

column9: Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018); Private Security Forces (Ethiopia)
column17: Oromo rioters reportedly destroyed 300 government-owned, government-supported and foreign factories (especially textile, plastic and bottled-water companies) and farms in Oromia, leaving four managers and two armed guards killed. Over 1,200 offices, including police stations, prisons and military camps, were also reportedly attacked, as well as 500 government-owned vehicles including trucks and buses, leaving three drivers killed. The attacks occurred between 3 and 8 October in places located within a 100km radius from Addis Ababa, and were carried out in retaliation for violence that marred Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.

Oromo rioters reportedly destroyed 300 government-owned, government-supported and foreign factories (especially textile, plastic and bottled-water companies) and farms in Oromia, leaving four managers and two armed guards killed. Over 1,200 offices, including police stations, prisons and military camps, were also reportedly attacked, as well as 500 government-owned vehicles including trucks and buses, leaving three drivers killed. The attacks occurred between 3 and 8 October in places located within a 100km radius from Addis Ababa, and were carried out in retaliation for violence that marred Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.

Gedeo people protested and clashed with soldiers in Dilla, SNNP, in support of Oromos protesting violence in Bishoftu a few days prior.
People protested against the government agenda in Dire Dawa, following the death of dozens of people a few days prior during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu.

Rioters in Negele Borena destroyed property belonging to government forces and clashed with soldiers. Dozens of attacks targeting government-owned or government-supported farms and businesses have been carried out by Oromo rioters since violence occurred during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.

Report of attacks by Gedeo militias on the Gurage and Silte communities in Dila town, Gedeo Zone of the SNNP region, leaving at least 23 people killed, 50 houses burnt down, 30 vehicles destroyed and forcing dozens of people to flee the town. The Gedeo assailants are believed to be among the dead. Other sources put the number of fatalities at 63. The events are believed to result from tensions over wealth differentials between Gedeo people and other communities living in the zone. At least 11 killed in Dila town, the remaining fatalities split among other areas. There are reports of TPLF cadres aiding the Gedeo in the clashes.

Rioters with sticks and stones having set up road blocks in Oromia clashed with UN personnel. The rioters stopped the UN vehicle, questionned them, ordered them to switch off all radios and take out the SIM card of their cell-phones. The UN vehicle was eventually let past the road block.
Rioters reportedly threw a boulder rock at a military truck near Metehara, pushing the truck over a nearby cliff. Some estimates give 25 fatalities others give no fatalities.

Report of attacks by Gedeo militias on the Gurage and Silte communities in Dila town, Gedeo Zone of the SNNP region, leaving at least 23 people killed, 50 houses burnt down, 30 vehicles destroyed and forcing dozens of people to flee the town. The Gedeo assailants are believed to be among the dead. Other sources put the number of fatalities at 63. The events are believed to result from tensions over wealth differentials between Gedeo people and other communities living in the zone. At least 11 killed in Dila town, the remaining fatalities split among other areas. There are reports of TPLF cadres aiding the Gedeo in the clashes.

Soldiers reportedly use artillery and mortars to attack villages in West Arsi, East Shewa and South West Shewa in the context of region-wide protests and riots against the government agenda following violence during Iresha celebrations in Bishoftu. No report of casualties.

Rioters reportedly destroyed an Al Amoudi owned Tea Farm in Gumaro. Dozens of attacks targeting government-owned or government-supported farms and businesses have been carried out by Oromo rioters since violence occurred during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.
Students at Haramaya university boycotted meals in protest against the government agenda and the recent violence in Bishoftu during Iresha celebrations.

Security Measures: Ethiopia declared a state of emergency for six months for the first time in 25 years following months of anti-government protests, especially in the restive Oromia region. The directive of the measure bans campaigns that could incite violence and disturbances, including protesting, including in schools, gesturing, exchanging opposition messages on social media, watching opposition TV programmes, and closing businesses and shops. The government also limits diplomats travel beyond 40km outside the capital without permission, forbids unauthorized people to approach businesses at night, and defines red zones outside the capital.

Soldiers reportedly use artillery and mortars to attack villages in West Arsi, East Shewa and South West Shewa in the context of region-wide protests and riots against the government agenda following violence during Iresha celebrations in Bishoftu. No report of casualties.

Soldiers reportedly use artillery and mortars to attack villages in West Arsi, East Shewa and South West Shewa in the context of region-wide protests and riots against the government agenda following violence during Iresha celebrations in Bishoftu. No report of casualties.

Dozens of attacks targeting government-owned or government-supported farms and businesses have been carried out by Oromo rioters since violence occurred during Iresha festivities in Bishoftu on 2 October.
Students at Jimma University in Oromia protested against the state of emergency announced by the government the day before. Police reportedly arrested about 200 students during the protest.
Ethiopian soldiers reportedly killed the Gedeo zone police commander in Dila, SNNP, entering the town after tribal clashes re-erupted.
Security Measures: Report of soldiers having put the Kolfe Fetno Derash district of Addis Ababa under siege and harassed residents in the context of increased anti-government protests.
Soldiers reportedly killed 28 people and looted properties in Hirora town, West Arsi Zone, Oromia.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018)
column17: An Oromo soldier reportedly killed the chief of army operations in Harare, Haramaya, Aweday and Dire Dawa in Eastern Ethiopia.
Arsi university students protested against the government agenda in Asela, Arsi.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Residents from the Hamar tribe have attacked a local prison, freeing prisoners and seizing weapons. They also closed a roadway leading to a sugar plantation.

column16: Fana Broadcasting Corporate; Addis Standard; Oromiya Media Network; AP
column17: Reports of up to 380 Oromo people killed by security forces and up to 35,000 arrested across Oromia between 3-17 October in response to the riots that followed the heavy casualties during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu early October. 200 were reportedly killed in West Arsi (28 deaths already coded on 10 October), 75 in East Shewa and 47 in East Arsi (11 deaths already coded on 13 October).

column16: Addis Standard; AP; Oromiya Media Network; Fana Broadcasting Corporate
column17: Reports of up to 380 Oromo people killed by security forces and up to 35,000 arrested across Oromia between 3-17 October in response to the riots that followed the heavy casualties during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu early October. 200 were reportedly killed in West Arsi (28 deaths already coded on 10 October), 75 in East Shewa and 47 in East Arsi (11 deaths already coded on 13 October).

column16: Addis Standard; Oromiya Media Network; Fana Broadcasting Corporate; AP
column17: Reports of up to 380 Oromo people killed by security forces and up to 35,000 arrested across Oromia between 3-17 October in response to the riots that followed the heavy casualties during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu early October. 200 were reportedly killed in West Arsi (28 deaths already coded on 10 October), 75 in East Shewa and 47 in East Arsi (11 deaths already coded on 13 October).
11 people were reportedly killed in a fire at Ziway prison south of Addis Ababa. The fire is believed to be have been a government plot to kill targeted prisoners.
A policeman was killed and four others injured at a sugar plantation project when local Hamar tribesmen attacked it. The plantation was allegedly built on land taken from locals.
Arba Minch University students in SNNP protested against the government agenda. Police later arrested 27 students.
Amhara people reportedly deserted the streets of Bahir Dar in protest against the government agenda.

column7: Students (Ethiopia); Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: Oromo and Amhara students of Debre Markos University protested against the government agenda.
Report of up to 50 soldiers killed in clashes between Amhara people and soldiers in Armacheho while the soldiers were trying to disarm farmers.
Report of clashes between soldiers and protesters in Jawi village, Robe district, East Arsi, leaving 11 people killed.
Looting: Report of soldiers breaking into and looting homes and livestock across Oromia.
People protested against the government agenda in Kofele, west Arsi.
Over 100,000 protested against the government agenda during the funeral of a civilian killed the week prior in Xaxaxo town, Meta Robi district.
Soldiers reportedly killed a civilian in Doni town, Bosat district, East Shewa, in the context of a government-imposed state of emergency in the region.
Clashes between unidentified armed group and soldiers in Golole village, near Hidilola in Borena zone, leaving at least several soldiers injured.
Rioters burnt down the home of an OPDO official in Kokosa suspected of helping government soldiers identify activists in the area.

Gonder residents in Amhara began a three day stay-at-home campaign to protest against the government agenda and the recently imposed state of emergency, paralysing schools, businesses and transportation in the town.
Soldiers reportedly killed three youths in Kokosa district, West Arsi, in the context of a government-imposed state of emergency in the region.
Soldiers reportedly killed a civilian in Shashamane in the context of a government-imposed state of emergency in the region.
Soldiers reportedly killed a civilian in Abaro, West Arsi, in the context of a government-imposed state of emergency in the region.

column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column16: AP; Addis Standard; Fana Broadcasting Corporate
column17: Arrests: Report by the state of emergencys Command Post that security officers arrested and detained 1,500 people across Oromia between 17-19 October linked to riots that followed the heavy casualties during Irecha festivities in Bishoftu early October. 450 people were arrested in Shashemene and 670 in surrounding localities in West Arsi for ""violence and property damage"", 302 in Guji, 110 in Dembi Dolo of Kelem Welega, 122 in and around Gonder in Amhara, including for closing their businesses or calling for strikes, and 35 in Bahir Dar for denying services in protest against the government agenda. Dozens of weapons were seized during the arrests.
Soldiers reportedly killed a civilian in Bedesa town, West Hararge, in the context of a government-imposed state of emergency in the region, and shot at three other people trying to lift his body.
Ethiopian soldiers shot and killed a student at Bule Hora University.

Defection: Two members of the Eritrean air force defected with their military jets to Ethiopia, arriving in Mekele in Tigray. Dozens of Eritrean pilots and members of the navy defected to neighboring countries over the past few years.
Ethiopian soldiers killed two young men in Taji town, Ilu district, South West Shewa.

Arrests: Authorities transported at least 30,000 political prisoners arrested after violence in Irecha early October to military bases in Amhara, Afar and Oromia. Opposition members put the number at 60,000.

column7: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front; APP: Afar Peoples Party; SLF: Sidama Liberation Front; AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Change to armed group: Four armed opposition parties joined forces and formed the ""Ethiopian Movement"" (Patriotic Ginbot 7, Oromo Democratic Front, Afar People Party and Sidama People Democratic Movement). The party is said to hold meeting outside Ethiopia.
Report of a young man killed by relatives of the Somali Regional State President.
Ethiopian soldiers executed three young men who had earlier been arrested near Dembi Dolo in Kelem Wellega.

column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: Arrests: Inquiry board reveals that security officers under the Command Post arrested and detained an additional 10,000 people across central and western Oromia, northern Amhara, and Addis Ababa, between 20 October-11 November, in the context of the declared state of emergency. The arrested were accused of inciting violence, destroying public and private goods, or disrupting traffic by erecting barricades on roads. They are being held in six detention centers and military camps around the country, including 4,329 in Tolay military camp.

column9: Prisoners (Ethiopia); Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: Agreement: Ethiopian authorities freed more than 2,000 prisoners jailed following the recent violence in Oromia and Amhara regions and imposition of a state of emergency, while around 400 suspects surrendered to the government before the end of a 10-day amnesty ultimatum, enabling the recovery of 1,500 arms.
Ethiopian soldiers beat to death a man in Sedika town, Arsi.
Report of a bomb attack in Bahir Dar in Amhara region.

column16: Eye Radio (South Sudan); Sudan Tribune; Radio Tamazuj
column17: Ethiopian police arrested at least 38 South Sudanese university students from the universities of Mekelle, Bardar, Jimma, Awasa and Technical Vocational Training Institute (TVET) on government scholarships after they protested in front of their embassy in Addis Abeba against delayed living stipend over the past 14 months. A representative of the students claimed that the South Sudan acting ambassador ordered their arrest. The students were reportedly released five days later after having been beaten in jail.

A group of six armed men from the Surma tribe attacked a vehicle transporting ten European tourists, including six from Slovakia and four from the Czech Republic, in Surma woreda, Bech Maji zone in SNNPR, leaving one of the four local drivers dead and one tourist lightly injured. The assailants also robbed the tourists.
Militia of Amhara farmers clashed overnight with government forces in Wegera district of northern Gonder, reportedly leaving 21 killed and abducting over 50 government soldiers.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Report of up to 85 prisoners killed at Tolay military camp in Jimma after they protested harsh punishment in the form of physical labor and starvation.

column9: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Clashes between Ethiopian forces and EPPF and Patriotic Ginbot 7 rebels in various places across Amhara and Tigray over 10-17 November (Adebay, Behaker, Kafta Humera, Lower Armacheho, Abraha-Jira, Gewla and Atsme-Harmaz). Rebels claimed to have taken control of Adebay, Gewla and Atsme by 17 November and to have inflicted considerable damage against government forces. Ginbot7 claim 40 government soldiers killed in the attacks.

column9: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement

Amhara militiamen raided an Ethiopian military camp in Sanja, north Gonder, killing an unknown number of Ethiopian soldiers and seizing weapons. Ethiopian forces reportedly engaged the combatents in the days that followed.

column9: ANDM: Amhara National Democratic Movement; Government of Ethiopia (1991-)
column17: An Ethiopian Parliament member representing Bahir Dar in the House of Representatives and member of the Amhara National Democratic Movement (ANDM) was killed by unknown gunmen at her office in Addis Ababa.

A member of the command post overseeing the state of emergency in Dabat town, north Gonder, shot and killed two individuals for allegedly blocking a road in protest. He also killed a local police officer who tried to intervene. The shooter was also injured in the clash with the policeman.

column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Teachers (Ethiopia); Health Workers (Ethiopia)
column17: The chief of Jimma University specialised teaching hospital was abducted by unknown gunmen. He remained missing and his whereabout unknown a week later.
A student at Jimma University was abducted by unknown gunmen. He remained missing and his whereabout unknown four days later.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Defection: 13 Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church leaders serving at the Waldeba Monastery in Gonder defected to the Patriotic Ginbot 7 Movement for Unity and Democracy due to frustratations by the Ethiopian regime. They were known for participating in the organisation of recent popular uprisings in North Gonder.
Reported clashes between Ethiopian soldiers and Oromo farmers in Wallo, Dawe Harawa district in Oromia.
Soldiers arrested 18 protesting students in Bale in the week of 20 November.
Overnight protest by students at Jimma university against the detention of fellow students by security forces. Soldiers arrested 28 students in relations to the protest.
Students at Walaga university in Nekemt protested on campus. Gunfire was being heard (source unknown).
Students at Ambo university protested increased harassment by soldiers stationed on campus. Several were reportedly injured in their response to the protest.
Two policemen killed by Oromo farmers militia in Bora town, Dawe district, Wallo.
Students at Ambo university protested for a second day. Soldiers fired tear gas to prevent them from getting out of their rooms.
Arrests: Members of the command post allegedly detained 48 members of the Oromia Police in Sebeta, Special Finfinne Zone.
Students at Jimma university protested on campus. They were reportedly beaten by soldiers.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Government forces attack rebels of Ginbot 7 in Abderafi, Armacho, north Gonder. A Patriotic Ginbot 7 commander killed himself as his team got surrounded by government forces. Government forces later reported that 15 rebels had been killed and 73 captured in clashes with the group.
Soldiers reportedly beat and arrested two singers in Addis Ababa and in Dire Dawa and arrested another in Burayu in the course of the same day.

2nd and 4th year students of veterinary pharmacy at Gonder University boycotted class complaining about lack of qualified teachers. Soldiers arrested 104 in response to the protests and suspended them from school for the academic year the following week.
Report that two people died at Tolay military camp in Jimma. They were arrested in Bidire town, Madda Walbu District in Bale, during the wave of protests in the region in previous months.
OLA ambushed Ethiopian special force soldiers on their way from Awash to China camp, killing 13, wounding more than 20 and capturing armaments.

State forces arrested OFCs Chairman Merera Gudina at his home in Addis Ababa for violating state of emergency restrictions after he denounced the governments crackdown on anti-govt protests at a European Parliament hearing on 9 November. He was taken to an unknown destination along with three other party members. It was later reported that he was badly beaten in detention, leaving him with a broken hand. Additional supporters of Gudina were arrested in the weeks that followed, including his lawyer on 16 December.
Gunmen killed a man in his home and injured another two in Rayitu district of Bale province.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Patriotic Ginbot 7 forces carried out successful attacks on government forces in Addis Alem around November/early December. Scarce details.
OLA forces killed a local command post commander in Dewale over his alleged involvement in crimes perpetrated in the area.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Patriotic Ginbot 7 forces carried out successful attacks on government forces in Dansha around November/early December. Scarce details.

OLA ambushed a shipment of internet equipment in Awash, leaving four people in the vehicle killed, including three Chinese and the driver, and the vehicle destroyed. The shipment was suspected to have been imported by the government from China through Djibouti to monitor internet activity and spy on ethnic groups, including Oromos, on social media.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: A prisoner reportedly died from torture at a prison in Degeluna Tijo district of Arsi.

Students at Woldia university protested against the government agenda at Woldia university, specifically denouncing the political and economic domination by Tigrayan oligarchs in the region, defying the state of emergency. At least 45 were arrested.
Students at Woldia university boycotted classes, demanding the release of their colleagues arrested for protesting three days prior.
Arrests: Security forces arrested at least 50 youths in Haiq, south Wollo, early December, for unclear reasons.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Defection: 46 Ethiopian government soldiers reportedly defected to join Patriotic Ginbot 7 in northern Ethiopia early December.
Clashes between government forces and unknown rebel forces in Dabat of north Gonder and in Jawi of Agew Awi early December.
Property destruction: Government forces reportedly burned down houses and crops belonging to families of rebel militias fighting them following recent heavy clashes in northern Ethiopia.
Clashes between government forces and unknown rebel forces in Dabat of north Gonder and in Jawi of Agew Awi early December.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Reports emerge that prisoners at Qilinto prison in Addis Ababa are being tortured and abused by prison officers. 37 prisoners appearing in court early December over the September incident at the prison said they were made to strip and beaten brutally, and could show marks on their bodies.
The Ogaden National Liberation Army attacked soldiers stationed in Dumodlay Village on the 15th of December, 2016; killing 6 soldiers and wounded 8 others, according to ONA.

16 December 2016, the OLA engaged in a battle with Ethiopian military forces in a place called Buri in the district of Haro Dibe of Bale Zone. Twelve enemy soldiers were killed and more than 15 others wounded in the fighting.
On 17 December 2016, the OLA attacked troops encamped at a water well known as Ela Roqa in Gale Dima area of Bale Zone, killing 12 of them and wounding more than 10 others.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: A prisoner was killed during a prison revolt against an attempt by prison guards to move a controversial figure into solitary confinement.
On 18 December 2016, the OLA ambushed government troops in a place known as Goro Mudhi Sonsa in the district of Goro of Bale Zone, killing 17 soldiers and wounding more than nine others.
in East Harage, Babile Arada, special police killed a man and took 6 others.
Students protest at Wollo University

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Three police officers and a prisoner have reportedly been killed in a shootout between the federal police and prison police in a dispute to take custody of a Colonel who supports the demand of the Wolkait people movement.

On 19 December 2016, a battle erupted between the OLA and Ethiopian military forces in a place known as Kara Bururi in the district of Haro Dibe of Bale Zone forces. Nine enemy soldiers were killed and more than 11 others wounded in the fighting which started at 6 p.m. and lasted until 6:30 p.m.

Agreement: Ethiopia has reportedly released thousands of prisoners who had been jailed during the state of emergency. People detained in Awash, Alage, Bir Sheleko and Tolay centers will be allowed to return home after receiving training,
On December 28, 2016 Ethiopian military soldiers arrested and killed a young man near Doni town in Bosat district, East Shawa.
Unknown assailants attacked a bus carrying 40 passengers outside the town of Gambella, western Ethiopia, killing five passengers. 20 suspects have been arrested.

Special police from the Somali region attack the border town of Mino, leaving 6 Oromia police officers, 4 government employees and 3 local militia members dead. Details scarce, and further casualties are likely.
Special police killed a man in East Hararge (misraq Hararge). Scarce details
Special police kill a man in East Hararge, Gursum, in the village of Kasaa

The Murle of South Sudan continued their cross border raid into the Gambella region of Ethiopia, reportedly killing 30 Anyuaks and abducting 106 children in the last six months. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said successive cross-border attacks by the South Sudanese Murle ethnic group in July and January last year and in February led to displacements and death, announcing that 'At least 3,714 people (743 households) are reportedly displaced, the majority taking shelter in Ongoi Town and Alemi and Thoo localities."" Casualties are spread across 2 other attacks occurring on the 5th and 26th of February respectively.
On 2 January, the BPLM reportedly killed over 40 government officials and members of the federal police and wounded 80 others during an attack in Kuwar Shuru Kole area.
Regime security forces reportedly killed a man in his residence in Bahir Dar on Jan 3, 2017. The man was arrested and later shot.
A grenade was detonated at Bahir Dar hotel where several government officials were staying. No casualties have been reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: A Young Oromo man dies while in custody in Tolay military camp, Ethiopia

First day of battles between Benishangul People's Liberation Movement and the military. A human rights activist confirms 8 regime soldiers dead while the rebel group puts the fatalities at 51 regime soldiers. Civilians also killed.

Second day of battles between Benishangul People's Liberation Movement and the military. A human rights activist confirms 8 dead while the rebel group puts the fatalities at 51 regime soldiers. Civilians also killed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: Reports of torture in Qilinto prison, especially targeting members of the OFC.

According to activists, during the last three weeks at least 23 incidents of cross boarder attacks have been recorded in five provinces ( West Hararge, East Hararge, Bale, Borana and Guji) resulting in killing of at least 47 people (15 previously recorded attacks in Misraq (east) Hararge. Attacks are reportedly being carried out by the Somali region special police forces.

Attacks are reportedly being carried out by the Somali region special police forces.

Attacks are reportedly being carried out by the Somali region special police forces.

According to activists, during the last three weeks at least 23 incidents of cross boarder attacks have been recorded in five provinces ( West Hararge, East Hararge, Bale, Borana and Guji) resulting in killing of at least 47 people (15 previously recorded attacks in Misraq (east) Hararge. Attacks are reportedly being carried out by the Somali region special police forces.
A bomb is detonated in a hotel in Gondar town. No party has claimed responsibility for the attack. 4 wounded, no fatalities reported.

An Ethiopian rebel group, the Benishangul People's Liberation Movement (BPLM), says it has killed 13 government soldiers and wounded eight others in western Ethiopia close to the Sudanese border in Belo, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State.
An office building for the Lideta sub-city administration has caught fire amid heightened tensions in the city, followed by a power outage. No group has claimed responsibility for the fire.
Police said that one person was killed and 18 others wounded after a grenade was thrown on Tuesday into the Entasol Hotel in Gondar town.
Sixteen soldiers have reportedly been killed and 30 others wounded in an ambush in Wolkaiyt Tsegede, northern Ethiopia.

Arrests: Dozens of people belonging to the Dorze ethnic group in southern Ethiopia have been arrested and charged with supporting ""terrorism"", including links to Ginbot 7. This comes in the context of the State of Emergency which was imposed in August of the last year.
A suspected spy for the Government of Ethiopia was killed last night.
South Sudanese Murle tribesmen killed 11 people and abducted 20 children during an attack carried out on the 15th of January in Ethiopia's southwestern Gambela Regional State.
Detonation: A grenade exploded in a cotton processing plant in Genda Wuha, causing a fire that destroyed the plant.
An explosion occurred during an epiphany (Timket) celebration in Janulana, Gondar Zone . No casualties reported

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitaries from the Somali Region have allegedly invaded Mayyu Mulluqqe town in East Hararghe zone. Subsequent clashes led to 4 casualties and many homes being burned. This is part of a series of violent events that have been occurred in this region since the beginning of the new year.
A number of youth are arrested after a demonstration during the Epiphany celebration in Lafto sub-city, Addis Ababa.
An Ethiopian police officer was found dead on the road near Borrayyu, Ethiopia. There have been reports of unrest in the area.

Ethiopian soldiers entered a bus in the town of Moyale in Borena zone and accused several aboard of having contraband from Kenya. Those accused refused to get off the bus and the soldiers opened fire, killing 4 and wounding 8 others aboard. Those injured were taken to the hospital in Moyale.
A young Oromo man was killed by EDF personnel in Arjo Guddato woreda of east wollega, Niqamte city. Details surrounding the incident are unclear. Feb 1 2017

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes yesterday between Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromiya police force personnel left 1 Oromia police officer dead and a second wounded. This took place in Ibro Musa village , Muqura, in Hararghe province.

Four regime soldiers have reportedly been killed while several other injured in Benishangul Gumuz region, western Ethiopia. A source who spoke to ESAT said that the soldiers were ambushed in Sherkole, a gold mining area, by armed groups who call themselves freedom fighters.
According to sources, 8 Anyuaks were killed while 16 children were abducted in a cross-border raid conducted by Murle tribesmen from South Sudan.

Reports from north Gondar say that Ethiopian regime forces have used heavy artillery on Monday during an abush on anti-government forces which resulted in the death of 4 of the rebel fighteers. At least 18 soldiers of the regime are believed to have been killed or injured in the resulting battle that lasted four hours.
Security forces killed two people in Afar after locals confronted the soldiers in an attempt to free one of their own, who had been arrested and beaten.

Sources say that regime forces were still firing heavy artillery on Tuesday in Belesa, setting homes of the fighters ablaze. This comes the day after a four hour battle between regime forces and opposition militias resulted in many casualties. It is unknown if there were casualties as a result of the shelling on Tuesday.

column7: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Unidentified Armed Group (Ethiopia)
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: First day of battles between Somali regional Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromia police officers with unknown militia allies. Unnamed ""freedom fighters"" aligned with Oromiya police officers clash with special forces from the country's Somali region. Fighting took place across several different villages in Gursum District, West Harerge Zone [eastern Ethiopia]. According to sources who spoke to OMN 5 Five Liyu Police officers killed. Source: OMN audio in Amharic on Feb 9th 2017

column7: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Unidentified Armed Group (Ethiopia)
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Second day of battles between Somali regional Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromia police officers with unknown militia allies. Unnamed ""freedom fighters"" aligned with Oromiya police officers clash with special forces from the country's Somali region. Fighting took place across several different villages in Gursum District, West Harerge Zone [eastern Ethiopia]. According to sources who spoke to OMN 5 Five Liyu Police officers killed. Source: OMN audio in Amharic on Feb 9th 2017

The Australia-based Qeerroo [Youth for Freedom and Democracy] said that residents of Sinana District in Bale Zone [southern Ethiopia] have destroyed and burned down properties of some people who were suspected of being spies and informants of the Ethiopian government.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day two of clashes: At least 18 people were killed in southeastern Ethiopia during fighting in Guji Zone, Oromiya Regional State, between residents and soldiers from the national army and Somali Regional forces. Somali regional forces ""liyu division"" have been occupying the area for some time, and were driven out by a civilian based militia early in the day. The soldiers returned and the resulting clashes that lasted over 2 days led to the death of at least 18 people, with further casualties likely.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day two of clashes: At least 18 people were killed in southeastern Ethiopia during fighting in Guji Zone, Oromiya Regional State, between residents and soldiers from the national army and Somali Regional forces. Somali regional forces (Liyu Police paramilitaries) have been occupying the area for some time, and were driven out by a civilian based militia early in the day. The soldiers returned and the resulting clashes that lasted over 2 days led to the death of at least 18 people, with further casualties likely.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Gursum- At least 20 members of the Somali special forces unit (Liyu Police paramilitaries) were killed in Gursum and Bombase in south eastern Ethiopia. The attack was reportedly carried out in retaliation by armed residents in the Oromo region of southern Ethiopia where the Liyu Police forces had reportedly carried out various human rights violations. Following the attack several people were reportedly arrested. According to an Oromo rights activist, the fighting took place in a town called Goree (in Gursum district), and that several were killed, after which the bodies of the dead and wounded were taken by Liyu Police to an unknown location.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Bombase- At least 20 members of the Somali special forces unit (Liyu Police paramilitaries) were killed in Gursum and Bombase in south eastern Ethiopia. The attack was reportedly carried out in retaliation by armed residents in the Oromo region of southern Ethiopia where the Somali forces had reportedly carried out various human rights violations. Following the attack several people were reportedly arrested.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Arrests: Reports of mass arrests being made in Doldola, west Arsi zone. It is estimated that over 200 hundred people from this town and its surrounding villages are currently incarcerated.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: A man died from injuries sustained in Maekelawi prison, reportedly due to torture.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries and armed Oromo citizens in Bale zone, Beltu district, Eela Qilisa village, left 7 Oromos dead and 9 wounded. 13 Liyu Police were reportedly killed during the fighting.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bale Zone Sawena district an intense battle between Liyu Police paramilitaries and armed Oromo citizens left 11 Oromos dead and several more wounded. Fatalities also included 2 federal soldiers and 4 Liyu Police.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day 1 of clashes in Bordode: Town people have risen up against a reported invasion by Liyu Police paramilitaries. During the battle 3 Liyu Policemen were killed and 5 others wounded. Town fighters reportedly seized weapons from the police. 2 Oromo citizens wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Today in Bale Zone Rayitu district in the village of Bokkol, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Ethiopian military units have opened fire, reportedly wounding a number of people. Government employees have fled to the city of Dhaddacha. The troops reportedly stole a number of livestock.
A protest was reported in Chinaksan, East Hararge against invasion and killings by Liyu Police. Protesters demand the Liyu Police and Federal troops leave the area.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day 2 of clashes in Bordode: Units of the Liyu Police paramilitary division reportedly invaded the town of Bordode and closed the roads to the east. Town residents responded violently, and during the clashes 3 liyu policeman were killed and 5 others wounded. Town fighters reportedly seized weapons from the police. 2 Oromo militiamen wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Oromo militias have reportedly killed one Liyu Policeman and wounded another.
Four Anyuaks were killed and four children were kidnapped in a cross border attack by the Murle clan South Sudan

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitary forces pushed forward in the morning in an attempt to take Funyan Bira, and were pushed back by Oromo Militia members. No information on casualties. Fighting is continuing itn the town of Owkaba.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes reported between Liyu Police and local Oromo militias in Arada Misra, ending in the death of 3 Policemen and the wounding of 4 others.

Ethiopian Security forces reportedly killed 13 members of the Benishangul Gumuz People's Liberation Movement (BPLM) who'd traveled from Eritrea to attack the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam. Eritrea denied any involvement. The other members of the group escaped to Sudan, where they were apprehended by the authorities and delivered back to Ethiopia.
Protests reported in Babile, with demonstrators taking to the streets to demand the removal of federal troops from the region.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bale Zone, Raytu district an invasion by members of the Liyu Police paramilitary force caused the displacement of a number of Oromo civilians. Sources also reported 'plundering' by the Liyu policemen, furthering tensions in the region.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Intense clashes reported in Mieso, a total of 6 people were killed
A bomb was reportedly thrown into the residence of the Mayor of Gonder, damaging the house but did not cause any fatalities. It is unclear who threw the bomb

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day one of clashes in Fedis: Two days of clashes in Fedis district, across a number of woredas. A total of 16 people killed including 10 Liyu Policemen, 2 Federal soldiers, and 4 Oromo citizens (including 2 women). Number of wounded much higher and fatalities are expected to rise. Civilians are reportedly fleeing the city.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day two of clashes in Fedis: Two days of clashes in Fedis district, across a number of woredas. A total of 16 people killed including 10 Liyu Policemen, 2 Federal soldiers, and 4 Oromo citizens (including 2 women). Number of wounded much higher and fatalities are expected to rise.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Oromo militias clashed with Liyu Police paramilitaries. 7 Liyu Police reportedly killed and several more wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Unidentified Armed Group (Ethiopia)
column17: A fight broke out between Oromiya region police officers and Liyu Police personnel when the latter attempted to build a house in front of the police station. State soldiers quickly intervened, seperating the two. Casualties are unknown at this time.
Two federal soldiers were found dead in 02 Kebele of Debre Tabor.

A fuel truck travelling from Sudan to Ethiopia came under attack in a place called Negade Bahir (metema) on the Ethiopian side of the border. No further information given at this time and the condition of the driver is unknown. No party claimed responsibility for the ambush.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Armed supporters of the Ginbot 7 movement attacked the prison in Gena Sinroray, freeing several prisoners and harassing federal soldiers. Fatalities were reported but specific numbers are unknown.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: East Hararghe in the town of Midhaga tola - clashes between the Arrada Bilisuma militia (free Arada militia) and Liyu Police paramilitaries in the town of Mudhii Baalliitti continue with 1 policeman killed and 2 wounded. No information on Oromo wounded/fatalities.

18 were killed and dozens of children kidnapped in a series of cross border raid by Murle militants in Gambella's Gog and Jor areas. An Ethiopian envoy is in Juba as of Thursday to find the abducted children and discuss reoccuring security issues along the common border between the two countries.

18 were killed and dozens of children kidnapped in a series of cross border raid by Murle militants in Gambella's Gog and Jor areas. An Ethiopian envoy is in Juba as of Thursday to find the abducted children and discuss reoccuring security issues along the common border between the two countries.

18 were killed and dozens of children kidnapped in a series of cross border raid by Murle militants in Gambella's Gog and Jor areas. An Ethiopian envoy is in Juba as of Thursday to find the abducted children and discuss reoccuring security issues along the common border between the two countries.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Intense Clashes in Mieso reportedly leave 4 dead.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 16 killed and 18 wounded during clashes in Qote bulaa in Seweyna district of Bale. Reports indicate that thousands are fleeing the Liyu Police paramilitary force, causing food security concerns.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes in Kasu of Gursum district between local Oromo militias and Liyu Police from Somali region. 2 fatalities reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Oromo militia fighters the Liyu Police paramilitaries from Somali region in Doba district, in a place called Kommiftu. Gunfire began at 8 in the morning and has lasted until 4 in the afternoon. One person was killed and 6 people wounded.
In the town of Burqa Tirtira, Ethiopian military personnel have violently repressed an opposition rally, wounding 3 people and arresting 16 more.
A man was shot in the leg by Ethiopian security forces. Details surrounding the incident are unknown.
Protests denoucing the Liyu Police invasion into Oromiya state were conducted. Protests were peaceful and no injuries were reported.

Security forces opened fire on a group of people protesting house demolitions in Bahir dar, killing 2. A young girl was also killed in the stampede that ensued as people frantically fled the area. The Ethiopian government has put forth plans to demolish 2,500 houses in the area.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day one of clashes in Adele. Intense clashes between local Oromo Militias and LLiyu Police paramilitaries left 7 policemen and 4 militia members dead. 1 Policeman killed on the 24th with the other fatalities falling on the next day.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Day two of clashes in Adele (charak): Intense clashes between local Oromo Militias and Liyu Police paramilitary forces left 7 policemen and 4 militia members dead. Fatalities later updated as 11 policemen dead and 4 militia members.
Tribal clashesreported Baate. According to local residents, 2 afar tribesmen were killed and 1 Oromo man seriously injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Intense clashes reported in Bokota. It is unclear if there was casualties or not.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: One woman killed in Mayyu Muluqqe, prompting clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries and local militias.
Tribal clashes continue in baate. According to local residents, 5 people were killed and 7 wounded.
Secondary students from Ambo town protested the arrest and detainment of political prisoners. Several students were arrested following the protest.

Security Measures: After a request by the State of Emergency Inquiry Board and having accepted the Command Post 's request, the House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday unanimously voted for extension of the State of Emergency (SoE) to another four-months. The reason for the extension was continued activity by anti-peace elements near the country's borders.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge , Bordodde zone, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed a 13 year old boy as he was with his mother. Events surrounding the death of the boy are unclear.
Continuing clashes between Afar Tribesmen and Oromo tribal militias have left 2 dead and 7 wounded.

A grenade was thrown at the Florida International Hotel in Gondar Saturday night. Three people have reportedly been injured in the attack. Govornment officials are known to regular be found in this particular hotel, and the hotel is also currently being used as a police command post during Ethiopia's declared state of emergency.
Arrests: Thirty nine monks have been detained after they publicly protested plans by the government to use their monastery for sugar development.

Six people were killed in a shooting that broke out at the Waldiba monastery in northern Ethiopia. Fighting broke out on Tuesday, and continued well into Wednesday as Amhara militiamen clashed with Tigray militiamen backed by the national army. The militias from Tigray were reportedly preventing the pilgrims from Amhara from going into the Tigray side of the monastery.
Three people were killed and four others injured when a parking area for vehicles belonging to a Chinese construction company came under attack. It is unclear who the attackers were at this time.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Baale zone, Beltu district, firing between Oromo tribesmen and Liyu Police paramilitarieserupted after 17 Oromos were arrested. Several people were wounded but no fatalities were reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararghe, in the district of Doba kebele of Misira cirfa, clashes were reported between Oromos and units of the Liyu Police. No Oromos deaths were reported, but 3 Liyu policemen were killed.

Six people were killed in a shooting that broke out at the Waldiba monastery in northern Ethiopia. Fighting broke out on Tuesday, and continued well into Wednesday as Amhara militiamen clashed with Tigray militiamen backed by the national army. The militias from Tigray were reportedly preventing the pilgrims from Amhara from going into the Tigray side of the monastery.
A church was reportedly set ablaze by regime soldiers in Denbia. Sporatic gunfire was later heard in an area nearby and several people arrested.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: According to a report by the Ogaden News Agency, Ethiopian regime soldiers and army units from the Ogaden National Liberation Army engaged in a brief fight on Sunday resulting in several fatalities. Residents fleeing the fighting reported seeing the bodies of 17 Ethiopian soldiers at the scene. Reporters at Jijiga hospital later reported that the hospital received several wounded soldiers who had been airlifted from the fight.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Fighting between local Oromo militias and Somali regional Liyu Police paramilitaries continues in West Hararge Kebeles of Goba and Goro Butu. 3 Policemen were reportedly injured.
Residents protesting the demolition of homes by the Ethiopian military were fired upon by federal military troops. 1 fatality and several injuries were reported.
Police fired on a youth group celebrating the outcome of a football match. 1 killed and 2 wounded. No further details were given in the report.
A bomb attack occurred in the ""college"" area around Beghemder hotel in Gondar city. Fatalities are unknown as of the time of this report.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: One soldier was killed and three others wounded in an attack by the PG7 forces on a Chinese irrigation site located near Dembia, Gonder zone.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: PG7 forces claims that 2 other Ethiopian federal commanders are killed in an attack on Addis Zeman in Debeb Gondar area.
A member of the Ethiopian Intelligence forces was found dead at his house in Gonder. No information on who may have been responsible for his death.

A grenade was hurled at the house of a government official in Gonder, leaving him seriously wounded. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, however sources mentioned that he may have been targeted for participating in the government crackdown in the town throughout the recent State of Emergency.

A truck carrying Ethiopian federal soldiers came under attack by unknown gunmen, leaving 5 soldiers dead and and 4 others wounded. The truck was reportedly traveling from Musie Bamb Military Camp to the city of Gondar when the driver was shot dead, causing the truck to roll.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: One man killed by Liyu Police paramilitaries during clashes with local tribesmen in the village of Funyan Ajoo.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: One Oromo tribesman killed in clashes with Liyu Police paramilitaries forces. According to local sources, clashes happened in a village called Arada Chifra.
3 Oromo men wounded in continuing clashes between Afar militia members and local Oromo tribesmen.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: One killed and 2 wounded in a gunfight between Oromo residents and Liyu Police paramilitary units in Waddesat Kalessa of Laga Hidha district.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries of Afar region and local Oromo tribesmen left two men in the hospital with bulletwounds. Two villages have reportedly sustained significant damage from fires. The two wounded men were taken to a hospital in Dese.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes reported in Doba and Goro Gutuu. No additional information given.
A bomb was thrown at the Lodge du Chateau in the city of Gondar Monday night injuring five people. The injured include three security officers, a guard for the lodge and a foreigner.

A bomb was thrown at a petrol station in Bahir dar, killing one of the employees and wounding several others. No party claimed responsibility for the attack, and motives for this particular attack are unclear.
Residents reported hearing gunfire shortly after a bomb was thrown at a petrol station in Bahir dar. Soldiers were roaming the city searching for the attackers.
Clashes continue between Afar tribesmen and armed Oromo residents. No additional information given at this time.
A grenade was thrown during a concert in Bahir Dar, followed by gunfire. Two people were killed and several others, including three police officers, were wounded.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Three soldiers were killed on Tuesday as their convoy came under attack by Ginbot 7 troops in Addis Zemen near Metmiku Yohannes Monastery.
A member of the OPDO cabinet in Dembi Dolo was killed by police officers during a nighttime raid. 50 others arrested in the city during raids the same night.

Twenty-three Afaris and two soldiers were killed in a two-day long deadly fight between two clans in Afar. The clans, Ablek Ad'ali and Sidiha, were reportedly fighting over benefits from land recently slated to be developed into a sugar plantation. Two soldiers were killed as they tried to intervene.

Twenty-three Afaris and two soldiers were killed in a two-day long deadly fight between two clans in Afar. The clans, Ablek Ad'ali and Sidiha, were reportedly fighting over benefits from land recently slated to be developed into a sugar plantation. Two soldiers were killed as they tried to intervene.

Twenty-three Afaris and two soldiers were killed in a two-day long deadly fight between two clans in Afar. The clans, Ablek Ad'ali and Sidiha, were reportedly fighting over benefits from land recently slated to be developed into a sugar plantation. Two soldiers were killed as they tried to intervene.

Arrests: An Oromo based media source has reported that members of the police force in Cinaqsan of Oromo descent are being arrested and held. This is in addition to a federal soldier being assigned to each member of the Oromo police force.
A border clash between the Afar and Amhara last week in Hadar, 15 kms from Bati, left at least 15 people injured from both sides

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Two fuel trucks heading to Gondar from Sudan came under attack on Tuesday in Chilga, north Gondar. The two trucks were completely burnt and the drivers injured, according to ESAT's sources. Patriotic Ginbot 7 forces took responsibility for the attack.

At least one person was killed and many others injured as Liyu police moved through Dhamolee region in Bale zone. The source also claimed that 15 houses were burned in a conflict between Liyu police forces from Somali region and Oromo citizens living in areas contested between the two ethnic groups. Oromo opposition leaders have blamed the government for stoking tensions between the two ethnic groups.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: An attack by Ginbot 7 militants left 13 military personnel dead and 4 others wounded in Libo Kemekem on Monday. The attack was reportedly in retaliation for various abuses carried out by regime soldiers in the area. One Ginbot 7 soldier was wounded.
Police forces have killed one man and wounded another 2 in the city of Adama in Oromia region. Additional details were not given by the source.
Students stage a protest in Dandii, central Oromiya.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes reported between Liyu Police paramilitary units and Oromo militias in Bale zone, Dhamole district. 4 Policemen and one militia member killed.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018)
column17: An engineer with the Ethiopian Air Force killed at least ten soldiers at an army meeting in Gode town of the Somali region of Ethiopia. He was said to have shot and killed himself after the tragic incident, while other sources say he was shot and killed by an officer. The engineer is said to have been relocated to Gode to serve as a regular soldier as a demotion and punishment for being a supporter of the anti- government protests in the Oromo and Amhara regions a year ago.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Speaking from Los Angeles, the leader of the group Ginbot 7 has claimed that the group had been victorious over Ethiopian regime forces in a two day battle across several towns in Gondar. Battles were reportedly fought in localities called Ajere and Janora in North Gondar as well as well as in Kemkem and Belesa in the south. The leader spoke of the battles as fierce and having ""deadly consequences"" for regime forces, without specifying a number of killed or wounded (10 fatalities divided among events).

Security Measures: Citing a leaked exam last year during secondary school exams, the Ethiopian Government has decided to suspend internet access in the country until the exams are over. The move brought on strong criticism from opposition leaders, who declared the move to be ""backwards""
