The leader spoke of the battles as fierce and having ""deadly consequences"" for regime forces, without specifying a number of killed or wounded (10 fatalities divided among events).

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Speaking from Los Angeles, the leader of the group Ginbot 7 has claimed that the group had been victorious over Ethiopian regime forces in a two day battle across several towns in Gondar. Battles were reportedly fought in localities called Ajere and Janora in North Gondar as well as well as in Kemkem and Belesa in the south. The leader spoke of the battles as fierce and having ""deadly consequences"" for regime forces, without specifying a number of killed or wounded (10 fatalities divided among events).

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Speaking from Los Angeles, the leader of the group Ginbot 7 has claimed that the group had been victorious over Ethiopian regime forces in a two day battle across several towns in Gondar. Battles were reportedly fought in localities called Ajere and Janora in North Gondar as well as well as in Kemkem and Belesa in the south. The leader spoke of the battles as fierce and having ""deadly consequences"" for regime forces, without specifying a number of killed or wounded (10 fatalities divided among events).

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Speaking from Los Angeles, the leader of the group Ginbot 7 has claimed that the group had been victorious over Ethiopian regime forces in a two day battle across several towns in Gondar. Battles were reportedly fought in localities called Ajere and Janora in North Gondar as well as well as in Kemkem and Belesa in the south. The leader spoke of the battles as fierce and having ""deadly consequences"" for regime forces, without specifying a number of killed or wounded (10 fatalities divided among events).

Fierce fighting took place between ONLA and Ethiopian soldiers in Anfi Village of Hamaro district in Nogob Region. According to a senior member of the ONLA, 10 Ethiopian soldiers were killed and an unknown number were wounded. The report also added that The ONLA has captured weapons, ammunition and communication equipment.
Arrests: According to Ginbot 7 sources, nearly 200 people have been arrested in Gondar following intense clashes between regime forces and armed Ginbot 7 militants.

On June 6th 2017 OMN posted a video claiming that a members of the Oromo Youth Organization 'Qeerroo' had killed a man they claimed was responsible for the death of 6 Oromo children in Awaday, Hararghe.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: At least 60 political prisoners were freed after anti-regime forces opened fire at a prison in north Gondar in town called Chinfaz Silara. One prison officer was killed and three others were injured. The Ginbot 7 movement later claimed responsibility for the attack.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Property destruction: Patriotic Ginbot 7 has claimed responsibility for an arson attack at an ammunition depot in Ethiopia's capital Addis Ababa on Saturday. The fire at the Federal Police ammunition depot in the capital went for hours and caused extensive damage to the depot before the city's fire department was able to put it under control.

Protests in Ambo erupted after a plan to re-arrange the Oromo alphabet was revealed by the Ethiopian education authority. 50 students were arrested, and 2 students died due to severe beatings received during transfer to prison facilities. One student died in a hospital in Ambo, the second in Addis Ababa. Six police officers are being held in connection to the deaths.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: A fuel truck traveling from Sudan to Metema, northern Ethiopia came under attack on Monday 2 kms outside Addis Zemen. The driver was injured during the attack and was taken to a hospital in Bahir dar for treatment. Patriotic Ginbot 7 took responsibility for the attack.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Prison Guards
column17: An undisclosed number of prisoners have reportedly escaped from the Bahir Dar Penitentiary after a shootout with prison guards. Sources suggested that arms may have been smuggled into the prison to assist the escape. No information on fatalities.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Patriotic Ginbot 7 announced in a statement to ESAT that they had attacked a command post in Ebnat, killing the commander. Gunfire could be heard in the area for several hours following the bomb attack. PG7's leader announced that the group had stepped up attacks against the regime and would continue to do so.

Ethiopian regime soldiers have reportedly opened fire on civilians in West Oromia, Welegga, Abbay chomani and hobabo gudaro districts. 2 people were seriously injured. Further details are unavailable at this time.
Continued protests against the changing of the Oromo Alphabet were reportedly being held by students in Ambo.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bale, Dawe Qachan district 3 Oromos were killed by an ""invading"" Somali Liyu Police paramilitary force. 2 others seriously wounded. Unclear when clashes started or finished as source dated 5 July mentioned the clashes were continuing.

Armed clashes involving residents of Habru District of North Welo Zone in Amhara Regional State and Chifra District of Afar Regional State begin on 05/07, and continued sporadically until at least 16/07. Fighting is believed to have occurred in both adjacent communities. Fourteen dead, total; eight fatalities reported on the first day of fighting.

Armed clashes involving residents of Habru District of North Welo Zone in Amhara Regional State and Chifra District of Afar Regional State begin on 05/07, and continued sporadically until at least 16/07. Fighting is believed to have occurred in both adjacent communities. Fourteen dead, total; eight fatalities reported on the first day of fighting.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes erupted between local Oromo militia members and Liyu Police units from Afar region when the police units invaded the area of Gafra, Harbu district. On the first day of clashes, 4 security forces were killed and 2 Oromo militiamen were wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: OMN announced in a media broadcast posted on facebook that 14 Afar Liyu Police paramilitaries had been killed along with 2 Oromos in ongoing clashes. Opposition media such as OMN blames the Ethiopian gov. for instigating cross border attacks. 4 fatalities coded on the first day of clashes (6th of July)

Agreement: Ninety-five Ethiopian rebel fighters from the Benishangul People's Liberation Movement (BPLM) have surrendered to government forces. 15 of those that surrendered were leaders who had been based in Khartoum.

Fighting among communities, which began on 05/07, continued sporadically until at least 16/07 - dates of specific battle not known. Eight reported killed the first day; six killed in the period between 06/07 and 16/07.

Fighting among communities, which began on 05/07, continued sporadically until at least 16/07 - dates of specific battle not known. Eight reported killed the first day; six killed in the period between 06/07 and 16/07.

A tax levied by authorities on 'estimated sales' on small businesses has sparked protests in several regions of the country. Government vehicles including police cars were set ablaze in Ambo as people reacted angrily to the new tax.

A tax levied by authorities on 'estimated sales' on small businesses has sparked protests in several regions of the country. In Chelenko and Chero towns of West Hararghe, protesting residents went to the office of the local administration and disrupted a cabinet meeting. Businesses were closed for the day in the towns.

A tax levied by authorities on 'estimated sales' on small businesses has sparked protests in several regions of the country. Protesters in Nazreth (Adama) blocked roads and took to the streets in protest.

A tax levied by authorities on 'estimated sales' on small businesses has sparked protests in several regions of the country. In Chelenko and Chero towns of West Hararghe, protesting residents went to the office of the local administration and disrupted a cabinet meeting. Businesses were closed for the day in the towns.
Property destruction: Armed men from Afar attacked Wollo Oromos, burning around 30 homes over the ""last few weeks."" Source dated 05/09. Locations not known.
A group in Ambo protests against federal tax increases.

An Oromo activist reported that regime soldiers/police officers have been beating civilians in the town of Burayo. This comes in the context of a protest by small businesses owners and youth reacting to a new tax levied this week.
In Kofale town of West Arsi, business owners staged a protest against a newly introduced tax on small businesses. Soldiers dispersed the protest, with two people arrested and 4 injured.
Arrests: About 30 people were taken away by government forces while on their way to a funeral in Mogor town, reasons not known; may be tied to anti-tax protests in Ambo.
Anti-riot military unit forces open fire on tax protesters in Ambo, killing two. No reported violence from protesters. The protest began the previous day.
Business people in Waliso protest for three consecutive days against a tax.
In protest of a federal tax Oromo youths throw stones at government vehicles. The violence occurred in either Ambo, Waliso or a location between to two towns.
Business people in Waliso protest for three consecutive days against a tax.
People in East Wollega (Sasiga), Nekemte, Goro, and ""other towns"" begin a business strike in protest of a government tax.
People in East Wollega (Sasiga), Nekemte, Goro, and ""other towns"" begin a business strike in protest of a government tax.

In Horro Guduru Wollega zone, Hooro Guduru woreda, an Oromo farmer by the name of Lata Morka was arrested and beaten to death in Kombolcha prison by Commandos. The attackers threw the body into the ditch after the killing. The body was later found by people and is now in Shambo hospital, in Wollega Zone.

""Heavy fighting"" between suspected Tigray Peoples Revolutionary Liberation Front and Eritrean forces was reported along the border between Ethiopia and Eritrea at Irob. Artillery fire was used, though it is not known if this method was the exclusive exchange. Causalities not known.
Business people in Waliso protest for three consecutive days against a tax.

Bomb attack reported at Tigrayan People's Liberation Front (TPLF) owned Selam Bus Garage in Addis Ababa. According to ESAT News the bomb blasts was followed by gunfire. Causalities, perpetrators not known.
Shop owners in Kolfe, Axena Tera shut down their businesses in protest of a tax increase.
Amaro militias attacks Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.

Fighting between Oromo and Kooree (Amaro) militias in Gujji, Adoolessa began on 23/07 and continued until 27/07. 12 dead, nine wounded. The fighting began after Amaro militias attacked Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.

Fighting between Oromo and Kooree (Amaro) militias in Gujji, Adoolessa began on 23/07 and continued until 27/07. 12 dead, nine wounded. The fighting began after Amaro militias attacked Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.
Detonation: A bomb was thrown in the Jimma bus station. No damage was caused. A shopkeeper in the area was later arrested and his shop searched by police. The reason for the attack is not known.

Fighting between Oromo and Kooree (Amaro) militias in Gujji, Adoolessa began on 23/07 and continued until 27/07. 12 dead, nine wounded. The fighting began after Amaro militias attacked Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.

Fighting between Oromo and Kooree (Amaro) militias in Gujji, Adoolessa began on 23/07 and continued until 27/07. 12 dead, nine wounded. The fighting began after Amaro militias attacked Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.

On 26 July the house of Jima town mayor was attacked by a hand grenade, but no one was injured. According to investigations carried out so far, it has been alleged that the attack was a drama organized by members of the security to malign the image of those small traders protesting against the hike of tax imposed by the government. It is not known if this claim was substantiated.

Fighting between Oromo and Kooree (Amaro) militias in Gujji, Adoolessa began on 23/07 and continued until 27/07. 12 dead, nine wounded. The fighting began after Amaro militias attacked Oromo areas killing five and destroying 100 houses. Shortly thereafter, Oromo militias mobilized and retaliated.

A bus was attacked and burned in Ambo. A second vehicle marked as a health minister's vehicle was also targeted and burned. Opposition leaders (unknown identity; possibly EDP) claim that the government was using these vehicles to transport troops in the area. Perpetrators not known. No causalities.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge Zone, Bordode woreda, Liyu Police paramilitary forces have attacked Oromo groups, who fought back. Clashes lasted for hours, ending only when federal troops intervened. Two policemen were reported dead after the fighting. Opposition figures accused the government of causing the clashes in support of a takeover of Oromo land.
In south Oromia, Wollo, Sanbate town, an Oromo business owner was killed by federal police for refusing to open his shop.
Shops in the Addis Ababa market of Merkato closed in protest of a tax increase. The market was previously shut down on 24/07 in protest of the tax.
In Dambi Dollo town, Qerros (Oromo Youth organization) attacked a man who had been supporting the government. The extent of the victim's injuries are not known.

Following a police shooting against a truck carrying construction materials in Kumbi, members of Qerros (Oromo Youth organization) attacked police, leading to a nearly all-day clash. The police were eventually driven out of the area. Four members of Qerros were injured and 37 were arrested.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Oromia residents of East Hararge zone, Cinaksa woreda protested a forced transfer of land by the government. Liyu Police paramilitaries - attempting to stop the protest - clashed with the Oromia police, who took the side of the protesters. Five Liyu Police reported dead.

Oromia residents of East Hararge zone, Cinaksa woreda protested a forced transfer of land by the government. Liyu Police, attempting to stop the protest clashed with the Oromia police, who took the side of the protesters. Five Liyu police reported dead. No reported violence from the protesters themselves.

Businesses and transporters have begun a strike and protest in the northwestern Bahir Dar town as part of a protest called to mark the first anniversary of the anti-government demonstrations held last year. Police made four arrests.

There was a bomb blast in Bahir Dar [northwestern Ethiopia] at 9:25 p.m. [local time, 1825 gmt] [on the night of 06/08]. A number of suspects were later arrested. The motive for detonating the explosive is not known.

In Ambo and Welliso, people restarted market boycott. The road from Wollega to Ambo has been closed. They have begun this second round of protests calling for the release to several Oromo prisoners, who are believed to have been arrested during an earlier protest or strike.

In Ambo and Welliso, people restarted market boycott. The road from Wollega to Ambo has been closed. They have begun this second round of protests calling for the release to several Oromo prisoners, who are believed to have been arrested during an earlier protest or strike.
Boycotts and protests in Ambo and Welliso continue. Qerros (Oromo Youth group) have destroyed 34 total vehicles. Transportation to and from the region has been completely stopped.
Boycotts and protests in Ambo and Welliso continue. Qerros (Oromo Youth group) have destroyed 34 total vehicles. Transportation to and from the region has been completely stopped.
In west and East Hararge zone, Regime forces have reportedly shot 11 people. Exact locations and motives for the violence are not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Arada Gulufa kebele, Somal Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked civilians. One died and 3 were wounded. The wounded have been taken to a hospital in Ciro. The reason for the attack was not reported. It was reported the days before that Liyu police was attempting to force Oromo people to leave the area.
In west and East Hararge zone, Regime forces have reportedly shot 11 people. Exact locations and motives for the violence are not known.

The U.S. embassy has confirmed a report of intense fighting around the city of Babile and Harar, announcing that the road is closed between the two cities. It is believed one of the actors is Oromo militia. Casualties not known.

The U.S. embassy has confirmed a report of intense fighting around the city of Babile and Harar, announcing that the road is closed between the two cities. It is believed one of the actors is Oromo militia. Casualties not known.

In East Hararge zone, Gursum woreda, Kore(Qore) kebele locals protested against a recently proposed land transfer by the Ethiopian government which re-assigned their village to the Somali region. The protesters were demanding that their land stays in Oromiya region.
""Anti-peace"" forces launch a hand grenade against civilians in Bahir Dar. Two injuries reported. Several suspects were arrested on 14/08.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Gumbi bordodde, woreda, at a place called Ija Dimtu Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries fired upon Oromo pastoralists. No information on fatalities given in the report.
Arrests: Police in Bahir Dar arrest 200 of those suspected to have participated in a protest in the city on 06/08. The operation lasted over two days.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Chinaksa woreda, in a place called Ulanula, Liyu Police paramilitaries allied with regime forces reportedly attacked Oromos, who fought back. A man was killed during the fight.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Oromo militiamen and Liyu Police paramilitaries fought. 3 Police officers were killed.
Clashes reported as Wollo Oromos battled Afar tribal militias on 21/08. (location, further details not specified).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Gumbi Bordode woreda (believed to be near Mieso), two civilian men were killed and one was wounded by Somali Liyu police as they were herding cows.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East and West Hararge zones, Oromos and Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries have been fighting. In East Hararge zone, Chinaksa woreda. 3 Oromos have been killed, as well as 4 Somali Liyu police officers. The exact location of the West Hararge fighting is not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East and West Hararge zones, Oromos and Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries have been fighting. In East Hararge zone, Chinaksa woreda. 3 Oromos have been killed, as well as 4 Somali Liyu Police officers. The exact location of the West Hararge fighting is not known.

Strike:A working boycott has started on 23/08 in several towns across Oromia region, including Ambo, Shashamane, Dodola, Bale, and other cities (not named). The strike was called by the Oromo Federalist Congress (OFC) with an aim for the release of political prisoners and end to a tax increase.

Protesters of tax hikes and political prisoners invade a coffee plant in Limu Kesa owned by the widow of the late prime minister, Meles Zenawi. The protesters took large quantities of coffee and distributed amongst themselves.
As a five day transport protest strike over economics and political prisoners began in many Oromia locations, demonstrators in Holeta, Hagere Maryam and Aweday smashed buses defying the order.
As a five day transport protest strike over economics and political prisoners began in many Oromia locations, demonstrators in Holeta, Hagere Maryam and Aweday smashed buses defying the order.
As a five day transport protest strike over economics and political prisoners began in many Oromia locations, demonstrators in Holeta, Hagere Maryam and Aweday smashed buses defying the order.

Strike:A working boycott has started on 23/08 in several towns across Oromia region, including Ambo, Shashamane, Dodola, Bale, and other cities (not named). The strike was called by the Oromo Federalist Congress (OFC) with an aim for the release of political prisoners and end to a tax increase.

Strike:A working boycott has started on 23/08 in several towns across Oromia region, including Ambo, Shashamane, Dodola, Bale, and other cities (not named). The strike was called by the Oromo Federalist Congress (OFC) with an aim for the release of political prisoners and end to a tax increase.

Tax strikes and protests occur over several areas of Oromia including Kofele, Adaba, Asasa, Ginchi, Nejo, Gute, and Burayu among others. Details limited. The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

Tax strikes and protests occur over several areas of Oromia including Kofele, Adaba, Asasa, Ginchi, Nejo, Gute, and Burayu among others. Details limited. The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

Strike:All points of entry into Addis Ababa were forced to close due to an OFC-led worker strike that called for the release of political prisoners and in opposition of tax hikes. Doezns of towns in Oromia followed the strike call, while bus transport between Addis Ababa and Bahir Dar was also affected. The strike is expected to last until 27/08.

Tax strikes and protests occur over several areas of Oromia including Kofele, Adaba, Asasa, Ginchi, Nejo, Gute, and Burayu among others. Details limited. The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

The source implies these episodes occurred on other nearby areas as well. All points of entry into Addis Ababa were blocked, while transport from Addis Ababa to Oromia were affected. The strike lasted until 27 August.

Strike:A working boycott has started on 23/08 in several towns across Oromia region, including Ambo, Shashamane, Dodola, Bale, and other cities (not named). The strike was called by the Oromo Federalist Congress (OFC) with an aim for the release of political prisoners and end to a tax increase.
13 people have been injured after a hand grenade was thrown by unknown attackers at a market in Jimma town in the Oromia Regional State on 24/08.

In west Hararge zone, Masala woreda, police have been accused of arresting and beating several young men who are suspected of encouraging people to participate in the market boycott. The extent of the boycott is not known.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Mieso town, Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries led by Tigre generals (Regime forces) are reportedly attacking civilians. No further info given in this report.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Oromo people and Liyu Police paramilitaries that started in Mieso woreda has spread Chinaksan woreda. Two Oromos civilians have been killed and others have been injured. Though clashes between the two actors began in Mieso woreda on 20/08, it is not clear if they continued throughout the period, or began again on or near 29/08.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Oromo people and Liyu Police paramilitaries that started in Mieso woreda has spread to Chinaksan woreda. Two Oromos civilians have been killed and others have been injured. Though clashes between the two actors began in Mieso woreda on 20/08, it is not clear if they continued throughout the period, or began again on or near 29/08.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes between Oromo militia and Liyu police continue in Chinaksen for a second day. Six civilian deaths reported.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge, Mieso district. Eight young men who were part of the militia fighting Liyu police forces in the area were killed, presumably by Oromo militia.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: A clash between Oromo people and Liyu Police paramilitaries on 01/09 in Mieso claims 30 lives.
A man who was part of the Oromo forces fighting against the Somali special police was killed in Eastern Hararge, Babile woreda.
In East Hararge zone, Dadar woreda, Qerro(Oromo young men) killed a man who had been reporting Oromo young men to Federal police. The attackers cut his arms off. The event was not confirmed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge Zone, Mieso district, Somali Liyu Police paramilitarie reportedly threw a grenade that landed near students who were registering for school. 4 children were seriously hurt. The school name was Buno primary school. Event not confirmed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Oromo militias pushed Liyu Police paramilitarie out of Chamuk. Several fatalities reported, though no numbers were provided.
On Sept. 7, at least four people were killed near Moyale when Oromo militia armed with machetes attacked patients in a hospital. The motive of the attack is believed to be revenge.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Baale Zone, Rayitu woreda, Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly attacked villagers in the area. Locals (Oromos) fought back, killing 8 of the Liyu police. 3 Oromos were killed and an additional 5 were wounded. The armed Oromos reportedly took control of a kabele that had been given by the government to Somali region, controlling it for a bit of time until federal troops intervened and took it back, causalities not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Suspected Liyu Police paramilitary attack Moyale, leading to a clash from defending residents. Fatalities are believed to be about 30.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Moyale, Borana zone, Chamluk town 12 people were killed and 9 wounded during clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromo people. Liyu police were supported by Ethiopian military army. People in the area have been evacuating in fear of continued clashes. Later in the day Liyu militias attacked from a state of retreat from the previous day. Liyu police later returned to the area, sparking clashes that reportedly killed up to 80 people - 60 Liyu police and 20 Oromos. (These numbers may be unreliable - a conservative estimate was made at 50, making the total for the day 62.)

An official of Somali Region, Hudet woreda, Liben zone, was killed along with some militia men (numbers not known) on 09/09. The man was a head of Water and Rural Infrastructure of the woreda. The perpetrators are unknown.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes continued in Rayitu Woreda of Bale zone. According to Pro-Oromo sources, more than 25 Liyu Police paramilitaries have been killed so far during clashes in the woreda. This number has not yet been confirmed. Several Oromos were also killed and wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Midaga lola woreda, Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly attacked an area, killing 4 people and wounding 2 others. It is not clear if the targets were civilian or military. Armed Oromos retaliated, killing 7 Liyu policemen and wounding 3 others, including a commander.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Midaga lola woreda, Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly attacked an area, killing 4 people and wounding 2 others. It is not clear if the targets were civilian or military. Armed Oromos retaliated, killing 7 Liyu policemen and wounding 3 others including a commander.

In East Shewam Walanchite city, a Tigray man was accused by a crowd of ""spying"" on people in the area. He was also accused of killing an Oromo man by the name of Bakala Babsa, and wounding his brother. The crowd lynched the man, burning his body in the main street.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: East Hararge, Chinaksan woreda 10 houses were burned down by from a heavy gunfire, presumably from Liyu Police paramilitary forces. Following the attack locals in the area clashed with the Liyu Police, reportedly driving them from the area. Causalities not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Borana zone, Wachile woreda, in a place called ""Laga Siminto"" Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked civilians. Heavy weapons were reportedly used. Causalities not known.

In East Shewam Walanchite city a Oromo man is killed and his brother wounded. The event occurred on or before 10/09. Perpetrators not known. Local residents believe the perpetrator to be a Tigray man.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: A Oromo civilian is killed in Gursum. Local authorities blame Liyu Police paramilitaries

Oromo militias attack and kill 32 ethnic Somalis in Aweday. More than 50 dead were later reported by both Oromo and Somali officials. Government forces were sent to restore order. An estimated 55,000 - 70,000 were displaced by recent fighting in the region. ""Hundreds"" were later arrested. The government sent military forces to the region in response.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

Protests against the TPLF take place in several Oromia Region towns (not named). Protesters are demonstrating against the killing of Oromo persons by Somali region militia members, politicians and activists believe the Somali region militias are backed by the ruling party in Ethiopia which is Tigrayan People's Liberation Front (TPLF).

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu Police paramilitary violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by Liyu Police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

People in Chinaksan village demonstrated against continued violence perpetrated by the Liyu police. They also complained that the government was disarming locals but not doing anything to stop the Liyu police. Similar protests took place in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.
On 13/09 protests were held in Boreda and Karamille towns of Western Haraghe zone. One person was killed by security officers, reasons not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Four people have been killed and seven others wounded in heavy fighting that took place in Bule Hora, near Hagere Maryam between the area farmers and Ethiopian Somali special forces (Liyu Police paramilitaries). The clashes began on 14/09 and continued into the morning of 15/09.

In East Hararge, Goro gutu woreda, Karra Mille, a demonstration was held against continued incursions by the Liyu police. It is not clear if the protesters were violent. Federal troops intervened; one man was killed and 6 others injured.
Unidentified militia shelled Shinfa town in Quara District. Casualties not known. Following the attacks, the Ethiopian government has ""closed all mobile phone networks in the area"".

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Four people have been killed and seven others wounded in heavy fighting that took place in Bule Hora, near Hagere Maryam between the area farmers and Ethiopian Somali special forces (Liyu Police paramilitaries). The clashes began on 14/09 and continued into the morning of 15/09.

In what is believed to be Guji Zone, Oromo people submitted complaints that they had been shot at by the Southern regional special forces. The date(s) of the violence is not known. Source reported on 16/09. Causalities not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge , Gumbi Bordede, 3 Oromo residents were killed in clashes with Somali region Liyu Police paramilitaries that lasted for 4 hours.
Reports of violence along the Oromo border with Burji and Amaro tribes in what is believed to be Guji Zone. Casualties not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Clashes broke out between Liyu Police paramilitaries and armed Oromos in Borana, Moyale town. Two Liyu policemen were killed, while 2 Oromos were wounded.
In Awaday, a young man was arrested and beaten by policemen. Further details unclear.
Arrests: 48 Oromo students in Jigjiga University were arrested, reasons not known. Five cannot be located.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Reports of rape by Liyu Police have been emerging from Oromo women who were forced out of Somali region. Location and date of the attacks not known.

In West Hararge zone, Boke woreda, Oromia police arrested more than 100 young men during a wedding party. They were released a few hours later after an uproar (it is unknown if this was a protest) by the local community. There were reports of beatings. Oromo youth were also arrested as they were traveling from Asabo town to Mieso to support the people who were banished from Somali region. Many also complained of ""beatings.""
In Bale zone, Beltu (laga hidha) woreda and in Robe people demonstrated against the government and Somali Regional President over ongoing violence happening in Eastern parts of the country.
In Bale zone, Beltu (laga hidha) woreda and in Robe people demonstrated against the government and Somali Regional President over ongoing violence happening in Eastern parts of the country.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge Zone, Goro Gutu woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries crossed the border and killed an unknown number of people . Oromo residents responded, reportedly killing 5 Liyu policemen.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge Zone, Goro Gutu woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries crossed the border and killed an unknown number of people. Oromo residents responded, reportedly killing 5 Liyu policemen.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitaries have attacked areas in Chinaksan woreda while in the presence of Oromia special forces. Causalities unknown. People have complained that the Oromo special forces have done nothing to protect them and that the violence continues despite their presence. It is not known if these complaints manifested as a protest.
A group of people, reportedly organized by the Somali regional government, attacked and burned to death an Oromo man living in Somali regional state. The location of the attack is not known.

In East Hararghe, Golo Oda woreda, several young men were arrested and beaten for demonstrating against the violence occurring in Eastern Ethiopia. Locals surrounded the police station in opposition to the arrests. Policemen fired their weapons, accidentally hitting the city administrator. The current status of the administrator is not known.
Weapons Seizure: In Bale zone, Seweyna woreda, Ethiopian regime forces have been conducting house to house searches and confiscating weapons. The reason for this action is not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Intense fighting between Liyu Police paramilitaries and the Oromo ethnic groups in the eastern Ethiopia has left ""more than 30 people"", including ""more than a dozen army members"", dead and several others injured in Mieso on 30/09.

An Oromo festival on 01/10 turned into a anti government protest. Over a million people gathered at Horra Harsede, a meeting place for Irreecha celebration in the central town of Bushoftu, 50 kilometres (31 miles) south of the capital, Addis Ababa.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries shot at civilians, killing one Oromo man in Daro labu woreda.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries shot at civilians, wounding one person in west Hararge, Mieso woreda. Opposition spokesmen are upset because the government had disarmed Oromos in the area, making it impossible for them to fight back.

Members of the military clash following an unarticulated dispute. One of the combatants fired on two others, killing them. The attacker then killed himself. The location of the clash within Ethiopia is not known.
In East Shewa , Awaday town, people took part in a demonstration denouncing the jailing of various Oromo political figures.
Oromo Opposition media is accusing federal soldiers of shooting and killing a high school student during a protest in west Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, in a place called Muso.
In West Hararge, Guraawa woreda, Dira town, People demonstrated to oppose the jailing of various Oromo political figures. Note: Girawa woreda is in East Hararge Zone.

Demonstrations for the release of political prisoners were held in Fadis, east Hararge zone. According to opposition media, a young man by the name of Jamal Kile was killed by Ethiopian military forces during the demonstration.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.

Nine people were killed in clashes between the Afaris and security forces of the Tigray region in an area called Danti in Megalle district on the border between the two regions. Six people were killed and nine others wounded on the Tigray side while three were killed and three others injured on the Afari side. The fighting was sparked when an Afari father retaliated the killing of his two children by the Tigray side. The Afaris also accused that the Somali Special Police have raided a village in Aafar injuring three people and robbing livestock. Two deaths were reported in the second incident.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Somali Special Police (Liyu) raided a village in Aafar injuring three people and robbing livestock. Two deaths reported.
Tigray militia attack and kill two Afari children in Danti in Megalle district. The attack led to a general clash in the area.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.

Protests reported in Ambo after rumours spread that a mineral water factory was to move to another town. The initial protest led to a wider anti-government protest. Date unknown; reported by the source in conjunction with a series of anti-government protests which occurred on 11/10.

Three people were killed and three others injured in anti-government protests in Boke. It is not clear if the protesters engaged with a second actor. There were several anti-government protests throughout the region; more than 30 people were also confirmed to have been injured in various places, exact locations unknown.

Between five and six are dead in anti-government protests is Shashamane, Oromia. ESAT later reported 8 deaths. There were several anti-government protests throughout the region; more than 30 people were also confirmed to have been injured in various places, exact locations unknown.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protest in Wollega for the release of political prisoners.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.

Oromo People in Borana areas blocked a road to prevent Ethiopian federal troops from delivering supplies to Somali Liyu police. Federal forces reportedly opened fire, killing five and wounding tens more. The fatality count was later updated to 6.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Protests in Wollega continue for a second day. Protesters blocked the Moyale-Addis road.
Protests in Shashamane continue. No incidents reported.

Ethiopian government forces killed four Oromia people and wounded 18 others in the town of Soda. The forces were transporting weapons to Liyu police and opened fire after residents demanded that they stop transporting weapons.
Oromo young men (Qerroo) burnt down one bajaj (3 wheeled vehicle) in Jijga owned by a Somali woman because she has been sending Chat to Somali region.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in Bule Hora.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in Gimbi.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Protests in Wollega continue for a third day. Protesters blocked the Moyale-Addis road.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.

Arrests: A large number of people were arrested in Jijiga city as they were preparing to war against Oromo residents. According to the report, they came from Shinile, Somali region armed with knives and other weapons with the intention of harming Oromos in the area.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
Regime forces shoot and killed two in Chanho (also known as Debre Selam). The action led to businesses closing the following day in protest as well as demonstrations in several neighbouring towns.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Chanho the day following the killing of two residents by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Gebre Guracha the day following the killing of two residents by government forces. The protests became violent the following day.
Anti-government protests reported in Muke Turi the day following the killing of two residents by government forces. The protests became violent the following day.
Residents of Fiche violently demonstrate following the killing of two by government forces in Debre Selam. Protests continued into the following day.
Anti-government protests reported in Sulultra the day following the killing of two residents by government forces.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Two are killed in Fiche when security forces opened fire on the demonstrators.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. The source reports ""protests continued"" in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

The source reports ""protests continued"" in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. An explosive detonated in Bedele - perpetrators not known. The source reports ""protests continued"" in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. The source reports ""protests continued"" in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Violent anti-government protests occur in several Oromia towns including Asela, Horogudru, Ambro, Wollega, Horogudru, Muketuri, and Fiche. The protested chanted anti-TPLF slogans and burned government vehicles. Students were involved at Ambro, Gebre Guracha, Horo Guduru and Asela. Other articles from the same sources state ""a dozen"" protesters have been killed since ""last week."" The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

In south Shewa zone, Kuyo Garba gurracha, Wucale woreda, anti-government rioters burned 10 government vehicles after a demonstration turned violent. Fatalities as a result of the violence were reported but who died is not clear.
Regime security forces shot and killed two anti-government protesters in Bedele. It is not known if the protesters were violent.
Anti-government protesters overtake a coffee plantation in Jima.
Regime security forces shot and killed two anti-government protesters in Gundo Maskal town of North Shewa. It is not known if the protesters were violent.

Anti-government Oromo protests descend into violence with the Amharas group in Dega and Chora. Eight Oromos and three Amharas were reported killed, though other sources have the number as high as 20. Several houses were burnt in the fighting. Homes of Tigrayans were also targeted.

Anti-government Oromo protests descend into violence with the Amharas group in Dega and Chora. Eight Oromos and three Amharas were reported killed, though other sources have the number as high as 20. Several houses were burnt in the fighting. Homes of Tigrayans were also targeted.
A man was killed and thrown into the ditch by a member of Ethiopian national army. The location was not clear, but is said to have taken place around Haraghe.

In Ilu Abba Bora, Buno Badale woreda, Ethiopian federal army troopers who were reportedly wearing Oromiya forces uniforms shot at demonstrators as they were protesting in the town. Opposition groups have accused the government of attempting to turn peaceful protests violent as an excuse to clamp down. Casualties not known.
In East Shewa zone, Fantale woreda, Oromo Karayu (Oromo Clan) and Argoba (Ethnic group in Ethiopia, unrelated to Oromo) reportedly clashed. No information on fatalities or further details.
Students of Adama Science and Technology University conducted an anti-government demonstration.

In Buno Badale zone, a peaceful demonstration turned deadly after an unidentified group of armed men started shooting. Rioting followed, and several houses were burned. 12 fatalities were later reported as a result of the chaos and gunshot wounds. According to opposition media, the government reported the demonstration before it had happened, leading to suspicions that they had been behind the attack, however this was not confirmed.
Residents of Guder burn tires and block roads in anti-government protests. Protesters have also forcibly stopped sugar supply trucks in an effort to economically hurt the industry.
Prison officials beat a political prisoner to death. It was reported the deceased was attempting to smuggle a mobile phone. Source dated 22/10 - date of death not known.

Security forces killed three people in Ambo in an attempt to free trucks loaded with sugar that were held up by residents in protest. One of the trucks was set on fire by the protesters. The interrupted supply has caused sugar prices to recently rise. Oromiya Media Network reports the event occurred on 26/10, with 12 fatalities. At later report on 30/10 claims at least 10 dead.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In east Hararge zone, Jarso woreda Liyu Police paramilitaries supported by Ethiopian federal army attacked a group of people, identity not known. Causalities not known.

Protests reported in Holeta, 24 miles west of the capital this morning with protesters blocking roads with rocks and burning tires. A truck was set ablaze and Agazi forces took control of the town later in the day.

Two members of the Agazi special forces were killed in an ambush carried out by unknown individuals in Ginchi 50 miles west of Addis Ababa. Two other members of the force were wounded in the grenade attack on a gas station, presumably in the same location.

In East Hararge zone, Mayo Muluke woreda, security forces killed one Oromo young man. The forces fired bullets to disperse a crowd of people gathered to oppose security forces from taking Chat from Oromia region to areas controlled by the Liyu police force in Somali region.

Three are dead and several others wounded in Nekemt after rumours of an illegally owned firearm by a civilian. Two of the dead are Amhara and one is Oromo. It is believed the protests are related to the wider unrest in the region. Other fatality recorded in event on 30/10.

Agazi special forces kill Oromos in Nekemt ""over the weekend."" The source states that the military has killed 30 over the past week, but with the exception of Ambo (10 dead) it does not provide details such as date and location. The number may have taken into account that attack at Bedele, though the perpetrating actor remains unknown.

Three are dead and several others wounded in Nekemt after rumours of an illegally owned firearm by a civilian. Two of the dead are Amhara and one is Oromo. It is believed the protests are related to the wider unrest in the region. Other 2 fatalities recorded in event on 29/10.
Nine Amharas are dead following an attack by TPLF forces in Kamashi Zone. Many others were reportedly displaced.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 4 Oromos killed by suspected Liyu Police as they were taking their cows to water. All 4 dead are from the same family. Incident reported in Hararghe zone, Mieso woreda, in an area called Bareda.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: East Hararge, Mayu muluke woreda, Somali Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo people and killed 2 persons and left 4 more wounded. No additional information.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge, Chinaksan woreda one person was killed and 3 were wounded during a shooting by suspected Liyu Police. The victim's identities are not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Attacks and many injured in violence by suspected Liyu Police members in West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Looting: In Guji zone, Liban woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly conducted a cattle raid, taking as many as 450 Oromo owned animals.
Students of Metu University in Illubabor staged a protest rally. The students were chanting slogans denouncing the ethnic and divisive policies of the TPLF government.
Protesters in Chefe Donso, in East Shewa set ablaze courts, government offices, as well as the town's municipality and several other buildings in protest of the TPLF regime. Several arrests reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bale zone, Mada wolabu woreda, ""many""  Oromo people living on the border of Oromia and Somali region were killed by Liyu Police paramilitaries. About 7000 people have fled the area to Dalo mana woreda.
In Minjar Shenkora, North Shewa, protesters burnt a Chinese chipwood factory and disrupted a meeting by regime officials. The protesters were demonstrating the TPLF regime. Arrests reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge, Gumbi Bordode woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo people early in the morning in a pre-dawn raid. They killed one person and wounded one other

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Guji zone, Liban woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo people, who returned fire. Seven Oromos and 8 people Liyu policemen were killed in the exchange.
Ethiopian forces carry out an attack against Liben community. During the attack seven people were killed and several others wounded.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
Eritrean refugees and opposition groups staged a protest against their government, specifically against political and religious persecution. The protesters numbered 200.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitaries killed one Oromo man in Adama and sexually assaulted his wife.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Patriotic Ginbot 7 attacks a military camp in Azezo. Causalities not known; a truck was destroyed.
Students in Bule Hora University demonstrated against national security forces on campus.

A bomb thrown into a hotel in Bahir Dar injured two people. The grenade was thrown into the Yohannes II Garden Hotel where a soccer team from Axum, Tigray had checked in. It is not known if the team was the target.
At least ten people were killed and several others wounded in an attack at Ziway that sources say might have an 'ethnic element.'
Locals of Shakiso protest a contract extension of a 'billionaire' mining gold in the area.

A newly formed militant group known as the 'Ethiopian National Party' carries out two attacks on military forces in Gonder and Azezo. No causalities reported. The political goals of the group are not yet known.

A newly formed militant group known as the 'Ethiopian National Party' carries out two attacks on military forces in Gonder and Azezo. No causalities reported. The political goals of the group are not yet known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bale zone, Gindir woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly killed children gathering firewood. No further information on causality figures.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge, Daro Labu woreda, Ethiopian security forces wearing Liyu Police uniforms killed two people by cutting their reproductive organs and their heads. The reason for the attack is not known.
Defection: Thirty soldiers of the army's 10th division disappear along the southern border with Kenya. The group may have deserted.
Residents of Adola protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective. The date of the Adola protest is not known - source dated 20/11.
Residents of Dima protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitaries kill 30 people in 'northern Oromia,' reasons not known. Seven of the dead are Oromo.
A federal police commander for the north west region of Ethiopia was killed during the night hours in Bahir Dar. The officer was attacked by unidentified assailants at his home.

20 dead in an ethnic clash between Somali and Oromo groups ""last week."" The clashes took place along the border area of the Somali and Oromo regions. Details limited. Fatalities split between events.

column6: ARDUF: Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front
column17: The Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front (ARDUF) said in a press release that 'heavy fighting' has been going on since the third week of November. ARDUF claimed that its fighters killed 17 TPLF soldiers and a dozen critically wounded. The statement did not detail specific dates or locations. Report dated 6 December.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Borana zone, Moyale city, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Ethiopian security forces have wounded around 7 people ""throughout the week."" Source dated 23/11.

20 dead in an ethnic clash between Somali and Oromo groups ""last week."" The clashes took place along the border area of the Somali and Oromo regions. Details limited. Fatalities split between events.
Two young men were killed in Yaya Gulale and three were wounded by Ethiopian security forces as they were eating. The reason for the attack is not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: West Hararge, Bordode woreda, two of Oromia policemen were abducted and two were killed by Liyu Police paramilitaries.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Borana zone, Arero woreda, 3 people died and more than 23 people were wounded during clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromo people of the area. In a contradiction from the source, 10 more people were killed by Ethiopian security forces after Liyu Police requested help after 18 of their members were killed. Coded as unknown fatalities (3).

column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Somali Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: Government forces deploy to Bordor, kill 19 Somalis and 8 Oromos. The reason for the deployment to the area is believed to be a reaction to ethnic strife in the area.
In West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, students demonstrated against the Liyu police after a student was wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries wounded one person in Haramaya University. Students demonstrated condemning Liyu Police following the incident.

Ethiopian security forces have been arresting and beating young men who were going to the rural parts of Chiro city to help people who were removed from Somali region. The exact location of these attacks is not known.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
A elderly woman is jailed in the Somali region and beaten to death in an effort to silence her London-based activist grandson.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
State forces kill six anti-TPLF protesters in Gursum. No violence reported from protesters.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. In Gursum, Liyu and state forces directly attacked protesters. The attacked led to a clash with Oromo militia. Two Oromo policemen were killed, as well as 2 locals (armed civilian, Oromo Tribesman) and 1 local peacekeeper. The number was revised to seven the following day.
Security forces kill two civilians who were attempting to block the destruction of their home. The killings led to a road-blocking protest against the act. Date not clear - source dated 29/11.
Security forces kill two civilians who were attempting to block the destruction of their home. The killings led to a road-blocking protest against the act. Date not clear - source dated 29/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Protest in Kumbi against the TPLF government. Protests against the government have been occurring in several unnamed areas of East and West Hararghe since 28/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Protest in Boreda against the TPLF government. Protests against the government have been occurring in several unnamed areas of East and West Hararghe since 28/11.
Ethiopian security forces used tear gas to disperse students peacefully demonstrating at Bule Hora University. Many were later arrested. No reported injury.

Sudanese forces gain control of several Ethiopian villages along the border between the two countries. Area not listed by the source, however the occupied villages has been among those in an ongoing border dispute. The soldier claimed they had orders from their government for the action. No reported violence. The forces withdrew on 05/12.

Football fans embark on a violent anti-government protest in Weldiya. The protest was alleged to have begun after supporters of an opposing team shouted racial slurs at the group. Several cars and buildings burnt. After state military forces opened fire on the group, several of the protesters attacked Tigrayan owned businesses. Protest spread into Amhara towns (not named). In retaliation, military forces attacks civilians in Raya, Kobo, Haik and other towns on 04/12. Causalities in all instances not known.

A German tourist is killed by unidentified gunmen at Erta Are Volcano. Though not yet substantiated, there is speculation the Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front (ARDUF) may be responsible, as the group has carried out similar attacks against area civilians in years past.

Football fans embark on a violent anti-government protest in Weldiya. The protest was alleged to have begun after supporters of an opposing team shouted racial slurs at the group. Several cars and buildings burnt. After state military forces opened fire on the group, several of the protesters attacked Tigrayan owned businesses. Protest spread into Amhara towns (not named). In retaliation, military forces attacks civilians in Raya, Kobo, Haik and other towns on 04/12. Causalities in all instances not known.

Football fans embark on a violent anti-government protest in Weldiya. The protest was alleged to have begun after supporters of an opposing team shouted racial slurs at the group. Several cars and buildings burnt. After state military forces opened fire on the group, several of the protesters attacked Tigrayan owned businesses. Protest spread into Amhara towns (not named). In retaliation, military forces attacks civilians in Raya, Kobo, Haik and other towns on 04/12. Causalities in all instances not known.
Following a car accident in South Omo, Mursi residents embark on a violent protest, attacking passing motorists. Thirteen dead, 24 injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge, Jarso woreda, Anano Mite area, Liyu Police killed one person and wounded more. According to the report, the Liyu Police paramilitaries started an attack as they were harvesting their crops.

column8: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Suspected AGUDM elements burn a fuel tanker and kill ""all"" members of its military escort in Gonder. Exact causality figures not provided.
Two are dead following student unrest at Wolega University. The reason of the unrest is not known.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Jarso woreda, 1 Liyu Policeman was killed during overnight fighting (clashes began late on the 8th and continued on the 9th).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Four people were killed byLiyu Police paramilitaries in East Hararge, Babile woreda. The Liyu Police were supported by Ethiopian security forces. A member of the local peacekeeping militia killed two Ethiopian security forces during his capture. The militia member was later killed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Jarso woreda, 1 Liyu Policeman was killed during overnight fighting (clashes began late on the 8th and continued on the 9th).

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were ""disrupted"" - names not provided.

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were ""disrupted"" - names not provided.

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were ""disrupted"" - names not provided.
State forces shoot and kill two students at Nekemt University. Date not known - source dated 12/12. The killings led to a series of protests.

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were ""disrupted"" - names not provided.
State forces shoot and kill two students at Debre Tabor University. Date not known - source dated 12/12. The killings led to a series of protests.

Amhara and Oromo students clash at Adigrat University. One death. It is believed the clash was motivated by disputes between their respective clans. Oromiya media network claims the Amhara and Oromo students clashed with Tigre students. The latter may be the case as the details in the Zehabesha report were limited.

column16: Shabelle Media Network; Oromiya Media Network
column17: Ethiopian security forces killed at least 9 protesting civilians and wounded more in Chelenko town, Meta woreda, east Hararge zone. A secondary source, published later in the week accounts for 18 dead. The attack spurred a number of area protests.

Anti-government protests continue for three days at the University of Bahir Dar. Students from Bahir Dar University, like the other universities, started protesting after the killing of a student in Adigrat University.

People in different parts of Oromia region (exact locations not named) demonstrated following a number of security forces actions against area civilians in Chelenko. The protesters requested that Ethiopian security forces leave the Oromia region.

Anti-government protests continue for three days at the University of Bahir Dar. Students from Bahir Dar University, like the other universities, started protesting immediately after the killing of a student in Adigrat University.

Anti-government protests continue for three days at the University of Bahir Dar. Students from Bahir Dar University, like the other universities, started protesting immediately after the killing of a student in Adigrat University.
Anti-government protests at the University of Debre Tabor.
Anti-government protests at the University of Weldiya.
Anti-government protests at the University of Gonder.
29 Oromo fighters are killed by Somali attackers in Hawi Gudina between 14/12 - 17/12.

32 Somalis are killed by Oromo attackers in Daro Lebu between 14/12 - 17/12. The attacks were apparent retaliatory strikes during several days of attacks in nearby Hawi Gudina. Other reports claim varying fatalities; 14 - 65.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 29 Oromos are killed by Somali attackers in Hawi Gudina between 14/12 - 17/12. A second source claims Liyu Police paramilitaries were involved in Hawi Gudina at a location known as Dhaga dhaba. Three killed on this date.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
In south Oromia Wollo, Baate woreda, Afar police killed two people and wounded two others. They were being supported by Ethiopian security forces.

column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police; Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018)
column17: 32 Somalis are killed by Oromo attackers in Daro Lebu between 14/12 - 17/12. The attacks were apparent retaliatory strikes during several days of attacks in nearby Hawi Gudina. Other reports claim varying fatalities; 14 - 65. Liyu Police paramilitaries, assisted by security forces were involved in Daro Lebu on 15/12. 11 killed on this date.

Regime security forces killed 7 civilians on Monday as they protested the killing of protesters in Chelenko on 11/12. The number of fatalities was spread among two cities, Yabello and Moyale.
Anti government protests in Metu, Nekempte, Dembi Dolo, Wadera, Shakiso following killing of civilians in Chelenqo.
Anti government protests in Metu, Nekempte, Dembi Dolo, Wadera, Shakiso following killing of civilians in Chelenqo.
