column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge zone, Doba woreda, 4 people including a member of Oromia police were wounded by Liyu Police paramilitaries from Somali region.
As of 25/12 anti-government protests at Dire Dawa University (among other not named universities) ""continue."" The date(s) of the initial protest at Dure Dawa (not others) not known.
In west Hararge, Habro woreda, Wachu town, Ethiopian security forces killed 2 young men as they were traveling to Daro Labu. Residents killed 4 of security forces to avenge the two men.

In west Hararge, Habro woreda, Wachu town, Ethiopian security forces killed 2 young men as they were traveling to Daro Labu. Residents killed 4 of security forces to avenge the two men killed by them.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: On Gurbi bordode woreda (part of Mieso), Ethiopian security forces along with Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly ""sneaked into the middle of the town and started a fight"" with people. 6 locals were killed, and one was wounded in the fight that lasted for more than 5 hours.
Gunmen killed eight South Sudanese refugees, including women and children at Dima Refugee Camp in Gambella region of Western Ethiopia on 24/12.
As of 25/12 anti-government protests at Dire Dawa University (among other not named universities) ""continue."" The date(s) of the initial protest at Dure Dawa (not others) not known.

Anti government protests in Kellem, Wollega on or before 29/12.
Anti government protests in Asebe Teferi (aka Chiro) on or before 29/12. Protesters smashed windows.

Four students were injured in Bule Hora University as anti-TPLF protesters clashed with regime supporters. Classes have been disrupted and the pro-TPLF students have reportedly left the campus. Injuries not known.
On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have ""continued"" in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.
Security forces killed two people in Horogudru-Shambu, West Wollega during an anti-government protest.
In Horo Guduru welega woreda, Shambu town, Ethiopian security forces killed two people in an attempt to release a sugar transport truck that was being held by local militias.
Oromo militia clashes with Amhara and Tigray militias in Yayu on or before 12/30. Six injured. Security forces made arrests.

Protesters call for the release of political prisoners in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa, Ambo and Bako noting the demonstrations have ""continued"" on 03/01 (date of initial protest not given; protests in Ambo and Bako have continued for ""several days now."") [As such, protests in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa coded as two days; Ambo and Bako coded as three]. Clashes with security forces have been reported in ""some places.""
Security forces enter Gelila in an effort quell an anti-government protest in Gelila. It is not known if the forces stopped the protest.

Protesters call for the release of political prisoners in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa, Ambo and Bako noting the demonstrations have ""continued"" on 03/01 (date of initial protest not given; protests in Ambo and Bako have continued for ""several days now."") [As such, protests in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa coded as two days; Ambo and Bako coded as three]. Clashes with security forces have been reported in ""some places.""
Anti-government protests ""continue"" in Shambu 01/01. It is not known when the protest began, or if it had continued for consecutive days.

[As such, protests in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa coded as two days; Ambo and Bako coded as three]. Clashes with security forces have been reported in ""some places.""

In Adama, Goro High School students took to the streets protesting the arrest and detention of 18 students of Adama University. Eighteen students of the Adma University were arrested on 02/01 and taken to undisclosed location. Students believe they were targeted because they are ethnic Oromos and ethnic Amhara. It is not known if the students were protesting at the time of their arrest.

Protesters call for the release of political prisoners in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa, Ambo and Bako noting the demonstrations have ""continued"" on 03/01 (date of initial protest not given; protests in Ambo and Bako have continued for ""several days now."") [As such, protests in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa coded as two days; Ambo and Bako coded as three]. Clashes with security forces have been reported in ""some places.""

[As such, protests in Shashemene, Kofele, Arsi Kokosa coded as two days; Ambo and Bako coded as three]. Clashes with security forces have been reported in ""some places.""

In Illubabor zone, Ale woreda, Onga town, Ethiopian security forces injured young men who were organized to start their own business. According to the report, they broke into the rented office and damaged all their computers and printers. The reason for the attack is not known.

In Harari region, Erara woreda, Ethiopian security forces shot and killed a civilian. Additionally, Erara woreda administrator was beaten badly by Ethiopian security forces. The motives in both instances are not known. It is not known if the attacks were related.

In west Arsi zone, Kokosa woreda, 3 people died in the conflict between Oromo police and Local Qerros. A taxi driver tried to hit someone and Qerros retaliated, kicking off a short conflict. Police became involved, sparking clashes that led to the death of the three.

In Borana zone, Odo shakiso woreda (conflicting: Odo Sakiso Woreda is in Guji Zone), Ethiopian security forces reportedly beat and arrested students who were coming back from school wearing Oromo cultural clothes.
In East Hararge zone, Erer woreda, Dodota town, Ethiopian security forces and local militias have engaged in short clashes. No further info. Conflicting: Erer Woreda is in the Somali zone.

Forces of the Ogaden National Liberation Front fighting the regime in Eastern Ethiopia said they had killed many soldiers and wounded unknown numbers of government troops"" (fatalities coded as 3) in Jaleelo, Shilabo on 08/01. The report also added that the ONLA has captured weapons, ammunition and communication equipment.

Reports of an extrajudicial killing of prisoners in Yirga Alem. The four prisoners, who had served their sentences were shot when they complained they had not been released. Prison officials cliam the four were trying to escape.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
Agreement: The Ethiopian government announced on 21/01 that 148 members of the Eritrean GDM had surrendered to Ethiopian government authorities ""in recent weeks.""

Agreement: Ethiopian government announced to release 528 people of political prisoners. 108 of them were Oromo prisoners including Dr. Marara Gudina, president of Oromo federalist Congress. They have also announced to close Maekelawe prison. A number of the prisoners were released two days later.

In west Hararge, Chiro city, there was a large protest that lasted for hours against the appointing of a man named Mamaya Yusef into the city administration. The protests were kicked off after rumours spread that he had killed two people during the crackdown in 2015. Police responded ""brutally"" injuring almost 15 people, including 3 who were hospitalized in serious condition.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Four are killed during continued violent protests against the TPLF government.

Anti-TPLF protest continue in Weldiya. Reports of stone throwing on behalf of protesters. Security forces opened fire on a group of the demonstrators, killing between 7-12. Note: it is possible 4 of the 12 were fatally wounded on the previous day of protests. A later report claimed 11 dead over two days. Several arrests made. Protests continued the following day during their victim's funeral procession. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area.
Anti-government protests occur ""at the weekend."" At least one death reported at the hands of security forces.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge zone, Mieso zone, Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly attacked people as they were going about their daily activities, sparking clashes among local militias. One Oromo was killed. Locals complained that Liyu Police took around 200 animals.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge zone, Mieso zone, Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly attacked people as they were going about their daily activities, sparking clashes among local militias. One Oromo was killed. Locals complained that Liyu Police took around 200 animals.

Anti-TPLF protest continue in Weldiya. Reports of stone throwing on behalf of protesters. Security forces opened fire on a group of the demonstrators, killing between 7-12. Note: it is possible 4 of the 12 were fatally wounded on the previous day of protests. A later report claimed 11 dead over two days. Several arrests made. Protests continued the following day during their victim's funeral procession. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area.

Two trucks carrying grains and a fuel tanker were set on fire in Hara town, 20 km away from Weldiya. The acton was part of a larger anti-TPLF protest in the nearby city. The protesters also raided a police station in the town, freeing a number of arrested Weldiya demonstrators from the previous day.
Two protesters are shot and killed by military forces on 22/01, bringing claimed total to 13 over the multiple day ordeal.
Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo.
TPLF security forces shot and killed three people in Alem Tena, East Shewa while holding a sit in protest at a flagpole to mourn the death of protesters in Woldia and Moyale in the weekend.

A massive anti-government protest took place in Welkite city, the administrative city of the Gurage Zone in southern regional state. Thousands came out to the streets protesting against the city administration's failure to deliver a promised hospital.
Unidentified men have thrown a bomb into the Addis Zemen Hotel in Metema town, North Gondar injuring two individuals working for the regime's intelligence and security.
Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo. Reports of police making ""arbitrary arrests.""
Residents of the Gurage Zone capital, Welkite [southern Ethiopia] went to the streets to protest against the killing of people by government security forces in Oromia and Amhara regional states.

Tigrayan TPLF and soldiers from other ethnic groups within the army have exchanged fire in Kobo town, where 3-9 protesters were killed by TPLF soldiers. Sources said non-Tigrayan soldiers within the army have refused to use deadly force against protesters in the town which angered the Tigrayan commanders. Casualities not known.
People in the town of Robit blocked roads preventing the progress of TPLF Agazi soldiers.

Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo continue. The demonstrations became violent. A reported 3 dead following security force intervention. A second source claims nine protester dead. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area. Reports of police making ""arbitrary arrests.""
ONLA fighters claim to have killed 11 members of Ethiopian military force on 25/01 at Habawein in Degahabur.

In East Shewa zone, Fantale woreda, Sara weba kebele, Matahara sugar cane factory reportedly dug up a cemetery, exposing diseased bones on the sidewalk and surface area. People gathered in the area in protest and security forces responded with gunfire. A young girl of 12 years old was killed and two more people were injured.
Students of Salale University protest ""for days"" (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces ""shot and killed"" [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.

Angry residents burnt several local administrative offices, businesses affiliated with the regime and four trucks in Kobo protests. 9 protesters, one TPLF soldier killed in the violence. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area.
Residents protest the TPLF government by blocking roads with logs and other materials in Kobo and Mersa on 26/01.
Residents protest the TPLF government by blocking roads with logs and other materials in Kobo and Mersa on 26/01.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Bale zone, Sawena woreda. Reports of cattle theft and sexual assault.
Students of Salale University protest ""for days"" (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces ""shot and killed"" [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.
TPLF forces shot and killed 13 people in Mersa town where angry protesters set ablaze administrative and judicial offices and businesses affiliated with the TPLF regime.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In west Hararge zone, Fadis woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked civilians. One person was injured in the attack.

10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01. Reports of detainments and executions in Mersa, as well as the killing of a judge at the hand of protesters.
10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01.
10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01.
10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01.
On 29/01, one civilian was killed and three more wounded in Moyale town, in southern Ethiopia, when security forces opened fire at a group of youngsters returning from a local football match.
Anti-TPLF protests in Weldiya continue. Soldiers fired live ammunition, two protesters wounded. No reported protester violence, though the source described ""battles"" in its headline.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In Bate, between Hawi Gudina woreda and Daru Labu woreda, west Hararge zone, Liyu Police paramilitaries entered a home during the night and killed 2 people and wounded a third.
Anti-government protests continue in Mersa. No reported violence or police interaction.

An anti-government protest at Gondar University [north-western Ethiopia] has disrupted examinations. Three students who were badly beaten by police during the protest are admitted at Gondar Hospital and are said to be in a critical situation.

Arrests: Soldiers for the TPLF regime known as Agazi have arrested hundreds of youth in Woldia and Mersa towns in Northern Ethiopia. The reason for their immediate arrest is not known. Source dated 31/01; date of arrests not given.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Doba woreda, Oda bultum area, clashes between Liyu Police paramilitaries and local militias broke out, lasting for almost 6 hours (8a.m-2p.m). 2 locals were killed.

Arrests: Soldiers for the TPLF regime known as Agazi have arrested hundreds of youth in Woldia and Mersa towns in Northern Ethiopia. The reason for their immediate arrest is not known. Source dated 31/01; date of arrests not given.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

In Adama (aka Nazreth) city, Oromia region, the government demolished many people's houses claiming that had been built illegally. The security forces arrested many people for protesting against the demolition.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: On February 07, 2018,in East Hararge zone, Chinaksan woreda, at Qobo(Kobo) Biqa(Bika), 10 year old boy was killed in the shooting between local militia and Liyu Police paramilitaries.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: Property destruction: Liyu Police paramilitaries burnt two houses down at Gololcha (Chinaksan woreda). The reason for their action is not known. No injuries were reported.

Federal security forces killed a young man in Diredawa on the night of 07/02 for unknown reason. His funeral the following day turned into protest. The federal security forces are firing at the protesters. No confirmed number of death and injury reported.

In wollo zone, Bate Woreda (Haro Maya), Afar region militia crossed the border 15 Kilometres into the region and attacked civilians. Extent of injuries not known. The city administration asked federal security forces for help, but federal security forces were favouring Afar region militias.

Federal security forces killed a young man in Diredawa on the night of 07/02 for unknown reason. His funeral the following day turned into protest. The federal security forces are firing at the protesters. No confirmed number of death and injury reported.

column8: Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Agazi Unit
column17: Military-Agazi forces killed 10 Internally Displaced People [IDPs] at the Hamaresa [eastern Ethiopia] camp on 11/02 following a protest of a number of IDPs. The camp shelters people [ethnic Oromo] displaced from Somali Regional State. State television claimed ""clashes.""
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Several anti-government protests took place in Addis Ababa on 12/02. The protests took place in the subdivisions of Lege Tafo, Furi, Kara Kore, Burayu, Asko, Sebeta
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.
Several anti-government protests took place in Addis Ababa on 12/02. The protests took place in the subdivisions of Lege Tafo, Furi, Kara Kore, Burayu, Asko, Sebeta

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Riotous anti-government protests in Jima over at least two days. The protesters targeted government operated buses.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Following a total trade and market boycott the previous day, protests took place in East Hararge Zone, Kombolcha woreda, Melka Raafu city.
Large anti-government protest in Bishoftu.
Residents of an Addis Abeba suburb hold a anti-government demonstration, burn tyres. The protest began the previous day.
Riotous anti-government protests in Jima over at least two days. The protesters targeted government operated buses.

In East Shewa zone, Bose woreda, Wolanchiti town, Ethiopian security forces killed one person and wounded 3 more. The victims were taking part in a protest/business boycott against the TPLF government.
Several are arrested and two are killed during a 7 day ""stay at home strike"" in Welkite. The strike began on 13/02, though it is not known when the violence occurred.

Reports that security forces have been ""killing and jailing people."" Numbers of fatalities not known. There were protests in Jima the two previous days, though it is not clear if there were active protests on 14/02.

In Holeta town, Oromia special zone Finfine, the Ethiopian security forces run their truck over 7 year old boy. According the eye witnesses, they did it intentionally. It is not known if the child died.
In Welenchiti town, East Shewa zone, security forces killed 2 people. One of them was local administrative unit leader. It is not known if the victims were protesting at the time.
A protest sparked ""last week"" (source dated 21/02) when residents of Wolkite learnt that the project to build a world class hospital in the town has been moved to the Tigray region.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Chinaksan woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Ethiopian security forces simultaneously attacked the people of Qobo(Kobo) area. Two persons died from local areas and 3 people from Liyu Police were captured alive.
In East Hararge zone, around Haramaya University, 4 people were killed in security forces shooting for supporting the students in boycott.

Massive protest in Gurage zone, Wolkite city, turned into violent after security forces killed one person and wounded 3 more. 7 government vehicles were burned down also city administration building and all the documents in it were burned down.

Non-violent activity: Ethiopia's Prime Minister, Hailemariam Desalegn, resignation to Parliament. In a televised address, the PM said the resignation would be ""part of the solution to the [anti-government protest] crisis.""

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018

Property destruction: West Arsi zone prison located in Shashamene is set alight. People think that it is the government itself that burnt the prison to use that as an excuse to declare state of emergency.

Security Measures: The Ethiopian government declared a six-month state of emergency on 16/02. The government had cited ""ethnic-based clashes"" and ""chaos and unruliness"" as the reasons for the move.
Arrests: In DireDawa city, in the area called 08, Ethiopian security forces imprisoned many youths following the ""stay-at-home"" boycott. There are more than 200 youth in the prison.
In Qellam wollega zone, Jimma Horro woreda, Nunu town, people protested the state of emergency
Protest against the state of emergency in Addis Ababa.
In Gondar, Amhara region, many people were injured by Ethiopian security forces as they were welcoming the recently released political prisoners.
""Unrest"" reported in Waja Timuga, North Wollo. Protesters attacked administrative offices venting their anger against the regime. Date of the protest not known - source dated 21/02.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Mayu muluke woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries and local residents have been fighting ""for days."" It is not clear when the fighting began; coded as two days. Causality numbers not known.
In west Hararge zone, Chinaksan woreda, Ethiopian security forces arrested and beat youths and leaders in the woreda on February 21, 2018. Motive not known.
In Shashamane city, a driver was beaten by security forces for having picture of political party leader on his vehicle.

Anti-government, anti-state of emergency protests reported in Gurage area, affecting the towns of Welkite, Indibir and Agena. Violence reported. Three dead among the towns. Date(s) not known - source dated 21/02. Several arrests reported.

Anti-government, anti-state of emergency protests reported in Gurage area, affecting the towns of Welkite, Indibir and Agena. Violence reported. Three dead among the towns. Date(s) not known - source dated 21/02. Several arrests reported.

Anti-government, anti-state of emergency protests reported in Gurage area, affecting the towns of Welkite, Indibir and Agena. Violence reported. Three dead among the towns. Date(s) not known - source dated 21/02. Several arrests reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: In West Hararge zone, Mayu muluke woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries and local residents have been fighting ""for days."" It is not clear when the fighting began; coded as two days. Causality numbers not known.

Ethiopian security members are arrested and imprisoned by protesters in Asandabo. Several of the arrested were senior military officers. Several of the officers were reportedly wounded. The group was later released.

In north west Shewa, zone, Tole woreda, Bantu town, a student was shot by security forces and taken to hospital. He was shot during a protest that students were doing to oppose the state of emergency.

Ethiopian security forces killed one student and wounded two more in Arsii zone, Lemo woreda, Bokoji town. Students were singing in group as they were going back home from school, but security forces did not understand the language the students were speaking and thought they were protesting.
Agreement: ONLF announces it ceases hostilities with Ethiopian government.
Arrests: Security forces arrest ""thousands"" of OFC supporters who had gathered to ""welcome home"" a number of recently released political prisoners.

Clashes have been reported in Bahir Dar, after soccer fans chanted anti-TPLF slogans in and outside the city stadium. No casualties were reported but stone throwing fans have reportedly clashed with security forces after they had left the stadium.
Renewed protest in Oromo region, where opposition leaders were banned from meeting their supporters. One is dead following protests in Dembi Dolo on 24/02.
Protests against restrictions on meetings with political dissidents begins on 24/02 and continues for at least four days.

In Kelam welega, Dambi dolo city, more than 6 people died in a shooting by Ethiopia security forces. Security forces arrested a man who was announcing a religious conference. A number of people opposed the arrest and security forces responded by opening fire.
Gebeyehu Fantahun, a political prisoner serving a four year term dies after reports of abuse.
Day two: Protests against restrictions on meetings with political decedents begins on 24/02 and continues for at least four days.

Day three: The city of Nekemte was covered with plumes of smokes as protesters burnt tyres and blocked roads in third day of protests over the detention and ban on leaders of the Oromo Federalist Congress (OFC). The protest may have also been related to the detention of OFC supporters in Gute.

Day four: One person was killed and 20 others wounded when snipers of the TPLF/Agazi forces indiscriminately shot at protesters in the city of Nekemte. It was additionally reported a protester threw a hand grenade against security forces. Protests in the city began on 24/02.
Arrests: The Ethiopian government has arrested the mayor of Nekemte town for allegedly collaborating with protesters.
Following numerous reports of assault upon protesters, a number of demonstrators attacked security forces. Five deaths reported among the security forces.

In Guto Gidda woreda, Uke town (near Nekemt), one man was killed and 3 people wounded by security forces. It is not known if the individuals were protesting at the time. There were additional reports of security forces breaking into homes and attacking residents.
Unrest in ""western Oromo"" continues. (Likely in or around Dembi Dolo) One student reported killed and a second wounded. A number of local administrative officials were arrested.

Ethiopia's Defence Minister declared on 07 March that 17 security forces have been killed since the beginning of government's state of emergency on 16/02. (Five security force deaths have been previously recorded). Specific details, such as time and location not provided.
02 March. Three are killed by security forces in Gonder. It is not known if the victims were protesting at the time of attack.
02 March. Security forces shot and killed a 12 year old in Mendi town.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 02 March. Reports of security forces and Liyu Police paramilitaries attacking and injuring people in Chinaksen woreda, exact location not provided. In one instance, Liyu Police stabbed and killed an Oromo person.
02 March. Reports of security forces ""arresting and killing people"" in Meyumuluke. Two deaths reported, one injury.
02 March. One person was killed in Kelem Wollega (exact location not reported) while another sustained serious injuries.
02 March. Three are killed by security forces in Ambo. It is not known if the victims were protesting at the time of attack.
03 March. Security forces kill six protesters in Kelem Wellega over 03/03 and 04/03. No reported violence from protesters.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Ambo on 03/03 and 04/03. 3 people were reported killed.
03 March. A man is shot and killed by security forces. The man was at home at the time of attack and not protesting.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Ginchi on 03/03 and 04/03.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Guder on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Security forces kill six protesters in Kelem Wellega over 03/03 and 04/03. No reported violence from protesters.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Ginchi on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Ambo on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Security forces shot and killed a man and injured his son in Guder.
On 4 March, in Chiro, west Hararghe zone, one person was killed by security forces. There were no protests in the city at the time.
On 4 March, a man was shot from the back by suspected security forces in Gimbi. There were no protests at the time.
04 March. Three people killed by security forces including a man taken from his house.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Guder on 03/03 and 04/03.
05 March. Security forces shot and killed three people (protesters). Two were killed in Jimma, according to Oromo activists, while the third was killed in West Hararghe, in a locality called Chiro.

05 March. Security forces shot and killed three people (protesters). Two were killed in Jimma, according to Oromo activists, while the third was killed in West Hararghe, in Chiro. The victim in Chiro was not protesting at the time of attack.
06 March. A shopkeeper in Mieso accused government forces of ""excessive violence."" The violence is alleged to have occurred on or before 06/03.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 07 March. Liyu Police paramilitary forces move into Meda Welabu, engage in a battle with Oromo militia. Two Oromo and three Liyu Police dead. Before departing the Liyu Police stole 150 cattle.
07 March. Security forces beat a man to death as he walked home. The reason for the attack is not known.
07 March. In Jimma Zone, Omo Nada woreda, security forces kill two civilians.
08 March. Several injuries reported in Mieso after security forces open fire on civilians.
08 March. Security forces beat a pregnant woman in Dire Dawa until she miscarried.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Agazi Unit
column17: 10 March. Agazi Soldiers shot and killed at least 9 civilians in Moyale town. 25 others wounded. ESAT claimed 13 dead in a later report. The five soldiers involved in the shooting were later arrested, though the government claimed the attacks were accidental. The attacks caused 50,000 to flee the area, many of whom crossed the border into Kenya.
11 March. Security forces shoot and kill a civilian in Habro woreda, Dalo town. The victim was executed after being called from inside a house.

Arrests: 11 March. ""Hundreds"" of Oromo students are arrested while travelling during an academic break. The location of the arrests are not known. One of the students may have been suspected of carrying an explosive. A few days later, on 14 March, Taye Denda a member of the Oromo State justice bureau was also arrested after expressing criticism of the Moyale killings.
11 March. Security forces kill one and injure another in Moyale the day following a series of attacks which killed between 9-13.
13 March. Security forces shoot and kill a 12-year old at a unknown Oromo location. The reason for the attack is not known.

13 March. Qeerro (Oromo youths) blocked fuel tankers operating in southern Oromo State in protest against recent state violence. The blockade has created a severe fuel shortage in Addis Ababa. The blockade began on 13/03 and lasted at least until 14/03.
14 March. A Oromo fuel blockade, largely affecting Addis Ababa, enters its second day. The protest is believed to last a week, though there were no reports of specific instances.
14 March. A civilian is found shot in Ginchi woreda, Chilimo. Perpetrators not known.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
16 March, seven soldiers were killed when they attempted to seize guns from local farmers in North Gondar Zone of the Amhara Region.
16 March. In Jima woreda, security forces have been arresting and beating people including students. They broke into student's apartment and beat them.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: On 16 March, soldiers dressed in Liyu Police uniforms reportedly killed 5 members of a family int he village of Burka Dare in Seweyna district, Bale zone. Villagers fled.

17 March. In Kelam welaga zone, Dambi Dollo woreda, security forces were attacked and 12 killed including two of their commanders. It was reported that OLF, Oromo liberation front was behind the killings.
17 March. Unconfirmed reports that three fuel trucks transporting gas from Amhara region to Addis Ababa were set on fire after going against a fuel boycott.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
column17: 18 March 2018: Liyu police killed 5 people (assumed Oromo) and wounded two in Seweyna woreda (Bale, Oromia). The victims were all of the same family, though it is not known if they were targeted due to this.
21 March. Students started demonstrating against the arrest of Oromo students at universities. Security forces responded by firing shots. No reports of injuries.
More than 10 people were killed in communal clashes between pastoralists between Decha and Cheta districts in Kafa Zone. No date, source dated 24 March.

Arrests: More than 1,100 people have been arrested across Ethiopia since the state of emergency was declared in February following the resignation of Hailemariam Desalegn. More than 30 people including journalists were detained by Ethiopian security forces in Addis Abeba, Bahir Dar and in cities in east and west Hararghe zone on 25 March for instance.
On 25 March, 19 civilians who gathered to discuss the formation of a new political party were arrested by security forces in Bahir Dar. Some of the arrested were allegedly tortured.
Around the week of 25 March, in Badassa, west Hararge, a man was re-arrested and tortured several times.

Around the week of 25 March in Boke town, west Hararge zone, a young man was tortured by security forces and died after he was taken to hospital in Addis Ababa. He was accused of blocking the road and stirring others to violence. Details are limited.
On 25 March, security forces continued to arrest and beat people in east Guji and other parts of Oromia region.
Around the week of 25 March, in west Shewa zone, Ambo, a 12th grade student was taken along with her friends by security forces. They appeared in hospital 7 days later.
On 26 March, youth in Harari Woreda protested against the local militia.

On 27 March, two suspected Kenyans from the Garre clan were killed in Ethiopia while riding a motorcycle by suspected members of the Kenyan Degodia clan. The attack took place near the border with Kenya. Retaliatory clashes occurred in Kenya the following days.

Non-violent activity: On 27 March, Ethiopia's ruling coalition (EPRDF) elected Abiy Ahmed as leader of the party. This will pave the way for the first Oromo prime minister in the 27-year rule of the EPRDF.
On 28 March, command post soldiers have been arresting and beating students who were leaving the campus in Salale University (in Fiche, Shewa zone).
On 28 March, soldiers shot and wounded a 26 year old woman as she was celebrating the new president in Nekemt town, east wellega zone.
On 29 March, soldiers broke into the apartments of students in Jimma university and beat and injured many students.
On 30 March, students at Haromaya University were reported to have been detained and beaten.
On 31 March, an attack by unknown gunmen left a soldier killed and three children injured in North Gondar Zone, Amhara State, Goghdaw District, Cochabo Province. Further details limited.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 3 April, a man who had been protecting people from Liyu Police paramilitaries was killed at night in his house in West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda. It was reported that he was killed by order from the security forces.

On 3 April, three security forces were killed by an grenade thrown by an unknown person as they were ""humiliating"" people in Kelam Welaga zone, Dambi Dolo. Following their death the people from the area reported shootings.
On 4 April, security forces arrested more than 300 people, and many were killed in Kelam Welaga zone, Dambi Dolo. No further details

In east Guji zone, federal police beat three young people and threw them in the ditch. One person died in the ditch while the rest survived and are being treated in hospital. Specific date not reported, source date: 4 April 2018.
Arrests: on 4 April, in East Hararge zone, Habro woreda, more than 100 young men were arrested for expressing joy during celebrations of the new prime minister.
On 4 April, in East Guji zone, federal police beat three young people and threw them into a ditch. One died while the others received hospital treatment.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Agazi Unit
column17: On 8 April, a military officer from the Agazi unit shot dead a 20 year mother in Qobo town, east Hararghe zone. She was abducted and killed after being severely assaulted.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 9 April, in west Hararge zone, Miesso woreda, Woltane town, Liyu Police paramilitaries crossed the boundary to attack the people. When the people started defending themselves, security forces surrounded them and beat them.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Agazi Unit
column17: On 9 April, a young man was reportedly shot by Agazi forces in Kobo. He was hospitalised. The incident has not been verified by independent sources.

Around 9 April, 8 Oromo students were arrested from Haramaya university which led to a massive protest by the rest of the students. Reports of continued arrests in Habro and Miesso woredas, east and west Hararge zones respectively security forces.
On 9 April protests were reported in Qobo after the killing of a pregnant woman by security forces the previous evening. The protesters gathered peacefully.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
On 11 April, two militia members from the Tigray region were killed in a shootout with an Afari militia. Injuries were reported on the Afari side.
On 11 April, two were killed in Biir district, near the Eritrean border in clashes with soldiers of the Command Post. No further details provided.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
On 11 April, at Diredawa university, security forces beat and harassed students who have had no classes for about a month.
On 11 April, a 60-year old man was killed by security forces in Kombo village, Chanka district of Kellam wellaga. His son was also critically wounded.
On 11 April, at Haramaya university the security forces beat, harassed and arrested students who have had no classes for about a month. They also prevented the students from access to cafeteria.
In east Hararge zone, Mayu Muluke woreda, students protested following three of their teachers being detained. The school was closed but no one was injured.
On 11 April, In west Hararge zone, Doba woreda, Doba city, many people were injured when military forces opened fire on them as they were protesting for the release of people from prison.
Non-violent activity: On 12 April the Ethiopian House of Peoples Representatives postponed local elections for a year citing security challenges.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 12 April, an unknown person threw a bomb at the prison in Najo city. Security forces arrested people afterwards though local people accuse the security forces of throwing the bomb to stir unrest.

On 13 April, scores of people were reportedly feared dead and thousands displaced in renewed clashes between the Guji and Gedeo communities in Southern Ethiopia between Finchawa and Awassa. Gedeo people were being forced out of their villages in their thousands.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 14 April, in west Hararge zone, Miesso woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries crossed the border and wounded a man. He is being treated in the Chiro Hospital after being seriously injured.

In west Hararge zone, Badessa town, the command post continues to arrest and torture young men. More than 150 young men are being tortured in the prison. 30 of them were transferred to Diredawa city prison.
Arrests: On 14 April in west Hararge zone, Burka Dimtu woreda, the command post arrested 53 young men and 12 religious leaders.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
A member of the military killed a civilian in east Hararge zone, Deder woreda, Kobo town. Source dated 15 April.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Agazi Unit
column17: On 15 April, security forces killed two men in Guji zone, Karcha and other woredas. No more details reported.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Agazi Unit
column17: On 15 April, a total of four people were killed by the Agazi units in the Guji zone in Oromia. One of the four was killed in Bule Hora town and three people from the town were also wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Agazi Unit
column17: On 15 April, a total of three people were killed by the Agazi units in the Guji zone in Oromia.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018

On 16 April, clashes continued in southern Ethiopia between Gedeo and Guji communities. At least 10 people were reported killed in Bule Hora town. Several houses were also set ablaze.

Security forces are heard firing live pellets and 16 people, mostly students arrested by police backed by military.

30 April - 1 May :In Welega university in Nekemte, about 6,000 students protested following the renewal of work permission for MIDROC gold company.

On 30 April, residents living in East and West Guji zone near a gold mine in Southern Ethiopia took to the streets for in protest against the extension of a contract for MIDROC mining company for another ten years. The residents say the dangerous chemicals released from the mining project has resulted in birth defects, blindness and various ailments.

On 1 May, the renewal of a gold mining project for another ten years triggered street protests in five towns in Southern Ethiopia. Locals say the project, which has exploited their natural resources for over twenty years has not benefited the poor. Residents of Shakiso and Fincha towns in Guji zone in Southern Ethiopia have taken to the streets after authorities extended contracts to MIDROC, a company owned by an Ethiopian born Saudi tycoon.

column17: On 31 May, Liyu police attacked people with heavy weapons in Mieso woreda, West Hararge. No one was killed in the fight. Ethiopian security forces were unarming the people at the same time as the Liyu police were attacking the people.
It was reported that a 14-year old boy had his genitals mutilated by TPLF agents in Benishangul. Date not specified.
On 3 June, protests were reported in Hanna Mariam area of Addis Ababa by displaced residents.

On 3 June, around 50 houses were set ablaze in clashes between the Guji and Gedeo communities in Gedeb, a transport route to Moyale in Southern Ethiopia. Thousands feared displaced. No reports of casualties.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4 June, in Tulu Gulad and Jijjiga, Liyu Police paramilitaries, Fedaral police and Oromia police fought following an attack by Liyu Police on the people in Gore Gutu woreda.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4 June, In East Hararge zone, Tulu Gulad and Jijjiga, Liyu Police paramilitaries, Fedaral police and Oromia police fought following an attack by Liyu Police on the inhabitants of Gore Gutu woreda.

On 4 June, in Guji zone, Hambalawa Mana, Gedeo and Burji people started a fight with Oromo people on the border. At least 10 people were killed, and many were removed from their homes and their properties were destroyed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4 June in East Hararge, Gore Gutu woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries seriously wounded 2 young men.
Security Measures: on 5 June, Ethiopia's parliament lifted the state of emergency imposed since February.
Agreement: on 5 June, Ethiopia said it would implement the Algiers peace agreement signed with Eritrea in December 2000 and 'fully accept' the Ethiopian Eritrean Boundary Commission decision.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Arrests: on 5 June, more than 100 youths were seized by Liyu Police paramilitaries in Jijiga zone, the day after an urgent proclamation was announced in the Ethio-Somali region.

Between the 4-14 June, over 200 people were reportedly killed in ethnic violence in Guji Zone in Southern Ethiopia while over 300,000 were displaced. The violence between the Guji and Gedeo groups that began in April has also resulted in the destruction of schools, churches and private properties. Fatalities spread over 10 events including a fight between Oromos and Gedeos on 4 June that left 10 killed.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 5 June, Liyu Police paramilitaries crossed the border and killed an 11 year old girl by cutting her throat with knife in Bale zone, Mada Wolabu woreda.
Between 3-10 June, a number of Amhara people were injured in an attack by local youths in the town of Kilim Wollega in the town of Cio district.

On 6 June, around 3,000 residents of the subdivision of Hanna Mariam took to the streets of Addis Ababa to protest the demolition of their homes to provide land for investors.

On the week of 3-9 June, Oromo youth groups surrounded Amhara homes, beating residents, and looting property in the Siyo District of Qellem Wollega Zone, Oromia State. The incident came against alleged rising attacks by Oromos on Amhara people.

On 7 June, in the Rahile woreda, Afar region, a large number of people protested. They requested that Mr. Rashid Sali be released from prison. Rashid Sali is Samara University human resource director and was detained as he disagreed with Ethiopian military generals as they wanted to have total control over Samara university.

Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Barahle, Koneba and other towns.

column17: On 8 June a Liyu Police paramilitary unit attacked three localities in the Oromo region - Qobbo Bikka, Ulanula and Walensu - in Chinaksen district, Oromia, killing three people and wounding three others.

column17: Around 9 June, Oromo people in Harari demonstrated against the regional government's displacement from their land without compensation. Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly shot and injured demonstrators.

Thirty homes and four vehicles were also set ablaze. The Qebenas claim the town belongs to them and demand that the Gurages should leave the town. One death reported on 13 June.
On 13 June, some people were reported killed in clashes in the town of Kebele, Kibbutin. No further details.

Over 13-15 June, riots reported between the Sidama and Wolaita groups in Hawassa town following the kidnapping and killing of two people and violence at a new year festival. Residences were burnt and ransacked. Total of 10 people killed from 13-15 June.

column7: Wolayeta Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-)
column17: Around 15 June, around three people were killed in Wolaita Sodo town following retaliatory violence between Sidama and Wolaita ethnic groups.
On 17 June, the TPLF organised a protest rally in Addis Ababa in an attempt to reportedly frustrate Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed.
On 17 June, protests were reported in Mekele by natives of Irob against the decision by the federal government to accept and implement the boundary ruling with Eritrea.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: In East Hararge zone, Babile woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed one person and wounded three persons.
On 19 June, in West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, security forces beat and re-arrested a group of young men.

On 21 June, residents of Dire Dawa, a city in Eastern Ethiopia, protested for the president of the Somali region to step down, his administration of instigating conflict among different groups, and of corruption.
On 21 June, protests in the Afar region continue. In Konnaba, Afar women were reported at front line of the protest. The protesters are calling for good governance and social justice.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 21 June, in Jimma town, Jimma zone, security forces opened fire on a crowd welcoming recently released political prisoners injuring at least 11 people.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Agreement: On 21 June Ginbot 7 declared that they will unarm their soldiers and join for a discussion with the Ethiopian government.

On 23 June, an unidentified man attempted to throw a grenade at the new PM Abiy Ahmed during a rally in the capital before being apprehended by police. The grenade still detonated resulting in 2 deaths and 150 injuries.
On 24 June, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.
On 24 June in Kembolcha, protesters reportedly raided a school named after the day the ruling EPRDF took power, removed the nameboard and threw it in the river.

column7: SEPDM: Southern Ethiopian Peoples Democratic Movement
column17: Non-violent activity: on 25 June, the chairman of the Southern Ethiopian People's Democratic Movement (SEPDM), one of the four coalition members of the EPRDF, resigned over conflict in the southern region. Political observers claim the move came as part of prime minister Abiy's call for accountability among senior leaders in the southern region state (the chairman was accused of being implicated in manufacturing the conflict).

On 25 June, one person was killed in violence between Berta people and Oromo/Amhara groups in Asosa, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June.

""A male staff member of an INGO was killed when the public transport bus he was riding on was shot at by armed attackers. A total of 26 people were on the bus, of which 3 were killed and others wounded.""

On 26 June, 7 people were killed in violence between Berta people and Oromo/Amhara groups in Asosa, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June.

Between 25-27 June, a total of 14 people were reported killed in violence between Berta people and Oromo/Amhara groups in Asosa, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State, including one on the first day and seven on the second. & remaining fatalities spread over two events on 27 June.

On or around 27 June, police shot and killed non-locals (Amhara/Oromo groups) who were holding a counter-protest against the attacks by the Bertas in Asosa, Benishangul region. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June, including one on the first day and seven on the second. & remaining fatalities spread over two events on 27 June.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 27 June, in east Hararge zone, Gumbi Bordede woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed two people. No further details.
On 28 June, unidentified gunmen shot and wounded four police officers in Nekemte, Oromia Regional State
Arrests: on 28 June, up to 125 youth were arrested by the police, as they prepared to receive the prime minister who was hosted in the region's state capital, Samara.
Property destruction: on 28 June, it was reported that the Grand Anwar Mosque in Addis Ababa was set on fire. No further details.

column16: Diamond World News Service; Addis Fortune
column17: On June 29th, between three and five hundred protestors invaded an emerald site run by Web Gemstone Mining (majority owned by Gemfields) in the area of Web (Borena zone). Two employees suffered minor injuries. The reasons for the demonstration are unclear.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 29 June 2018: In kumbi woreda, East Hararge zone, Liyu police and Oromo people fought. One person was wounded from each side

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 29 June 2018: In West Hararge zone, Oda Bultum woreda, 15 KMs from Bedesa, Liyu police wounded one Oromo person; it is unclear whether the Oromo were also armed or not.

On 30 June, residents of Bahir Dar and other 20 towns in Ethiopia's northwestern Amhara Regional State were reported to hold peaceful rallies to show support for the reforms brought by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed in the country.
On 30 June, in Metema, the Sudanese army killed five farm workers in an unprovoked attack.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 30 June 2018: In east Hararge zone Chinaksen woreda, Liyu police killed one person and wounded one. They also burned down houses. The Oromo people were assumed to be unarmed when they were attacked.

column9: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement; ONLA: Ogaden National Liberation Army
column17: Agreement: on 30 June, the Ethiopian government agreed to lift the terror label from the ONLF, OLF and Ginbot 7. Two days later, the UOLF agreed to give up arms and accept the government's peace offer.
On or after 1st July, a group purporting to be a faction of the OLF attacked locations in Welega zone, killing four police officers.
On 1 July, a massive crowd was reported at a rally in the northwestern Ethiopian town of Bahir Dar in support of Prime Minister Abiy.
On 1 July, a rally was reported in Shewa Robit in support of Prime Minister Abiy.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 01 July 2018: In East Hararge zone, Babile woreda, Liyu police and Oromo people fought. One person was killed from Oromo people and 6 members of Liyu police were killed as well .

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Around 2 July, in west Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Liyu Police paramilitaries wounded 7 people.
Around 2 July, in Kelem Welega zone, the road between Dambi Dolo and Addis Ababa has been closed because of the fight between OLF (Oromo liberation front) and Ethiopian security forces.

On 3 July, Ethiopian and Sudanese troops engaged in a brief battle after Sudanese soldiers killed and injured several Ethiopian farmers. There were deaths on both sides. Seven Ethiopians including members of the army have been sent to Genda Wuha Hospital in Metema after the brief exchange of fire.
Arrests: on 3 July, Ethiopia announced it had arrested 54 individuals, including 4 senior police officers in connection with riots in the Benishangul Gumuz regional last week.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 4 July. Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked predominantly Oromo residents of Babile and Chinaksen in East Hararghe killing at least three, setting 60 houses on fire and displacing hundreds of people. 1 fatality reported in Babile.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 4 July. Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked predominantly Oromo residents of Babile and Chinaksen in East Hararghe killing at least three, setting 60 houses on fire and displacing hundreds of people. There was a similar attack in Gursum, the administrator said adding that one person was killed in an area called Kumbi.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 4 July. The Liyu Police attacked predominantly Oromo residents of Babile and Chinaksen in East Hararghe killing at least three, setting 60 houses on fire and displacing hundreds of people. 1 fatality recorded in Chinaksen.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo civilians in Bule Hora woreda, Bornea zone. Two civilians were killed, and three injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4th July, Liyu Police attacked Chinaksen woreda, eastern Hararge zone and clashed with Oromo militiamen. 9 killed including 7 Liyu Police. One Oromo injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 4th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed four and wounded one in Meda Welabu woreda, Bale zone (Oromia).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 5th July, conflict continued between the Oromo militia and the Liyu Police, in Chinakswer (Eastern Harage zone). One Oromo was wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 6th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries fired at civilians in Moyale town (Borena zone), killing two. They also set fire to houses in the town.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch.
