column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 7th July, a member of the federal police was killed by Liyu Police in Babile (Eastern Hararge zone).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 7th July, a civilian was killed by Liyu Police in Babile (Eastern Hararge zone). On the same day a member of the Federal Police was killed.
On 8th July, an unknown armed group killed 10 people in Senbete (Wollo zone). 8 of the decesased were the Amhara regional police, the identity of the other 2 is not specified.

On 9 July, Ethiopia and Eritrea declared in a joint statement that they are no longer at war after a series of historic meetings in Asmara to end decades of acrimony and conflict. They also announced that trade, diplomatic and communication linkages would be re-established.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 10th July, fighting between Liyu Police and an Oromo militia resulted in the death of five Liyu Police paramilitaries, and one Oromo. The event took place within Dawa Sara woreda (coordinates for Robe used).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 10th July, Liyu Police killed one Oromo and wounded another, at Mieso woreda in Western Hararge.

On or before 11th July, a protest at a hotel took place in Debre Markos, against an unpopular political elites who was (falsely) rumoured to be staying at the hotel. The protestors set fire to a car suspected to belong to the politician, and damaged the hotel. After four hours, the federal army broke up the protests.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 12th July, Liyu Police clashed with Oromo forces in Chinaksen woreda (East Harerge zone). Seven Liyu Police were killed, as well as two Oromo fighters. Two Oromo were also injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 12th July, Liyu Police clashed with Oromo forces in Meda Welabu woreda (Bale zone). Four Liyu Police paramilitaries were killed, as well as one Oromo fighter.

Agreement: On 12th July, a faction of the OLF - led by Dawud Ibsa - announced that it had agreed to a ceasefire with the government. This follows a meeting earlier in the week between Dawud Ibsa and Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed in Asmara.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 13th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked a location in Mieso woreda (West Hararge zone), whilst the residents were sleeping. Seven people were reported killed, three of whom are described as Oromia police (assumed also in civilian capacity).

During mid-July, armed Oromo were alleged to have massacred Ethiopian-Somali civilians (unknown estimate ). There was no specific location provided (coordinates for Somali regional capital Jijiga used).

Around July 16, in North Shewa zone (including in Debre Tsige town), police intercepted over 70 guns and one automatic riffle hidden in trucks by unidentified actors to be transported to the captal. Some of the seized guns are Russian made Makarov pistols.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Movement of forces: On or before 16th July, the government of Ethiopia instructed the army and federal police to protect civilians from the Liyu Police in the Oromo and Somali regions, redeploying them to parts of the border between the areas. The regional presidents were reported to have agreed to this move. Relatedly, meetings were held in Dire Dawa on or before the 19th July, to prevent further instability from Abdi Illey (the president of the Somali region, who controls the Liyu Police).

On 19th July, a mob attacked journalists travelling to Addis Ababa, at Mieso woreda (West Hararge zone), accusing them of being spies. The driver of their vehicle died later in hospital, and five other crew were injured. Nobody has been arrested.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 20th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed 5 Oromo citizens in Chinaksen woreda (East Hararge zone), and wounded many more.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Movement of forces: On or before 21st July, large numbers of Liyu Police were reported to have been crossing into Chinakser woreda in East Hararge zone, as well as other woredas in the zone.
On 21st July, one person was killed and another wounded when an unidentified group fired at civilians in Dembi Dollo woreda (Kelem Wellega zone).

column16: Oromiya Media Network; Xinhua; Local Source
column17: On 21st and 22nd July, violence erupted between mainly Muslim residents of Goba city (Bale zone) and mainly Christian migrant residents of surrounding villages in the area over ownership of a park in Goba town. The violence was ostensibly related to the replacement of a statue in a park traditionally used by the Christians for Timket (Epiphany) celebrations with a statue of a local Muslim hero. Police failed to separate them. The federal army was later sent to prevent clashes from re-occurring. 11 people were reported killed during the weekend (some of whom died later as a result of their injuries), and over 100 injured.

column16: Oromiya Media Network; Xinhua; Local Source
column17: On 21st and 22nd July, violence erupted between mainly Muslim residents of Goba city (Bale zone) and mainly Christian migrant residents of surrounding villages in the area over ownership of a park in Goba town. The violence was ostensibly related to the replacement of a statue in a park traditionally used by the Christians for Timket (Epiphany) celebrations with a statue of a local Muslim hero. Police failed to separate them. The federal army was later sent to prevent clashes from re-occurring. 11 people were reported killed during the weekend (some of whom died later as a result of their injuries), and over 100 injured.
On 22nd July, residents of the Benshangul-Gumaz zone attacked Oromo civilians and looted their property in the zone (coordinates for Asosa used).

column16: Local Source; Xinhua; Oromiya Media Network
column17: On 21st and 22nd July, violence erupted between mainly Muslim residents of Goba city (Bale zone) and mainly Christian migrant residents of surrounding villages in the area over ownership of a park in Goba town. The violence was ostensibly related to the replacement of a statue in a park traditionally used by the Christians for Timket (Epiphany) celebrations with a statue of a local Muslim hero. Police failed to separate them. The federal army was later sent to prevent clashes from re-occurring. 11 people were reported killed during the weekend (some of whom died later as a result of their injuries), and over 100 injured.

On 23rd July, a large number of protesters gathered in Jijiga city (Somali zone) demanding the resignation of the controversial regional president, Abdi Illey. Police violently broke up the protests, causing a number of injuries.

On 23rd July, clashes took place in Dessie city (Amhara zone) between two Muslim sects, over the ownership of a local mosque. Six people were injured, and over 50 were arrested by police the following day.
On 24th July, police killed a pregnant woman who was on her way to give birth in a hospital. The event took place in Dembi Dolo, Kelem Wellega zone. Three police were arrested.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 25th July, Liyu Police attacked Oromo forces in Chinaksen woreda (East Hararge zone). Four Liyu Police paramilitaries were killed in the fighting.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 25th July, prisoners rioted at three prisons in the Amhara region (at Debre Markos, Weldiya and Finote Selam towns). The prisoners believed they should be released under the recently passed Amnesty Law, and set the prisons on fire whilst trying to escape. Some inmates attempted to incite violence at two prisons in Addis Ababa, though without success.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 25th July, prisoners rioted at Arba Minch town (Gamo Gofa zone). The prisoners believed they should be released under the recently passed Amnesty Law, and set the prisons on fire whilst trying to escape.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 25th July, prisoners rioted at an unspecified location in Tigray (coordinates for regional capital of Mekele used). The prisoners believed they should be released under the recently passed Amnesty Law.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 25th July, prisoners rioted at three prisons in the Amhara region (at Debre Markos, Weldiya and Finote Selam towns). The prisoners believed they should be released under the recently passed Amnesty Law, and set the prisons on fire whilst trying to escape. Some inmates attempted to incite violence at two prisons in Addis Ababa, though without success.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 25th July, prisoners rioted at three prisons in the Amhara region (at Debre Markos, Weldiya and Finote Selam towns). The prisoners believed they should be released under the recently passed Amnesty Law, and set the prisons on fire whilst trying to escape. Some inmates attempted to incite violence at two prisons in Addis Ababa, though without success.
On 26th July, protests broke out in Gonder (Amhara zone), the home town of the murdered chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, Eng Simegnew.

On 26th July, the body of the chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam - Eng Simegnew - was discovered in his car in Addis Ababa. He was shot in the back of the head. Protests erupted in his hometown in Amhara after his suspected murder. The construction of the dam has caused a long-standing dispute with Egypt, which fears the dam could reduce its share of the Nile waters.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 27th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked civilians in Chinakser woreda (East Harerge zone). One Oromo civilian was killed, and another was wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Afar Special Forces
column17: On or before July 28th, Special Forces from the Afar region were reported to have been attacking Oromo civilians in Wollo zone (coordinates for South Wollo used).
On 29 July, Ethiopian police clashed with protesters in Wereta calling for the arrest of culprits behind the death of the chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam
29 July 2018: Afar Militias attacked an Oromo cummunty in Wollo zone, Amhara region. No fatalities reported
On 29 July, Ethiopian police fired teargas to disperse crowd in Addis Ababa calling for the arrest of culprits behind the death of the chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 30th July, Liyu Police and Oromo fighters clashed in Chinakser woreda (East Harerge zone). One Oromo was killed and three were wounded, whilst six Liyu Police were killed, and over ten injured.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 30th July, Liyu Police and Oromo fighters fought in Babile woreda (East Harerge zone). One Oromo was killed, whilst four Liyu Police paramilitaries died, and three were wounded.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: Security measures: On 30th July, the administrators of three prisons (Kilinto, Kaliti and Shewa Robit) were fired and replaced, amidst concerns over the treatment of prisoners.

On 30th July, unidentified gunmen ambushed a commercial vehicle travelling from Dilla to Amaro, killing the driver and another passenger. The ambush took place in Kembolcha, Gelana woreda (coordinates for Dilla used).

column16: Diamond World News Service; Addis Fortune
column17: On July 31st, between two and three hundred protestors invaded emerald site run by Web Gemstone Mining (majority owned by Gemfields) in the area of Web (Borena zone), overwhelming police stationed at the site. The protestors looted the camps, and broke into a safe containing gemstones (causing injuries to the looters in the process).
On 31 July, three Tigray people working at the Tana Beles sugar project, Amhara, were killed by unidentified armed men in an ""ethnic"" attack.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 31st July, Liyu Police killed two civilians in Mieso woreda (West Harerge zone).

column7: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: Agreement: On 31st July, the Oromo Liberation Front announced a temporary unilateral ceasefire with the government. On the same day, the leader of the Patriot Ginbot 7 rebel movement - Professor Berhanu Nega - announced that the leadership of the rebel group would be returning from exile following the recent decision by the Ethiopian government to remove the group (which is based in Eritrea) from a list of terrorist organisations.
Around August 1, police intercepted about 500 ammos for kalashnikov rifles hidden in a public bus en route between Goba town and Asosa towns (Benshangul-Gumaz).

Arrests: On 1st August, between 30 and 40 Ethiopian commandos were detained in Mekele (Tigray region). The circumstances surrouonding their mission - as well as the reason for their detention - are unclear, though preliminary information indicates the commandos were on a mission to arrest unspecified politicians on the orders of the executive, but were detained by the head of the TPLF party.
On 1st August, three children were killed by unexploded ordnance near Zela Ambesa (Tigray region), which was likely a relic of the 1998-2000 Ethiopian-Eritrean war.

Arrests: On 2nd August, 108 people were arrested in Benshangul-Gumaz region (coordinates for Assosa used). Those arrested were suspected of invovlement in the violence of late June, and included twenty police officers. There was no mention of the ethnicity of those arrested.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 3rd August, clashes broke out between the Ethiopian military and Liyu Police paramilitaries in Jijiga town (capital of the Somali region), amidst reports that government troops had been deployed to arrest local politicians, in a stand-off with Somali regional President Abdi Illey. The military occupied a number of key sites throughout the town. Over the next two days (August 4th and 5th), a group of youth calling themselves ""Heego"" (allegedly supporting controversial regional President Abdi Illey) reportedly burned down several churches and looted shops and banks. Some reports indicate that the Heego attacked non-Somalis, particularly Oromos, in the town. Over the three days of violence, 29 people were reported to have been killed, although precise times and details of the attackers and victims are currently lacking.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 3rd, Liyu Police killed two civilians in Mieso woreda (West Harerge zone), and wounded four others, before looting livestock.

column16: Oromiya Media Network; ESAT; Local Source; VOA
column17: On 3rd August, clashes broke out between the Ethiopian military and Liyu Police paramilitaries in Jijiga town (capital of the Somali region), amidst reports that government troops had been deployed to arrest local politicians, in a stand-off with Somali regional President Abdi Illey. The military occupied a number of key sites throughout the town. Over the next two days (August 4th and 5th), a group of youth calling themselves ""Heego"" (allegedly supporting controversial regional President Abdi Illey) reportedly burned down several churches and looted shops and banks. Some reports indicate that the Heego attacked non-Somalis, particularly Oromos, in the town. Over the three days of violence, 29 people were reported to have been killed, although precise times and details of the attackers and victims are currently lacking.
On 4 August, Ethiopian Somalis protested in Dire Dawa against the human rights violations by the regional government.
On 4 August, supporters of the Somali region's president protested against the deployment of federal troops to Jigjiga town.

column16: Local Source; Oromiya Media Network; VOA; ESAT
column17: On 3rd August, clashes broke out between the Ethiopian military and Liyu Police paramilitaries in Jijiga town (capital of the Somali region), amidst reports that government troops had been deployed to arrest local politicians, in a stand-off with Somali regional President Abdi Illey. The military occupied a number of key sites throughout the town. Over the next two days (August 4th and 5th), a group of youth calling themselves ""Heego"" (allegedly supporting controversial regional President Abdi Illey) reportedly burned down several churches and looted shops and banks. Some reports indicate that the Heego attacked non-Somalis, particularly Oromos, in the town. Over the three days of violence, 29 people were reported to have been killed, although precise times and details of the attackers and victims are currently lacking.
On August 5th, protesters gathered in Addis Ababa in response to the violence in Jijiga (capital of the Somali region), and concerns about the safety of their kin.

On or before August 5th, ten people were killed in Dire Dawa city, whilst an unspecified number were injured, and property destroyed in suspected riots. It was reported that violence involved members of the Somali and Oromo ethnic groups, but the idendity of the attackers and victims is unclear. A subsequent report has identified six of the deceased as being nationals of Djibouti.

Property destruction: Between 4th and 6th of August, members of the pro-Abdi Illey Heego Youth Movement destroyed property and burned churches in Jijiga (Somali region), and looted shops and banks. The Ethiopian government's Human Rights Commission was attacked and looted on August 8th. One report stated that the water supply of the town had been poisoned.

Agreement: On August 6th, the President of the Somali region - Abdi Illey - resigned, and was flown to Addis Ababa the following day, where he was placed in home custody of the federal army. Illey had been locked in a stand-off with the government over the controversial Liyu Police paramilitary force. Months of protests and violence also occurred in the Somali region against his leadership. On August 20, the Ethiopian Somali People's Democratic Party (the ruling party of the Somali region) elected Mustafe Muhumed Omar as the new regional governor of the Somali region, whilst three Executive and five Central Committee members resigned or were forced out of the party.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 6th, four civilians were killed by the Liyu Police and Heego Youth Movement forces in Jijiga town (Somali region). Sources indicate the victims were not of Somali ethnicity, although their precise ethnicity was not specified.

Agreement: On August 7th, representatives of the Ethiopian government and the OLF reached a peace agreement in Asmara, Eritrea, and formed a joint committee to observe the implentation of the agreement.

Looting: Between 4th and 6th of August, members of the pro-Abdi Illey Heego Youth Movement destroyed property and burned churches in Jijiga (Somali region), and looted shops and banks. The Ethiopian government's Human Rights Commission was attacked and looted on August 8th. One report stated that the water supply of the town had been poisoned.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 8th and 9th, Liyu Police paramilitaries clashed with Oromo fighters in Bati woreda (Amhara region). One Oromo was killed, on an unspecified date.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 8th, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Oromo police forces fought at an unspecified location on the Oromo-Somali border (coordinates for Chinakser woreda, East Harerge zone, used). One member of the Oromia police was killed in the clash.

On 8th August, residents of Jijiga (Somali region) reported sporadic clashes and shooting, though no specific group was mentioned. Looting was reported to be occurring, whilst residents warned of shortages in basic goods.

On August 9th, rival Muslim groups - the Al-Ahbash Islamic sect and a mainstream Muslim group - clashed over a dispute about the ownership of a mosque, and its finances. The event took place in Kombolcha (Debub Wollo zone, Amhara region), and resulted in 33 people being injured (11 of which were seriously injured). Police have arrested 10 suspects.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 8th and 9th, Liyu Police paramilitaries clashed with Oromo fighters in Bati woreda (Amhara region). One Oromo was killed, on an unspecified date.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or around August 9th, the director of Togochale woreda (Somali region) reported that the Liyu Police had attacked him and attempted to steal his vehicle. He was shot in the head, but the gunshot only grazed him.

Looting: On or around August 9th, an unknown group of youth attacked a camp in Togochale woreda (Somali region). They were reported to have looted the camp, stealing a fire engine, and wounded a number of civilians.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo civilians in Meyumuluke woreda (East Harerge zone), killing two civilians and wounding three others.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police assaulted nine villages in Babile woreda (East Harerge zone), killing 23 Oromo civilians and displacing over 50,000 people. The Liyu Police were reported to have taken control of the following villages: Barkale, Darera Arba, Gammachu, Lakulle, Sheik Hussen, Sheik Abdulkadir, Tula, Tulu Huro, and parts of Erar. 23 fatalities spread across 8 events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police assaulted nine villages in Babile woreda (East Harerge zone), killing 23 Oromo civilians and displacing over 50,000 people. On August 10th, clashes between Oromo and Gedeo fighters occurred at an unspecified location in West Guji zone (coordinates for zonal capital of Negele used). The clashes were reported to have displaced many Oromo civilians.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked Oromo civilians in Bati woreda (Amhara region), wounding many.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police assaulted nine villages in Babile woreda (East Harerge zone), killing 23 Oromo civilians and displacing over 50,000 people. The Liyu Police were reported to have taken control of the following villages: Barkale, Darera Arba, Gammachu, Lakulle, Sheik Hussen, Sheik Abdulkadir, Tula, Tulu Huro, and parts of Erar. 23 fatalities spread across 8 events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 10th, Liyu Police assaulted nine villages in Babile woreda (East Harerge zone), killing 23 Oromo civilians and displacing over 50,000 people. The Liyu Police were reported to have taken control of the following villages: Barkale, Darera Arba, Gammachu, Lakulle, Sheik Hussen, Sheik Abdulkadir, Tula, Tulu Huro, and parts of Erar. 23 fatalities spread across 8 events.
On August 11th, two civilians were killed after an unidentified armed group stopped their car and attacked them. The event occurred at an unspecified location in East Wellega zone.
On August 12th, the Ogaden National Liberation Front announced a unilateral ceasefire, and its desire to enter peace talks with the Ethiopian government.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column16: Local Source; Oromiya Media Network; Addis Standard; Reuters
column17: On 12th and 13th August, sources report that Liyu Police attacked three unspecified locations in Meyumuluke woreda (East Harerge zone) over two days. These attacks resulted in the deaths of 37 Oromo civilians, whilst 44 were wounded (including four Oromo police, event coded separately below). 37 fatalities spread across two events.

On August 12th, a lynch-mob attacked a civilian and allegedly set him on fire, before torching his vehicle, following false rumours that he was planning to bomb a large rally in Shashamane (West Arsi zone) where known activist Jawar Mohammad was speaking at. The victim later died of his injuries. Several suspects have been arrested.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column16: Oromiya Media Network; Reuters; Addis Standard; Local Source
column17: On 12th and 13th August, sources report that Liyu Police attacked three unspecified locations in Meyumuluke woreda (East Harerge zone) over two days. These attacks resulted in the deaths of 37 Oromo civilians, whilst 44 were wounded (including four Oromo police, event coded separately below). 37 fatalities spread across two events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before August 13th, four members of the Oromo riot police were wounded in clashes with Liyu Police paramilitaries, in Meyumuluke woreda (East Harerge zone). The incident occurred amidst attacks by the Liyu Police against Oromo civilians in the woreda.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 14th, 30 Oromo civilians were killed by Liyu Police paramilitaries at Meyumuluke woreda (East Harerge zone).

Weapons seizure: On or before August 14th, government forces seized approximately 425 explosive devices in Tigray (coordinates for regional capital of Mekele used) underneath a bridge at an unspecified location.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 15th, Liyu Police paramilitaries (reportedly from the Afar region) attacked Oromo civilians at Bati woreda (Amhara region). One civilian was killed, and another wounded. 42 livestock were stolen by the Liyu Police.
15 August, on or about. Three people were killed in an attack by suspected indigenous Shekachos in Tepi town. A similar attack occurred two weeks later.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 16th, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed and wounded an unspecified number of Oromo civilians at Chinaksen woreda (East Harerge zone). Unknown fatalities and wounded.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On August 16th, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed an Oromo civilian in Mieso woreda (East Harerge zone).
On August 16th, protestors from the town of Tepi gathered in Addis Ababa to demonstrate against alleged abuses of power by the Tepi authorities.
Around August 16, in Addis Ababa city (Addis Ababa, Addis Ababa), federal police intercepted over 1,000 pistols and about 4,000 munitions hidden by unidentified actors in the tanker of a fuel truck.
Agreement: On August 17th, the Amhara Democratic Forces Movement signed a reconcilliation agreement with the regional government of Amhara. The agreement was reached in Asmara, Eritrea.

Arrests: On and before August 22nd, around 500 people were arrested in the Oromia region on suspicion of involvement in various illegal acts (including murder, land occupation, and arson). At present, there is no information as to the ethnicity of those arrested.

Arrests: On August 22nd, approx. 300 people were arrested by police in the SSNP region (coordinates for regional capital of Hawasa used). The arrests were in response to unrest and deadly riots in June, involving the Sidama and Wolaita ethnic groups.
25 August. Youths in Birrsheleko, Western Gojjam, Amahra region protested over lack of benefits from the large farmlands in the area.
26-27 August. Violent clashes between Oromo and Somali youths in Dire Dawa over two days.
Agreement: 26 August. Gumuz and Amhara communities in Benishangul Gumuz region resolved their conflict after mediation in Loijignafo Woreda. Clashes occurred between the two earlier in the year.
27 August. Taxi drivers in Addis Abeba demonstrated outside Fana Broadcasting opposing the new Zonal allocation system.

column8: ESPDP: Ethiopian Somali People's Democratic Party
column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Arrests: 27 August. The former regional president of the Somali region in Ethiopia, Abdi Mohamed Omer, commonly known as Abdi Illey has been arrested, a day after the state stripped him of immunity, along with six other officials in Addid Abeba. Three days later, the Police Commissioner of Somali region was arrested in Jigjiga on suspicion of leading the Hego youth militia and involvement in the recent chaos in the region.
26-27 August. Violent clashes between Oromo and Somali youths in Dire Dawa over two days.
Around 28 August. Reports that Oromo militias killed at least 9 Somali civilians in Baabile & Tulli Guled. Unclear date. 9 fatalities spread over the two locations.

On August 28, in Asmara city (Aneba, Eritrea), the Chairman of TPDM and the Director of the Ethiopian National Intelligence and Security Agency reached the agreement to for TPDM to continue its struggle through peaceful means. Coded location as Addis Ababa and set GP to 3.
Around 28 August. Reports that Oromo militias killed at least 9 Somali civilians in Baabile & Tulli Guled. Unclear date. 9 fatalities spread over the two locations.
28 August. Protests were held in Jigjiga as bodies of Somali civilians killed in Baabile & Tulli Guled arrived at the hospital.
28 August. Two people were killed in a renewed attack by suspected indigenous Shekachos in Tepi town, SNNPR.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before 29 August. 4 people were killed and 3 were wounded by Liyu police in Sheik hussen and Gamachis villages in Babile woreda, east Hararge zone. Federal police arrested 35 people who came to kill the people on the border.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before 29 August. In east Hararge zone, Gumbi woreda (close to Kumbi), Liyu police killed two people and wounded six people including an off-duty Oromia police officer.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before 30 August. In East Hararge zone, Mayu Muluke woreda, Liyu police wounded 5 people.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Looting: 30 August. In Wollo zone, Bati woreda, Liyu police stole more than 100 cattle.

30 August. Supporters of former governor of the Ethiopian Somali Regional State are holding protests in the region's headquarters, Jigjiga town, demanding the release of Abdi Mahamud Omar (Abdi Iley).
Change to armed group: 30 August. OLF and Oromo Federalist Congress deal to form an alliance in Addis Abeba today.

Arrests: On or before 31 August. The crime prevention unit of the capital's police said it has arrested 108 people that it said have been involved in looting private and public properties as well as in the illegal movement of hard currencies in Addis Ababa. Police have also seized weapons and motor bikes that the suspects allegedly used in the crime, according a report by the etv.
31 August. Residents of Telemt Woreda, North Gonder demonstrated calling for good governance and economic development issues to be resolved.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before 31 August. In east Hararge zone, Meta woreda, Liyu police wounded two people.

column8: SEPDM: Southern Ethiopian Peoples Democratic Movement
column17: Arrests: On or before 31 August. Mayor of Awasa city and more than 100 people have been arrested and charged in the Federal High Court for alleged roles in the recent chaos in the region.

01-02 September. In Dawa Chefe Woreda of Oromo Zone, Amhara region clashes between suspected Amhara police and people claimed lives. The violence is said to be the improper use of local investment lands. Unknown fatalities estimated at 3 - spread over the two days of violence.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On or before 01 September. In east Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, Somali region Liyu police killed 2 people and wounded one person.

column6: AGUDM: Patriotic Ginbot 7 for Unity and Democratic Movement
column17: 01 September. Thousands of PG7 fighters returned to Ethiopia through the Humera border after their military base in Eritrea was closed. A week later, TPDF fighters also began returning from Eritrea to Ethiopia. The moves follow recent peace and demobilisation and reintegration deals between various rebel groups and the government (including PG7, ADFM, ONLF and OLF).

01-02 September. In Dawa Chefe Woreda of Oromo Zone, Amhara region clashes between suspected Amhara police and people claimed lives. The violence is said to be the improper use of local investment lands. Unknown fatalities estimated at 3 - spread over the two days of violence.
On or before 02 September. In west Wellaga, Mana Sibo woreda, a young girl from Oromo tribe was killed by an alleged member of the Barta tribe. This led to protests.
On or before 02 September. In west Wellaga, Mana Sibo woreda, large number of people demonstrated following the death of a young girl from Oromo tribe. She was killed by someone from Barta tribe.
02 September. Riots in Alaba, Southern Ethiopia caused the destruction of properties and injured several people.
Around 02 September. Two killed and thousands displaced in Raya by Tigray Liyu Hail (special force) in suspected violence.

On or before 02 September. At least 4 Somalis of the Gare clan killed in Moyale. Moyale has consistently been hit with inter ethnic conflict and border dispute between the Borana Oromo Qero and Somali residents of the area.
On or before 03 September. At least 10 members of the Oromo community have been killed in a clash in Delti City of Assosa Zone.
On or before 03 September. Residents of Sheka, Tepi protested outside the Zonal city over recent clashes. They have asked for change of the local government.
04 September. People in Gondar under the name of ""Qemant's Identity Question coordinating committee members"" protested to call for the release of detained members.
05 August. Amhara people protested at the door of ETV/EBC in Adiss Abeba against land expropriation and persecution in Raya.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 9 June, Liyu Police officers returned to the three localities they attacked the day before and continued their attacks as well as attacking two more - Darbiga and Gololcha - killing seven people and wounding 17.

On or before 07 September. At least one National Movement of Amhara (NaMA) member killed and scores arrested by government securities in unclear circumstances. NaMA is a pro-Amhara political movement formed in June 2018.
Arrests: on or before 07 September. Police arrested over 400 National Movement of Amhara (NaMA) members in unclear circumstances in Jema. NaMA is a pro-Amhara political movement formed in June 2018.
On or before 11 September. Youth from Region 5 (Somali Region of Ethiopia) clashed with Oromo youths in Moyale.

Movement of forces: 11 September. Prime Minister Dr Abiy Ahmed said Ethiopian and Eritrean troops will begin to withdraw from border areas today. They officially opened the Debay Sima-Burre and Serha-Zalambesa border points between the two countries for road transport connectivity.

Movement of forces: 11 September. Prime Minister Dr Abiy Ahmed said Ethiopian and Eritrean troops will begin to withdraw from border areas today. They officially opened the Debay Sima-Burre and Serha-Zalambesa border points between the two countries for road transport connectivity.
11 September. A young man was killed in Moyale town by a member of the Defence Force. The shooting occurred when securities tried to queel a fight between Somali and Oromo communities.

12 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in Merkato, Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.

12 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.
13 September. Violent clashes between Meskan (Gurage) and Amhara groups in Inseno city of Gurage Zone. No reported fatalities.

13 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in the Addisu Michael area of Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.
13 September. Violent clashes between Meskan (Gurage) and Amhara groups in Inseno city of Gurage Zone has continued for a second day.
On or before: 13 September. In Amhara region, Wollo zone, Harxume furse woreda, federal police killed two people.

13 September. Police clash with local youth in the Kolfe area of Addis Ababa. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.

13 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in the Lege Tafo area of Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.
13 September. At least 7 Amahara people were reportedly killed in Benishangul by Gumz militia.
13 September. Riots followed the killing of the seven Amhara people in Guba Woreda, Benishangul region.

13 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in the Addisu Gebeya area of Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash.  23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.
13 September. Youths fight over hanging of the opposition Oromo Liberation Front (OLF's) flag in the Asko area of Addis Abeba. Federal Police force intervened to prevent further clash.

13 September. There are reports of unrest in Piazza and near Karl Square in Addis Ababa. British Embassy staff have been advised to restrict movement in these areas where possible. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.

13 September. There are reports of unrest in Piazza and near Karl Square in Addis Ababa. British Embassy staff have been advised to restrict movement in these areas where possible. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.

14 September. A young man has reportedly been killed in Addis Abeba near Kolfe on the second day of the clashes. 23 people were killed in unrest in Addis Ababa between September 12-14th and over 2,500 youths arrested. Fatalities spread over 9 events.

Displacement: 14 September. Dorze ethnic members are reportedly being displaced from Ketta and Burayu, in Oromia special zone in the outskirt of Finfinne. The displaced residents are staying in a church.
14 September. Residents of Maji-bero in Bench Maji Zone hold a protest accusing the government of neglect and unresponsiveness to their questions.

Displacement: 14 September. Dorze ethnic members are reportedly being displaced from Ketta and Burayu, in Oromia special zone in the outskirt of Finfinne. The displaced residents are staying in a church.
14 September. Reuters TV journalist and cameraman were attacked in Addis Ababa while reporting a conflict. Their cameras smashed and confiscated by same youth group.

column9: Gamo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Gurage Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: 16 September. Armed Oromo youths have attacked members of the Gamo and Gurage ethnic groups in Burayu, Sebeta, Ashewa Meda (near Holeta), Holeta and Keta leaving at least 23 dead and hundreds displaced. Fatalities spread over four locations. Amnesty International places the number at 58.
On or before 16 September. Violent clashes between Meskan and Amerko Communities in Inseno city of Gurage Zone left 16 people dead.

column9: Gamo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Gurage Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: 16 September. Armed Oromo youths have attacked members of the Gamo and Gurage ethnic groups in Burayu, Sebeta, Ashewa Meda (near Holeta), Holeta and Keta leaving at least 23 dead and hundreds displaced. Fatalities spread over four locations. Amnesty International places the number at 58.

16 September. At least 18 Amhara people have been killed in a coordinated attack by alleged Qerro and OLF members in Chinaksen.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Thousands of people protested in Armba Minch city condemning the attacks against Gamo people in Burayu. The protest turned violent and police assaulted several protesters, some with life threatening injuries.
17 September. At least one person was reportedly killed when Oromo youth attempted to attack local residents in Jomo but it was quashed as security forces intervened early.
17 September. A protest in Alamata about the identity question of Raya people (a subgroup of the Oromo) was met by force from the local security forces. Several protesters were injured.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.
17 September. The Oromia Regional Government has said that it has arrested over 200 people, who are prime suspects of executing the targeted ethnic attacks in Burayu.

18 September. Scores of Amhara people displaced from the Somali region of Ethiopia held a protest in Bahir Dar asking the government to support them. Several protesters were attacked by the Region's police.
17 September. Residents of Burayu from the Oromo community held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in Burayu by Oromo youths.
23 September. A protest condemning anti-change forces and supporting Oromo Democratic Party was held in Adama.
23 September. People protested in Gambella city. Protesters claimed Gambella has been neglected when changes were taking place in the other parts of the country.
23 September. Reports of riots by youth during the reception and welcoming ceremony for the ONLF leaders in Jigjiga. The Somali regional government deployed anti-riot forces.
23 September. Riots occurred in the Addis Abeba shelters as police forcefully repatriated people displaced from Burayu the week before due to targeted ethnic attacks.
24 September. The day after protests demanding change and reforms in Gambella, four people were killed, 16 more wounded by national security forces in Gambella city.
25 September. In Gimbi, car carrying 4 Kemashi Zone officials and passengers from Benishangul region was ambushed by unidentified armed men. The four officials died.
28 September. Clashes between Gumuz and Oromo militias in Kemashi Zone resulted ileft at least 10 people dead. Around 10,000 have fled to Gimbi town so far.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: 01 October. Heavy fighting broke out between Oromia region police and Gumuz militia. At least seven police officers from the Oromia region were killed near the border town of Gimbi.

01-02 October. Clashes between Gumuz and Oromo militia in Kemashi after the killing of four Kemashi officials by Oromo militias a few day before left at least 40 killed. Scores arrested. Fatalities spread over the two days of violence.

01 October. A fight between two individuals in Melka Jebdu, Dire Dawa escalated into an ethnic clash between two unidentified groups. This has left two people dead. Police has also arrested scores of people.
02 October. People in Afar region protested against officials involved as salt traders, taking control of one of the salt production areas.

On or before 02 October. Hundreds of people were arrested in Welkait after the Tigray regional government started forcing them to join seven centers of military training. Hundreds of people fled to Dansha and Abdrafi.

01-02 October. Clashes between Gumuz and Oromo militia in Kemashi after the killing of four Kemashi officials by Oromo militias a few day before left at least 40 killed. Scores arrested. Fatalities spread over the two days of violence.
02 October. An unidentified communal armed group killed at least 11 people in the Batara district of Kaffa Zone.
04 October. An unidentified policeman scuffled with other police officers in Bole costing the lives of four federal police officers, including his.
On or before 04 October. Clashes in the border areas of Northern Shoa and Oromo region led to the displacement of people to Minjar area.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 10 June, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked five more localities in the Chinaksen district - Geellaa, Hosale, Usweyne, Tiiro and Marar - killing four people and wounding another four.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 10 June, Liyu Police paramilitaries attacked five more localities in the Chinaksen district - Geellaa, Hosale, Usweyne, Tiiro and Marar - killing four people and wounding another four.
07 October. Protesters took to the streets in Gambella to condemn the violence end September and call on the government to take action.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: 07 October. Tigray Special force were deployed to Raya following identity protests a few weeks prior.
07 October. The Oromo Liberation Front has said that its members are being arrested in Addis Abeba and Oromia regions.
07 October. Residents of Lalibela held a peaceful demonstration urging the government to save ancient churches in the town.
08 October. Unknown number of people were killed in the clash between a group of young men and security forces in the West Welega zone, Boji woreda.
08 October. In Bale zone, Golocha woreda, five people were killed in clashes between people and security forces.
08 October. Clashes between Somali and Oromo ethnic groups in Chiaksen took the life of one person.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: 08 October. Police arrested several Gambella Youth Leaders.

09 October. More than 2,000 fighters of the Tigray People's Democratic Movement (TPDM) arrived at Zela ambesa, Ethiopia from Eritrea. TPDM reached an agreement with the government of Ethiopia to engage in a peaceful political activity.
09 October. An unknown group has attacked and burned down shops in Hawasa Market.
10 October. Several hundred soldiers marched on the prime minister's office to demand pay rises. The PM met with them. Several arrested in the next days.
Around October 11, in Tepi district (Sheka, Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples), ethnic Gumuz and Oromo clashed, leaving six people killed.
On or before 12 October: OLF forces in Kelem Wellega, Western Wellega reportedly attacked business people and forced government militias to disarm.
12 October. Teachers in Takusa, Western Gonder staged protests due to disagreements with the local City Council over housing projects.
12 October. Residents of Agaro took to the streets calling for the removal of the City's officials. A person was killed when members of the Defence forces fired at the protesters.
12 October. Scores of people held a demonstration in Ambo against the abusing and insulting of mothers and women.
13-14 October. Ethiopian Defense Forces fought against OLF forces in Western Wellega. Coded as two events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: 13-14 October. Tigray Liyu police killed at least 4 people in two days as the Raya people protested being administered in Tigray Region. Unclear if victims were physically protesting. Fatalities spread across two events.
14 October. Protest held in Asaita in Afar, opposing the regional government's abuse of power and calling for protest in 32 districts of Afar in the coming week.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 14 October. Police apprehended 51 people who were training and preparing to attack people in Benshangul region. Sources claims they might be related to the ONLA.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: 14 October. Tigray special force (Liyu Hail) deployed in Dansha to oppress local voices planning to seek respect for their Amhara identity.
13-14 October. Ethiopian Defense Forces fought against OLF forces in Western Wellega. Coded as two events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: 13-14 October. Tigray Liyu police killed at least 4 people in two days as the Raya people protested being administered in Tigray Region. Unclear if victims were physically protesting. Fatalities spread across two events.
On or before 17 October. Three members of the Ethiopian Defense were killed by alleged OLF soldiers in Amaro. The government army was intervening to stop the attack on civilians.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Afar Special Forces
column17: 17 October. The Afar special forces has attacked protesters in Afar region, Ethiopia. Protesters were demanding changes in governance and administrators of the region.
18 October. 1400 youths of Addis Abeba, who have been detained in Tolay Detention Center for one month, have been released. They were detained following protests in Addis Abeba last month.
18 October. Oromo affiliated militia killed five Somali people travelling by bus around Harar City.
18 October. A member of Federal police was shot dead by unidentified person on the border between Kemashi zone and East Welega zone.

column7: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On October 19, an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz killed two security forces (an Oromia police and a federal police) who were helping displaced people in Sasiga woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia).

On October 20, in Oda Buldigilu woreda (Asosa, Benshangul-Gumaz), an unidentified armed group attacked ethnic Oromo people for unknown reasons. An unknown number of people were killed and many properties were damaged.
20 October. Six dead in the Kemashi Zone after an unidentified group attacked residents. The government has deployed the military. Thousands of people have been displaced.
On October 20, 2018, in Gonder city (Semen Gondar, Amhara), police seized 999 handguns and 30 Kalashnikov rifles smuggled in from Sudan.
On October 21st, in Asmara city (Anseba, Eritrea), the Ethiopian government signed a peace agreement with the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: On October 21, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), Tigray Regional State Special Force fired gunshots at Amhara activists protesting against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators. Tigray security forces killed 6 protestors and injured more than 20.
On October 22, in Fiche town (North Shewa, Oromia), people staged a demonstration against the malfunction of the city administration.
""One male national UN contracted driver was shot and seriously wounded while distributing food in an IDP camp in Chinaksen.""

On October 24, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), Amhara ethnic group activists continued to stage demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Tigray State Police
column17: Over October 21-24, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), police have arrested over 200 Amhara ethnic group activists accused of participating in fatal protests in the town over the previous days.

On October 25, in Awaday woreda (East Hararghe, Oromia), people staged a demonstration demanding the release of several young men who were arrested last year. Security forces started shooting at the people.
On October 25, in different parts of Afar region, people staged demonstrations protested against the failure of federal reforms to be brought down to the regional level.

On October 25, at Nechisar National Park near Arba Minch city (Gamo Gofa, Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples), unidentified gunmen killed four people who were foraging for wood in a wildlife park.

On October 25, in Mohny town (Amhara, coded as north Welo prec2), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On October 25, in Kobo town (Semien Wollo, Ethiopia), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On October 25, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), Amhara ethnic group activists continued to stage demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On October 26, near Haro Limu woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group burned down 600 houses and damaged properties of the Oromo people.

On October 26, in Nekemt city (Oromia, Misraq Wellega), people staged demonstrations demanding attention of the government on the displacement of the Oromo people from on the border of Benishangul Gumuz region.

On October 27, in Nekemt city (Oromia, Misraq Wellega), people staged demonstrations demanding justice for attacks in Benishangul Gumuz State, asking the government take legal measures against forces who killed at least 50 people.

On October 28, in Semera town (Afar Zone 1, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights. People were lightly injured when security forces used tear gas and sticks to disperse demonstrators.
On or around October 28, in Erebti woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights.
On or around October 28, in Dallol woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights.

On October 28, in Berahle town (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights. People were lightly injured when security forces used tear gas and sticks to disperse demonstrators.
On October 28, in Gonder town (Semen Gondar, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Debre Tabor town (Debub Gondar, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Metema woreda (Semen Gondar, Amhara), several illegal weapons were found (assumed by police) in a semi-truck that tipped over on the highway.
On October 28, in Bahir Dar town (Bahir Dar Special Zone, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Dessie town (Debub Wollo, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Weldiya town (Semen Wello, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Debre Berhan town (North Shewa, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On October 28, in Gidami locality (Kelem Wellega, Oromia), OLF militiamen and Ethiopian Defense forces exchanged gunfire.
On October 29, somewhere in Misraq Wellega (Oromia), an unidentified armed group crossed the border between Oromia region and Benishangul Gumuz region and attacked people.
On October 29, in Gidami locality (Kelem Wellega, Oromia), OLF militiamen and Ethiopian Defense forces exchanged gunfire for the second day.

On October 29, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On October 30, in Chinaksen woreda (Misraq Harerge, Oromia), Somale Liyu police attacked farmers while they were working on their farm, wounding several people.
On October 30, in Doba woreda (Mirab Hararghe, Oromia), an unidentified armed group killed one person and wounded two.

On October 30, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the second day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On October 31, in Jijiga town (Fafan, Somali), Amharas and Somalis ethnic groups clashed over rhetoric from politicians from the Ethiopian Somali region, leaving three people dead and three wounded. The army was deployed following the clashes.
On October 31, in Gambella town (Agnuak, Gambela Peoples), unidentified armed actors threw grenades into a crowded market for unknown reasons, killing three people and injuring two others.

On October 31, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the third day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On November 1, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the fourth day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On November 2, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the fifth day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On November 3, in Dire Sawa city (Dire Dawa, Dire Dawa), gunmen beat members of the Oromo community for unknown reasons, leaving them injured.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On November 4, in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz crossed the border and attacked police and members of the Oromia ethnic group. Two Oromia regional police were killed in the attack.
On November 5, in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz attacked Oromo people and burned down houses.
On November 6, in Debark district (Semen Gondar, Amhara), four people were killed and two others seriously injured when a grenade exploded in a house. The perpetrators were unidentified.
On November 6, in Ambo town (Mirab Shewa, Oromia), people staged a protest demanding that the government take action on an armed group that has been killing and displacing people.
On November 6, in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz attacked Oromo people and burned down houses.

On November 6, in Gonder zone (Amhara), an unidentified armed group attacked a group of Qemant (Agaw) people. Several people were killed, and several others were injured. Properties have also been damaged. Number of people killed not specified; coded 10.
Assumed on November 6, in Nekemt city (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), police fired on protestors, killing three activists.

On November 7, in Haro Limu woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz attacked Oromo people and burned down houses. Over 50 houses burned down as of this day.

On November 7, in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), an unidentified armed group from Benishangul Gumuz attacked Oromo people and burned down houses. Over 50 houses burned down as of this day.
On November 7, in Dessie city (Debub Wollo, Amhara), several people staged a protest demanding that suspected killer of a young girl be killed following the girl's death.
On November 7, in Semen Gondar zone (Amhara), an unidentified armed group continued its attack on a group of Qemant (Agaw) people. Properties were also damaged.
On November 7, in Afar region, several people staged a protest demanding reforms over an unknown issue.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On November 8, somewhere on the border of the Oromia and Somali regions, police uncovered a mass grave of 200 people where the bodies are presumed to be related to a series of ethnic clashes carried out in August by the Liyu who were loyal to the former Somali region leader.
On November 8, in Babile woreda (Misraq Harerge, Oromia), Somali ethnic militia killed four farmers for unknown reasons.
On November 8, in Semen Gondar (Gonder, Amhara), Abiy Ahmed's government let go over 160 army generals and commanders of the army in a military reform.
On November 10, in Awash town (Afar Zone 3, Afar), people staged a protest demanding to reform Chinese foreign investment into the country.

Assumed on November 10, in Addis Ababa city, police arrested 40 officials of the military industrial complex, Metals and Engineering Corporation (METEC) - run by TPLF army generals - and members of the Ethiopian security and intelligence on charges of corruption.
On November 10, in Abala town in Abala woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged a protest demanding to reform Chinese foreign investment into the country.

On November 11, in Qelaf village in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), unknown Armed Group from Benishangul Gumuz region continued attacking, displacing, and burning the houses of the people. Injuries and fatalities were not reported.

column6: EPRDF: Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Democratic Front
column17: On November 13, in Addis Ababa city (Addis Ababa, Ababa), the Amhara Democratic Party, ADP (EPRDF) merged with a former rebel group, the Amhara Democratic Forces Movement (ADFM), in order to address the grievances of the Amhara people and to ensure their interests.
On November 14, in Moyale woreda (Borena, Oromia), ethnic conflict between armed Somali and Oromo groups continued. Twelve people were killed and 17 others were wounded.
On or around November 16, Amharas and Tigrayans clashed in Amhara region.
Assumed on November 16, in Jima city (Jimma, Oromia), 50 farmers complained that the government had taken their farms and they had not been compensated for it.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On November 17, in Guto Gida woreda (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), armed men from Benishangul Gumuz killed two Oromia police members.
On November 18, in Dire Dawa city (Dire Dawa, Dire Dawa), a group of organized Somale youth killed one and wounded several Oromo people. They also burned two houses.
On November 19, in Jijiga city (Fafan, Somali), Somale militia staged an organized attack on the Oromo ethnic group. The Jijiga city police have arrested 25.

On November 19, in Addis Ababa city (Addis Ababa, Addis Ababa), hundreds of Ethiopian Jews staged a demonstration to protest the Israeli government's decision not to allow all of them to emigrate to Israel, leaving their families divided between the two countries.
On November 20, in Addis Ababa city (Addis Ababa, Addis Ababa), Oromo Liberation Front (OLF) opened a new office in the city.
On November 20, in Babile woreda (Misraq Harerge, Oromia), an armed Somale group attacked Oromia people, killing three.

column9: Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: On November 20, in the Tigray region, 65 Oromo and Amhara ethnic group members of the national defense force are being imprisoned in Tigray region. Which police force arrested the soldiers was not specified, and the soldiers were arrested without the knowledge of the federal government.

On November 21, in Asosa city (Asosa, Benshangul-Gumaz), two students in Asosa University engaged in conflict that later evolved into armed rival tribal conflict. Three students were killed and 34 wounded.

On November 21, in Ethiopia, Ogaden Liberation Front soldiers returned back to Ethiopia after the peaceful agreement between Ethiopian Government and ONLF. GP 3 and location coded as Addis Ababa because specific location was not mentioned.

On November 21, in Debre Berhan city, security forces seized a shipment of illegal weapons as an unidentified group was trying to transport them to the other cities. The weapons came into the country though Gambella city.
On November 22, in Babile woreda (Misraq Harerge, Oromia), an armed Somale group continued its attacks on Oromia people. Number of injuries and deaths not reported.
On November 22, in Oromia region, an armed group from Benishangul Gumuz attacked Oromia people. GP 3 because the exact location not mentioned.
On November 22, in Dire Dawa city (Dire Dawa, Dire Dawa), Somale youth militia continued their organized attacks on the Oromo ethnic group. The number of deaths and injuries were not reported.

24 November 2018: People in Himora town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by Tigray regional president against PM Abiy and against identity issues raised b minorities in the Wolkait and Alamata areas.

24 November 2018: People of Alamata town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by the Tigray regional president. The press release accuses the prime minister Abiy for targeting only Tigrayans when arresting corruption suspects.

24 November 2018: People in Adwa town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by Tigray regional president against PM Abiy and against identity issues raised b minorities in the Wolkait and Alamata areas.
27 November 2018: Ambo University students protested against some individuals seeking to cause conflict among students from different tribes

28 November 2018: ODP, former OPDO, signed an agreement with Oromo Democratic Front (ODF), the leading Oromo opposition party, to eventually merge as one. ODP is a member of EPDRF, a ruling party whose bylaws does not allow its members to sign any kind of unity with other members. Some say that ODP is openly challenging EPDRF.
28 November 2018: People protested against the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz.

20 December:Two soldiers and a driver were killed by armed men who were suspected to be OLF forces. The soldiers were escorting two trucks belonging to the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia when they were attacked.

02 January (on or around): In Tigray region, Zela Ambesa residents blocked a convoy of soldiers withdrawing from the Zalambessa front. Ethiopian and Eritrean soldiers are withdrawing from border areas after a peace agreement improved relations between the two countries. Residents are asking for the trucks and weapons to stay in the area.

08 January: In Afar region , Argobba special woreda residents protested against the Argobba people's Democratic Party.

22-24 January: In Dire Dawa city, protests escalated following the targeting of a procession the day before. The protesters called for equal rights for job and other opportunities. They blocked the road by burning tyres and setting offices ablaze, and clashed with security forces. At least one person was reported killed in unclear circumstances and dozens of others wounded. Police arrested 84.
