06 April: In Afar region, Gewane, hundreds of youths held a demonstration demanding the arrest of the soldier who killed a civilian days earlier. [size=hundreds]
06 April: In Amhara region, Oromia zone, Kemise woreda, OLF fighters clashed with Amhara ethnic militia leaving at least 6 people killed and mosques and properties destroyed.
08 April: In Amhra region, Oromia zone, Ataye woreda, two Oromo people killed in the continued fight between Oromo and Amhara ethnic militia.
09 April: In Hawasa city, thousands of Sidama women demonstrated over the delayed Sidama regional referendum (over Sidama becoming a region). [Size=thousands]
10 April: In West Hararghe zone, Chiro town, Oromo people demonstrated over the attack on Oromo people in Amhara region. [Size=no report]
10 Apri: In Illubabor zone, Metu town, Oromo people held demonstration over the attack on Oromo people in Amhara region. [Size=no report]
12 April: Police arrested 59 head of government agencies and investors on suspecion of corruption.
14 April: Rioters injured police by throwing stones at them in Dire Dawa. The situation escalated when a police tried to arrest one of their friend. [Size=no report]
16 April: In Amhara region, north Wolo zone youths held demonstration complaining that they have not been benefiting from the Opal mine in the region. [Size=no report]
16 April: In West Hararghe zone, Chiro town people held demonstration after OLF soldiers in the training camp were reported to have been poisoned. [Size=no report]
16 April: In South west Shewa zone, Waliso town people held demonstration after OLF soldiers in the military training camp were reported to have been poisoned. [Size=no report]
17 April: Medical students demonstrated over their practice intern schedule and how it has been affecting their performance. Police intervened, leaving some injured. [Size=no report]
17 April: Military forces deployed in west Wellega zone killed a civilian. Reasons not known

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Afar Special Forces
column17: 19 April: People protested in Afar over lack of good governance at the regional level in Afar. Police arrested more than 100 demonstrators. [Size=over 100]
19 April: police seized 52 kalashnikov rifles and 10 Kilograms of illegal drugs in Gambella.

22 April: Tikur Anbesa specialized hospital and St. Paul General specialized hospital medical interns and students held demonstration against mistreatment, long working hours and low salary. [Size=No report]
22 April: Medical interns and students held demonstration against mistreatment, Long working hours and low salary in Gonder, Amhara region. [Size=No report]
23 April: In Gurage Zone, SNNP region, Masken ethnic group held demonstration against the newly created east Meskan woreda. They do not want to be part of the newly created woreda. [Size=No report]
25 April: Six members of unidentified armed group killed in the clash between Ethipian police and unidentified armed group in Gambella.

26 April: Several people killed in the fight between Gumuz ethnic militia and Amhara ethnic militia in Benishangul Gumuz region. At least 18 people mainly Amharas killed in the clash. The clash started between the truck driver (Amhara) and a local customer. The driver called a federal police who came and seriously injured the local customer. The Gumuz ethnic militias started attacking Amhara people in the region in revenge of that
26 April: Hospital and clinic employees held demonstration over salary raise, hospital safety and other issues in Bahir Dar, Amhara region. [Size=No report]

29 April: Dozens of civilians shot dead in the ethnic clashes between Amhara and Gumuz ethnic militias. According the report, attack started by Amhara ethnic militias in retaliation for earlier violence in Gumuz region. Fatalities coded as 12.
30 April: The Walta Police soccer team was attacked by unidentified armed group in Gewane, Afar region, while traveling on a bus. One killed and 5 wounded in the attack.
01 May: A military commander killed in the fight between OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (splinters) Soldiers in Shambu, east Welega zone, Oromia region.
02 May: In Amhara region, Bahir Dar city people held demonstration demanding the government to stop the killing and displacement of Amhara people in different places. [Size=Not reported]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 02 May: Liyu forces killed 11 pastoralists in the Miesso and Afdem districts. Fatalities spread between two events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 02 May: Liyu forces killed 11 pastoralists in the Miesso and Afdem districts. Fatalities spread between two events.

02 May: An Amhara ethnic militia attacked Gumuz civilians in Awi zone, Amhara region in retaliation for violence in the Benishangul Gumuz region days earlier. 'Several dozens' of people were killed in the attack, some sources indicate as many as 200 people may have been killed. Fatalities recorded with conservative estimate of 36.

03 May: An Amhara ethnic militia attacked Gumuz civilians in Awi zone, Amhara region in retaliation for violence in the Benishangul Gumuz region days earlier. 'Several dozens' of people were killed in the attack, some sources indicate as many as 200 people may have been killed. Fatalities recorded with conservative estimate of 36.

08 May: One civilian died in the violent demonstration by a group of youths who claimed to represent christian community. The demonstration started when a group of men started fencing the plot of land that the rioters claimed to be public's land.[size=not reported]
08 may: In Amhara region, Weldiya town people held demonstration asking the regional government to protect Amhara people in different regions from being dispalced. [Size=not reported]
08 May : In Bahir Dar town, Amhara region, the youths held demonstration asking the ADP, Amhara Democratic Party to keep their words. [size=not reported]

14 May: In Afar region, Aysaita woreda youths held demonstrations against the movement of military forces in the region for other purposes while the people are being attacked by ethnic militias. They blocked the higheway and prevented the militaries from passing through. [Size=no report]

16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals. [Size=no report]

16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals. [Size=no report]

16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals. [Size=no report]

16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals. [Size=no report]

16 May: In SNNP region, Sodo town, Woleyta people held demonstration demanding to have their own zone and asking the government to stop the attack on Woleyta people in different areas. [Size=no report]
17 May: A group of south Sudanese people in Ethiopia held demonstration demanding President Salvakiir to step down. [Size=No report]
21 May:Seven civilians killed in the clash between OLF soldiers and Military forces of Ethiopia in Guji zone.
23 May: In Debre Berhan town, Amhara people held demonstration demanding that Amhara people's voice may be heard. They also asked the government to stop internal displacements.[Size=No report]
27 May: OLF Shane militants threw grenade at civilians and killed 6 people in West Welega zone, Oromia region
31 May : In Amhara region, Bahir Dar town, teachers held demonstration demanding pay raise. [Size=no report]
31 May: In Amhara region, Dessie town, teachers held demonstration demanding pay raise. [Size=no report]
02 June: Gumuz ethnic militia attacked a group of Amhara people and killed 5 in Metekel town, Benshangul Gumuz region
04 June: Gumuz ethnic militia killed two people who were members of Amhara ethnic group that live in Metekel town, Benshangul Gumuz region
07 June: In Oromia- Finfine special zone, Burayu town, Police seized 1054 bullets, 148 pistols and 300 kalashnivok that were possessed illegally by a civilian.
08 June: In West Guji zone, Negele town people held demonstration against the armed group that have been living in the bush and terrorizing the people around. [Size=3000]

08 June: In Oromia region, Borana zone, people held demonstrations against the armed people that have been living in the bush and terrorizing the people around. They demanded that they be hunted down and be brought before court. [Size=No report]
08 June: In west Guji zone, Bule-Hora town people held demonstrations against the armed men who have beeen living in the bush and terrorizing the people around. [Size=No report]
12 June: A civilian died when a grenade was thrown at a hotel in Nekemt town by unidentified armed men
On June 15 (or before), a mob attacked a Hong Kong Shoe Factory in Akaki Kality, damaging its building. [size=no report]
19 June: A bomb exploded in downtown Bahir Dar on Wednesday in the very early morning.
20 June: The Dembi Dolo city mayor was shot and seriously wounded by unidentified armed group.

21 June: The one person and the Ethiopian Military Chief of Staff was shot dead in his house by his own body guards, who is suspected to be an element of the Amharan Nationalist Movement. The attack is suspected to be related to the attack on the governor of Amhara, in a reported coup attempt. Military forces around the house responded and there was a clash.

column9: ADP: Amhara Democratic Party; Government of Ethiopia (2018-)
column17: 21 June: Elements of the Amharan Nationalist Movement attacked ADP headquarters in Bahir Dar and killed 2 people, including the regional president, Ambachew Mekonen. The attack is suspected to be an attempted coup.
23 June: An unidentified ethnic militia killed 57 people and wounded 17 in Metekal woreda. They also burned down 44 houses.
24 June. General Asamnew Tsige, who allegedly orchestrated the coup attempt in Amhara, was killed in a shoot out with security forces in Bahir Dar.

25 June: Thousands of people in Gimbi town, West Wellega zone, held demonstration against a group of OLF soldiers that recently split from OLF and decided to remain armed . The people also asked that they may be unarmed and join the peaceful political arena. [size=thousands]

25 June: Thousands of people in Bedele town, Buno bedele zone, held demonstrations against a group of OLF soldiers that recently split from OLF and decided to remain armed. They demanded that they be unarmed and join peaceful political arena.[Size=thousands]

28 June: In Dembi Dolo town, West wellega zone, people held demonstrations against the a group of armed OLF soldiers that spilt from OLF recently and decided to remain armed. The people demanded that they may be unarmed and join a peaceful political arena. [Size=thousands]

column9: NAMA: National Movement of Amhara; Military Forces of Ethiopia (2018-)
column17: 28 June (on or before). Over 250 suspects, including those suspected of being loyal to Asamnew and members of the NAMA political party, have been arrested following the attack in Bahir Dar on June 22nd.

06 July: In West Shewa zone, Meta Robi town, thousands of people held demonstration against OLF militant wing, Shane. They said that Shane has been killing, raping and robbing people. They demanded the government to put an end to their action. [Size=thousands]
08 July: An unidentified armed group killed at least 12 people in Metekel Woreda area, Benishangul Gumuz region. The reason of the attack was unknown

column9: Anuak Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column17: 12 July: A Nuer militia attacked a group of South Sudanese refugees in Gambella. One person was killed in the attack and others wounded. The refugees were members of Agnuak ethnic group from South Sudan.

July 18: Demonstrators burned tires and blocked roads when the activists were denied access to a venue where they were going announce Sidama as a region. Security forces intervened and at least 25 were killed, although other sources report 60 fatalities. Some sources also reported that ethnic minorities were killed by 'angry mobs' but the details remain unclear. [Size=no report].

19 July: Three people were killed by military forces during protests held in Wendo Genet, Sidama zone. The demonstration was in support of the activists that were going to announce Sidama as a region. [Size=no repot]

19 July: Demonstrators marched towards the police station in Hula Woreda (no coordinates available, in the Hagere Selam area) to protest the killing of youth, police forces opened fire killing 14 demonstrators. [size=no report]
19 July: Security forces killed 12 protesters in Melga, Sidama (no coordinates available). [size=no report]

19 - 20 July: An angry mob burned down three churches in Hula Woreda (no coordinates available, in the Hagere Selam area) in response to security forces killing protesters earlier in the day. [size=no report]

20 July (on or around). An angry mob attacked a tourist lodge in Yirga Alem, burning vehicles and looting the property. The attack is believed to be related to Sidama's efforts for autonomy and the violent reaction of security forces against demonstrators. [size=no report]
05 Aug : Two were killed during a clash between members of federal police. The clash started when a member of federal police rejected an order from his boss and later killed him and his colleague.
07 Aug: A police officer shot and killed 8 people and wounded 9 in the bus station in Gambella. Reasons unknown.
08 Aug: Unidentified armed group killed 7 people and wounded 3 in Gumbi Bordode, West Hararghe zone.
On 8 August 2019, one male national INGO staff member was wounded when mob violence erupted at a project site in Gambella. [size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-); Government of Ethiopia (2018-)
column17: 12 August. Police arrested several (number not reported) police officers and local government officials in connection to violence in the Oromia region.
11 Aug. Unidentified armed ethnic militia attacked passengers in a Bajaj (three wheeler vehicle) in Kele. One killed and 6 injured in the attack.
14 Aug. Kenyan pastoralist and Oromo pastoralist clashed in Moyal. 2 Ethiopians and 1 Kenyan were killed in the clash.

16 Aug. Police intervened the demonstration held by South Wolo youths. 4 people killed by bullets fired by the police. The government gave the land to government officials after compensating the farmers, which the demonstrators objected to. [Size=no report]

18 August: Police forces seized five trucks full of weapons in metama. The weapons were being transported by members of military forces, who said they were taking them to Darfur, Sudan but could not provide any documents supporting the claim.
23 August: Ethiopian Orthodox church leader in Harar, Oromia region was killed by unidentified armed group.
26 Aug. Oromo militias attacked Tuli Guled town in Ethiopian Somali region (No coordinates available for Tuli Guled area). One person killed in the attack.

26 August. Two police officers assaulted a handcuffed youth in Addis. When a woman attempted to intervene, they assaulted her as well. One of the officers also fired shots into the air. An investigation was launched after a viedo of the attack was released.
03 Sep. An unidentified ethnic militia opened fire on a civilian women, near Birqod. The victim was seriously injured. The attack comes amidst communal tensions between ethnic groups in the area.
04 Sep. Two aid workers were killed after their vehicle was ambushed by an unidentified armed group in the Gambella region.
13 Sep. 9 people killed in the grenade explosion that was thrown at police camp in Burayu by unidentified armed group.
14 Sep. 2 civilians killed in the clash between unidentified armed group and security forces in Gidani.

column7: Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Orthodox Christian Group (Ethiopia)
column17: 23 Sep. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Nefas Mewcha against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group. [Size=thousands]

column17: 19 Sep. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Kombolcha against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group. [Size=thousands]

column17: 18 Sep. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Gonder against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group. [Size=thousands]

column17: 16 Sep. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Debre Tabor against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group. [Size=thousands]

As reported to have taken place throughout the past month, by October 15, at least 40 people have been killed following clashes between Bodi Tribesmen and Federal government soldiers in the lower Omo valley during a disarmament campaign. Clashes are reported to have begun as part of resettlement programs tied to the building of the Gibe III dam and sugar plantations. Four events were coded for four weeks between from September 15 to October 15 (16, 23, 30 September and 14 October), and fatalities were split for each event (10).
16 Sep. Guliso city Mayor was killed by unidentified armed men in Guliso.
17 Sep. One person killed in the grenade explosion that was thrown at the military camp in Mendi, west Wellega zone.

22 Sep. Five people killed in the clash between unidentified mobs of unknown number and security forces. The mobs were throwing rocks at a Christian church and commercial bank when the security forces intervened. The reason for the unrest is not known. [size=no report].

As reported to have taken place throughout the past month, by October 15, at least 40 people have been killed following clashes between Bodi Tribesmen and Federal government soldiers in the lower Omo valley during a disarmament campaign. Clashes are reported to have begun as part of resettlement programs tied to the building of the Gibe III dam and sugar plantations. Four events were coded for four weeks between from September 15 to October 15 (16, 23, 30 September and 14 October), and fatalities were split for each event (10).
24 Sep. Unidentified armed men ambushed Ethiopian military forces and police forces. Four soldiers and one civilian killed. Military and police were moving in the groups when they came uder attack.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: Between 23rd and 29th, unspecified number of people killed and wounded in the clash between Qemant Ethnic militia and Amhara region Liyu police. Unknown fatalities.
25 Sep. 20,000 automatic guns, pistol, 42,392 regular ammunition, 8,484 M14 ammunition and 45 automatic machine gun ammunition were seized in Elidar woreda, Afar region.
29 Sep. Gonder residents held demonstration against an attack on Amhara people and Amahara Liyu police. Amhara regional presiedency denied any attack in the region. [size=no report]
29 Sep. Security forces seized about 40 AK-47 riffles hidden in vehicle travelling to Addis Ababa, the capital city. The weapons were seized in Sebeta.

As reported to have taken place throughout the past month, by October 15, at least 40 people have been killed following clashes between Bodi Tribesmen and Federal government soldiers in the lower Omo valley during a disarmament campaign. Clashes are reported to have begun as part of resettlement programs tied to the building of the Gibe III dam and sugar plantations. Four events were coded for four weeks between from September 15 to October 15 (16, 23, 30 September and 14 October), and fatalities were split for each event (10).

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
column17: 6 October 2019: Armed gunmen opened fire on Amhara regional special security forces in Ataye town, North Shawa. 5 civilians were killed in the ensuing gun battle, along with 3 soldiers. Local authorities blamed the attack on the OLF (Oromo Liberation Front), while a spokesman for the OLF denied the allegations.

7th and 8th October 2019: Hundreds of women gathered in front of the administration buildings in Dire Dawa to conduct a peaceful demonstration against the government's lack of a final solution for conflicts in the areas of Dire Dawa, Ginchi Gara, and Amstagna. The protest lasted two days. [size=hundreds]

12 October 2019: Several people were arrested shortly after attempting to start a demonstration in Giorgis subcity, located in the capital, Addis Ababa. Those arrested were followers of the Baldares movement which opposes the current presidency and was planning a large rally in Meskal square the same day. The Addis Ababa city council had previously banned protests on the (12 October) citing security concerns. Additional small protest groups were reported in 4 Kilo, Markato, and French Embassy area. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
column17: On 8 October 2019, Amhara special forces in South Gondor, Abnat Woreda, Dega Melza area shot and killed Sergeant Aschalew Dese, a leader of the Amhara youth group ""Fano"". The language of the report suggests an armed conflict occurred, but it is not clear.
8 October 2019: A civilian was injured by local security forces, in Jijiga town. No further details.
8 October 2019: Oromo community members in Dire Dawa city held a protest demonstration denouncing the wounding of a civilian by Somali regional security forces earlier (no details). [size=no report]
8 October 2019: A court decision to overrule police requests to postpone hearings sparked street demonstrations in Bahir Dar. Police later intervened, firing tear gas on protesters. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 8 October 2019: Clashes erupted between Amhara Liyu police and local Oromo militiamen after a Liyu Policeman shot and killed an Oromo man (presumed armed). More militiamen attacked the Liyu police headquarters, resulting in 3 more fatalities.

7th and 8th October 2019: Hundreds of women gathered in front of the administration buildings in Dire Dawa to conduct a peaceful demonstration against the government's lack of a final solution for conflicts in the areas of Dire Dawa, Ginchi Gara, and Amstagna. The protest lasted two days. [size=hundreds]
9 October 2019: Members of the Somali Youth Federation gathered in Jijiga and demonstrated against what they saw discriminatory hiring practices by Ethiopian airlines. [size=no report]

9 October 2019: Residents of Adi Dearo town, located in upper Adiyabo of Western Tigray demonstrated against a local government official who was accused of engaging in serious sexual and financial crimes. Some news outlets have reported that demonstrators were shouting anti-TPLF slogans. [size=no report]
10 October 2019: Paramilitaries from Afar region attacked pastoralist civilians in Alaale town, Sitti province of Somali region. 1 person was killed and 5 others injured.
11 October 2019: A group of Oromo youth (Qeerroo) protested outside the office building of the Baldera organization as they held a press conference. [size=no report]

12 October 2019: Frustrated demonstrators attempting to reach Addis Ababa from Amhara region protested in Debre Birhan, north Shewa, claiming that Oromo Youth (Qeerroo) had closed the roads to block a planned protest by the Balderas movement. No information if any violence occurred. [size=no report]
12 October 2019: Borana zone residents held a support demonstration after hearing prime minister Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize. [size=no report]
12 October 2019: Locals gathered in Guji zone held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize. [size=no report]

12 October 2019: Residents of Assosa town rallied in demonstration to show their support of President Abiy Ahmed, who had recently won the Nobel prize. Leaders of the rally spoke to fellow residents of the town, encouraging them to support the president and his reforms. [size=no report]
12 October 2019: Residents of Sultulta held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize. [size=no report]
12 October 2019: Residents in Adama city (Nazret) held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize. [size=no report]
12 October 2019: Residents in Jima held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize. [size=no report]

As reported to have taken place throughout the past month, by October 15, at least 40 people have been killed following clashes between Bodi Tribesmen and Federal government soldiers in the lower Omo valley during a disarmament campaign. Clashes are reported to have begun as part of resettlement programs tied to the building of the Gibe III dam and sugar plantations. Four events were coded for four weeks between from September 15 to October 15 (16, 23, 30 September and 14 October), and fatalities were split for each event (10).
15 October 2019: Protesters condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: Protesters condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: Protesters condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: Protesters condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: Protesters condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.

16 October 2019: At least 20 people were killed in Burji zone as clashes erupted over issues related to the creation of a special administration zone. Locals divided about the issue and clashed with each other. At least one federal police officer was killed trying to intervene.
18 October 2019: A Benishangul Regional police officer was killed while traveling from Komashi Zone, Benishangul, to Oromiya region. Anti-OLF sources attributed his death to OLF members in the area.

14 October 2019: In Afar Region, Afambo Woreda, Obno Kabele, 17 people were killed and 34 wounded when armed gunmen crossed the border from Djibouti, attacking pastoralist villages using heavy and light weapons. The motive for the attack is unknown, although land-related issues revolving around ethnicity control of the area are suspected. The Djiboutian government later issued a statement and made clear that no members of the Djiboutian army were involved in the incident.

19 October 2019: Protesters from the ""Hadari Seb"" student's group gathered in Mekelle town to demonstrate against ethnically Tigrayan students being sent for university studies to other parts of the country where they could face violence due to their ethnicity. Demonstrators were dispersed by police after being deemed illegal due to lack of pre-approval. No violence occurred.

22 October 2019: Thousands of people held a demonstration in Aweday, demanding ethnic clashes cease in Jigjiga. They also asked that the Oromo people who have been arrested in West and east Oromia region be released. [size=thousands]

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Bale Robe. Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. Stores, factories, and heavy equipment was burned and destroyed.

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests in Arsi Negele. Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. Stores, factories, and heavy equipment was burned and destroyed. At least one person is reported to have been injured as a result of scuffles with rival protesters in Arsi Negele. Ethnic Amhara were reportedly attacked by mobs in Arsi, leading to some injuries.

23 October 2019: Three young men were shot and wounded by police in Ambo town during riots and protests. Riots were sparked across Oromiya region when popular activist Jawar Mohammed claimed that someone in the government had tried to assassinate or arrest him.

One man was brutally killed by rioters on the 23rd October in Harar city. Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob involving Qeerroo youth was seen heading toward his house.

23 October 2019: A popular Oromo activist living in Addis Ababa (Bole) issued a series of alerts on facebook during the night, claiming that the government had attempted to remove his guards and expose him to a potentially life-threatening situation. Within hours, hundreds of young men from the Qerroo Oromo youth group had surrounded his house, chanting slogans aimed at the prime minster. [size=hundreds]

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Dire Dawa. One person killed during riots in Dire Dawa on the 23rd October (reason for fatality unknown - sources suggest clashes with local police)

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Dodola. In the city, rioters clashed with federal police, resulting in at least two reported fatalities.

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Aweday. Rioters clashed with federal and local police, burned tires, and torched shops owned by non-Oromos. One person killed during riots in Aweday on the 23rd October.

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Haramaya (Alemaya). Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. Stores, factories, and heavy equipment was burned and destroyed. At least one person was killed in Haramaya (unknown how he was killed, but sources suggest clashes with police).

23 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including in Shashamene. Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. Stores, factories, and heavy equipment were burned and destroyed.
24 October 2019: Oromo youth protesters clashed with federal police in Ambo, causing them to open fire. 3 protesters were killed, and 10 others were injured.

24 October 2019: 4 people were killed and an unknown number of houses burned during rioting and clashes in Dodola town, Arsi. Riots were sparked across Oromiya region when popular activist Jawar Mohammed claimed that someone in the government had tried to assassinate or arrest him. This is the second day of riots in the city of Dodola. Those killed in Dodola were ethnic Amhara, who were attacked in homes, cars, and in the street.

25 October 2019: Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Most of those killed are said to have been non-Oromo ethnic peoples in Oromiya region. Rioting took place across the country, including Ambo. A government spokesperson confirmed that 78 fatalities occurred during the 3 days of rioting following the incident on the night of the 22/23. [size=no report]. Fatalities spread across multiple locations, with unknown values spread evenly across areas with known protests on the specified day.

25 October 2019: Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Most of those killed are said to have been non-Oromo ethnic peoples in Oromiya region. Riots occurred across Oromiya region, including Asela. A government spokesperson confirmed that 78 fatalities occurred during the 3 days of rioting following the incident on the night of the 22/23. [size=no report]. Fatalities spread across multiple locations, with unknown values spread evenly across areas with known protests on the specified day.

24th October 2019: Riots involving Qeeroo youth were reported in Bale Robe when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Rioters in Bale Robe attacked minority ethnic Gamo civilians leaving at least six dead. An additional 4 rioters were killed during clashes with rival groups (non-weaponized).

Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. At least 7 people were killed during riots in Dire Dawa city during the 3 days of rioting. Fatalities spread across 3 days (1 known fatality on the 23rd, 6 remaining fatalities spread between the 24th and 25th October, 2019. [size=no report]

24th October 2019: A popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. In the ensuing riots involving Qeerroo Youth, at least 3 demonstrators were killed in Ziway by a private security guard at a popular resort/hotel on the 24th October, 2019. [size=no report]

24 October 2019: Qerroo youth demonstrators continued to surround the home of a popular activist in Bole, Addis Ababa, burning tires and copies of the prime minister's newly released book. Some scuffles occurred with local police and rival groups.

24 October 2019: At least 3 people were killed in Harar during riots. Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Harar. Unknown reason of death in Harar, sources suggest rival mob/mob fighting. One known fatality recorded on the 23rd October, remaining fatalities recorded on the 24th October. No reported riots in Harar on the 25th October.

24 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Bishooftu (Debre Zeyit). Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. Stores, factories, and heavy equipment were burned and destroyed.

24 October 2019: Allegations pointing towards attempts to harm or arrest a popular Oromo activist sparked protests across Oromiya region, including Asela. Protesters burned pictures of the Prime Minster, Abiy Ahmed and blocked roads with burning tires. At least one person was injured in Asela by federal police as they attempted to stop rioters.

24 October 2019: At least 2 were killed and more than 60 others were injured during rioting in Adama city (Nazreth), Oromiya region. The fatalities occurred when private security guards guarding a flour factory opened fire on rioters who were threatening the area.
24 October 2019: A grenade was tossed into a church in Dodola, injuring dozens of ethnic Amhara people who had fled into the church for safety during riots on the 23rd and 24th October, 2019.

25 October 2019: Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Most of those killed are said to have been non-Oromo ethnic peoples in Oromiya region. Rioting locations included Debre Zeyit. A government spokesperson confirmed that 78 fatalities occurred during the 3 days of rioting following the incident on the night of the 22/23. [size=no report]. Fatalities spread across multiple locations, with unknown values spread evenly across areas with known protests on the specified day.

Most of those killed are said to have been non-Oromo ethnic peoples in Oromiya region. Rioting took place across the region, including Dodola town. A government spokesperson confirmed that 78 fatalities occurred during the 3 days of rioting following the incident on the night of the 22/23. [size=no report]. Fatalities spread across multiple locations, with unknown values spread evenly across areas with known protests on the specified day.

25 October 2019: Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Most of those killed are said to have been non-Oromo ethnic peoples in Oromiya region. Rioting locations included Shashamene. A government spokesperson confirmed that 78 fatalities occurred during the 3 days of rioting following the incident on the night of the 22/23. [size=no report]. Fatalities spread across multiple locations, with unknown values spread evenly across areas with known protests on the specified day.

25th October 2019: At least 4 people killed in riots on the 25th October 2019 in Bale Robe town, Oromiya region. Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house.

At least 7 people were killed during riots in Dire Dawa city during the 3 days of rioting. Riots began on the 23rd, when a popular activist accused the government of attempting to expose him to harm when his guards were removed and a mob was seen heading toward his house. Fatalities spread across 3 days (1 known fatality on the 23rd, 4 known fatalities on the 25th, remaining fatalities reported on the 24th. [size=no report]

25 October 2019: At least 16 total demonstrators were killed and many more were injured during three days of rioting in Adama city (Nazreth), Oromiya region. The fatalities occurred when private security guards guarding a local businesses opened fire on rioters who were threatening the area, some were killed during clashes with local police. Moreover, rioting youth was also reported to have attacked a news journalist reporting for VOA, seriously injuring him. 16 fatalities spread across three days.

26 October 2019: At least 16 total demonstrators were killed and many more were injured during three days of rioting in Adama city (Nazreth), Oromiya region. The fatalities occurred when private security guards guarding a local businesses opened fire on rioters who were threatening the area, some were killed during clashes with local police. Moreover, rioting youth was also reported to have attacked a news journalist reporting for VOA, seriously injuring him. 16 fatalities spread across three days (7)

28 October 2019: Workers in Mera Beta Woreda, North Shoa Zone rioted against their contracted construction company after questions about wages were left unanswered. Workers burned vehicles and equipment, with the company owner telling police that the situation was completely out of control. [size=no report]

28 October 2019: Two protesters were wounded by bullets when security forces intervened in a protest/demonstration in Mojo town, East Shewa of Oromiya region. The demonstrators were asking for the people who were arrested last week to be released. [Size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: 29 October 2019: The leader of the Amhara Fano militia group in Dera, North Shewa, was killed during a shootout with Oromiya police.

31 October 2019: Qerro Oromo Youth protesters gathered on the main street of Ambo town as prime minister Abiy Ahmed and Defense Minister Lemma Megesa gathered to meet with local officials to discuss violence that had occurred in the city a week before. Witnesses claimed that demonstrators numbered over 10,000, all demanding that Qerroo youth representatives be included in the talks. [size=over 10000]

1 November 2019: Federal Police engaged in a short firefight with suspected OLF militia in Meta Walqite woreda, West Shewa, resulting in the death of one police officer. Additional police forces in an ambulance coming to aid the ambushed troops were hit by gunfire, resulting in the death of three police soldiers and the ambulance driver (civilian).

3 November 2019: Splinter faction of the OLF (""Shane"") battle Ethiopian federal troops in Begi and Qondalla area, Wollega, Oromiya region with intermittant clashes taking place on the th, 3rd, 4th, and 5th November 2019. At least one person (a civilian) was confirmed killed during the clashes. Fatality coded to 4 November 2019.

4 November 2019: Splinter faction of the OLF (""Shane"") battle Ethiopian federal troops in Begi and Qondalla area, Wollega, Oromiya region with intermittant clashes taking place on the th, 3rd, 4th, and 5th November 2019. At least one person (a civilian) was confirmed killed during the clashes. Fatality coded to 4 November 2019.

5 November 2019: hundreds of people gathered at the Bole international airport to receive the bodies of 7 dead Ethiopian domestic workers who had been killed in Lebanon. Greiving family members expressed their frusteration at the workers' treatment abroad, especially in Arab ccountries.

5 November 2019: Splinter faction of the OLF (""Shane"") battle Ethiopian federal troops in Begi and Qondalla area, Wollega, Oromiya region with intermittant clashes taking place on the th, 3rd, 4th, and 5th November 2019. At least one person (a civilian) was confirmed killed during the clashes. Fatality coded to 4 November 2019.
9 November 2019: A peaceful protest was held by around 200 women in Mekele city, Tigray region, demonstrating against Gender-Based-violence. [size = hundreds]

9 November 2019: Two students, reportedly Oromo by ethnicity, were killed and 8 others injured by rioting students after a football match in Weldya Univ., located in north Wollo zone of Amhara regional state. Some Oromo language media reported that the two students had been killed by armed men.

From 10 to 14 November 2019, rioters erected roadblocks in Dire Dawa and clashed with federal forces who were attempting to open roadways. Intermittent clashes and sporadic gunfire were reported for 5 continuous days, November 10-14. At least 2 people were seriously injured. [size=no report]

On 12 November 2019, a student was killed in Dembi Dollo university following a fight between students near the university's cafeteria. The attack occurred shortly after ethnic clashes occurred in Woldiya university, and is thought to have been similarly ethnically motivated. [size=no repot]

From 10 to 14 November 2019, rioters erected roadblocks in Dire Dawa and clashed with federal forces who were attempting to open roadways. Intermittent clashes and sporadic gunfire were reported for 5 continuous days, November 10-14. At least 2 people were seriously injured. [size=no report]

On 12 November 2019, in Bule Hora university, in west Guji zone of Oromia region, at least 10 students were injured during rioting/fighting that occurred after news spread that 2 students had been killed the day prior in Woldiya University. Military troops deployed to the campus were able to stop the rioting. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Guder, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Bulbula, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Ziway, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Weldiya, demonstrators marched to denounce the killing of two university students in Woldiya Universtiy, Amhara region. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Chiro, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [ size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Ginchi, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [ size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Asri Negele, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Hirna, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Haramaya, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Ambo, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University. [size=no report]
On 12 November 2019, in Shashamane, several people (mainly students) held a demonstration in Shashamane following the death of two Oromo students in Weldiya. [size=several]

From 10 to 14 November 2019, rioters erected roadblocks and clashed with federal forces in Dire Dawa who were attempting to open roadways. Intermittent clashes and sporadic gunfire were reported for 5 continuous days, November 10-14. At least 2 people were seriously injured. [size=no report]

On 12 November 2019, armed militants attacked a group of farmers in Eferatana Gidem woreda, N. Shewa region of Amhara zone, killing 1. A peace reconciliation ceremony was held in the community following the killing, suggesting that the violence stemmed from community issues.

On 13 November 2019, five Oromo students were attacked by local youth in Gondor who were armed with knives and other crude weapons. Some students were stabbed while others were thrown off buildings. No fatalities occurred. [size=no report]
On 13 November 2019, several Oromo students were attacked and beaten by local youth mobs in Wollo University. No fatalities reported. [size=no report]
On 13 November 2019, 2 Orthodox churches were burned by rioters in East Hararghe zone, Oromiya region, in what appears to have been targeted violence. [size=no report]

From 10 to 14 November 2019, rioters erected roadblocks in Dire Dawa and clashed with federal forces who were attempting to open roadways. Intermittent clashes and sporadic gunfire were reported for 5 continuous days, November 10-14. At least 2 people were seriously injured. [size=no report]
On 13 November 2019, several students were injured as ethnically-based groups clashed on campus in Metu university, located in Illulabor, Oromiya region. [size=no report]

From 10 to 14 November 2019, rioters erected roadblocks in Dire Dawa and clashed with federal forces who were attempting to open roadways. Intermittent clashes and sporadic gunfire were reported for 5 continuous days, November 10-14. At least 2 people were seriously injured. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2019, an unidentified group of people attacked a ""zemen bus"" as it traveled from Dire Dawa to Addis Ababa using rocks. The bus company recently changed its paint colors, a move seen as being political. No one was hurt in the incident. [size=no report]

On 15 November 2019, 3 students were reportedly injured during clashes on campus at the Meqedele-Ambo university. The situation is unclear although context suggests that the clashes may have been ethnically based. [size=no report]

On 16 November 2019, demonstrators blocked the road between Ambo and Addis Ababa using stones and logs after rumors circulated that Amhara ethnic students were being evacuated from the university in Ambo. Protesters blocking roads demanded that Oromo students be evacuated from Amhara region before any Amhara students were allowed to leave Oromiya region. [size=no report]

21 November 2019: An Oromia regional state official (head of the Roads Authority, Oromia State) was killed by unidentified gunmen in Laale Asaabi conservation zone of Qalam Wolegga. The identity of the gunmen has not been revealed, although OLF ""Shane"" militias are operating in the area.
21 November 2019: University students who were beginning a protest were quickly arrested at the Sidist (6) Kilo entrance to Addis Ababa University. No further details. [size=no report]

21 November 2019: Oromo and Afar communal militias clashed for unknown reasons in the Amibara woreda, Afar zone. At least 2 people were killed, one of whom died after being shot by Security forces that had come to stop the clashes.

22 November 2019: Secondary school students demonstrated against recent violence targeting ethnically Amhara students across the country. Protesters began near the Dambacha university located in West Gojam zone, and marched to the police station after several students were arrested. Police fired bullets into the air to disperse the protesters, and at least one person was seriously injured and taken to the hospital. [size=no report]
Around the 25th November 2019, a criminal prosecution official in Neqemte town was shot and killed by unidentified armed gunmen.

On the 25th November 2019, Addis Ababa Police forces shot dead a private security guard during a large dispute over hanging of religious banners near the Rwandan Embassy (where he worked as a security guard). Three other people were injured in the event. Both the security guard and the police forces were armed.

On the 25th of November 2019, several students were arrested by Addis Ababa police following a protest rally on Addis Ababa campus. Protesters denounced violence facing Oromo students studying in Amhara region. [size=no report]

On the evening of the 26th November, 2019, two local officials were killed in Gojo town, west Oromiya, by unidentified armed gunmen. The two killed were identified as the deputy governor of the Joldu district of western Oromia, and the political head of the Goje town. OLF breakaway ""Shane"" is active in the area and is supsected of being behind the attacks.

column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Afar Special Forces
column17: Around the 26th or 27th November, 2019: An Afar Special Forces (LIYU) soldier was killed by unspecified militants near Bati town. The road going through the town was closed for at least one day following the unrest. Further details are unavailable.

On the 4th of December 2019, 2 police officers and one civilian were killed by unidentified armed men while the police attempted to arrest a suspect in East Shawa, Adama city, Adulala Boku Woreda. The suspect was accused of providing false testimony in court.
On the 5th December 2019, unidentified armed men shot and injured 4 police officers in Gebre Guracha, North Shewa. One of the injured was the head of Kayuu police dept.
8 December 2019. Campus security at Woldia University beat a third year student (ethnically Oromo), causing hospitalization. The student later died.

8 December 2019: unidentified individuals beat a student at Gondor University, causing his death a few hours later in a hospital. Ethnic tension in communities surrounding universities over the past few weeks have led to attacks on students studying in zones outside of their ethnic homelands.
9 December 2019: In East Shewa zone, Awash Fantale Woreda, East Shewa (Oromiya region), clashes between Argobba and Karrayyu (Oromo) clans resulted in two fatalities.

14 December 2019: 3 Amhara locals and 1 person of Gumz ethnicity were killed during a shootout in Manbuk town, Metakal zone, Banishangul. 3 additional people were wounded before federal troops intervened and stopped the fighting.
On 8 December 2019, one INGO staff member was shot and killed in his home when an unknown NSAG began firing in Kutala Haro Kebele (West Wellega, Oromia).

Circa 10 December 2019: 4 University students of Amhara ethnicity were kidnapped as they fled the university following ethnic clashes. The identity of the kindappers is unknown. Further sources have claimed that as many as 17 students were kidnapped, blaming a breakaway faction of the OLF for the violence.
12 December 2019: Residents of Sodo city, Wolayta city, Sodo, demonstrated in support of President Abiy Ahmed's receiving of the Nobel Peace Prize award. [size=no report]
14 December 2019: 1 student was killed and 2 others injured when they were attacked by unidentified men as they walked from university campus to the church in Shambu Wollega, Oromiya.
16 December 2019: A woman-only rally was held in Wolayta zone (Sodo town), in support of Wolayta becoming a regional state. [size=no report]
18 December 2019: Religious groups, trade union groups, and community groups rallied in Sodo, Wolayta, in support of a Wolayta regional state. [size=no report]
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state. [size=no report]
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state. [size=no report]
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state. [size=no report]

On 20 December 2019, a mob burnt down two mosques and a muslim-owned business center in Mota (east Gojam zone, Amhara regional state). Rioters attacked the mosques and business center after a fire started in the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahdo Church. The cause of the church fire is not known. [size=no report]
21 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Shashamene denouncing an attack on a mosque in Gojam zone the night before. [size=no report]
21 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Jimma denouncing an attack on a mosque in Gojam zone the night before. [size=no report]
21 December 2019: Muslim worshippers gathered near the Nur Masjid in Addis Ababa (Arada subcity), denouncing the burning of mosques in Motta, East Gojjam, the night before. [size=no report]
19 December 2019: Tuk Tuk drivers (bajaj) staged a protest in Sodo in favor of Wolayta becoming an Ethiopian state. [size=hundreds]

Dec 24, 2019: Residents in Jigjiga protest against the burning of mosques in Amhara region, Ethiopia. Some reports claimed that police fired on protesters, leading to the death of one demonstrator, while other (more reliable) reports claimed that the demonstration took place without incident. [size=hundreds]

Circa 25th December 2019: 4 police officers were killed and 2 others wounded by unidentified attackers in the Maji town, Bench Maji zone of SNNPR. Houses of Amhara ethnic residents were later burned in a similar attack.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
column17: 26 December 2019: Amhara regional special police engaged in short clashes with Sudanese forces in North Gonder zone, Armacheho Woreda, in a cross-border incident after Sudanese forces shot and wounded a civilian man.

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made. [size= no report]

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made. [size=no report]

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made. [size= no report]

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made. [size= no report]

27 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Dessie, Amhara region, denouncing the burning of several mosques and muslim-owned businesses in East Gondar the week before. Protests were peaceful and no police intervention was recorded. [size=no report]

31 December 2019: 10 students and 3 security personnel were hospitalized after violent demonstrations erupted at Dire Dawa university following the death of a student at the university the day before. [size= no report]

28 December 2019: Unidentified students at Dire Dawa University threw a student from a different ethnic group off the top of a university building, killing him immediately. The killed was from the Amhara ethnic group. [size=no report]

1 January 2020: A second year university student was killed at Wello University after being beaten by a group of unidentified students. Motives for the beating include ethnic tensions in the country, which killed two other students in nearby universities in earlier weeks. [size=no report]
1 January 2020: Unidentified armed gunmen attacked Amhara ethnic residents of Gutu Seyoma Woreda, Gobu Seyo Qebele, killing 4 and kidnapping 2 women before fleeing toward Dembi Dolo.

1 January 2020: Unidentified armed men shot and killed a Benishangul State regional council member as he travelled to Asosa from Nekemt town. A man and woman travelling in the same car were injured in the attack.
2 January 2020: A protest rally was held in Asosa town, denouncing the killing of a Benishangul State regional council member the day before. [size=no report]
3 January 2020: Heavy truck drivers in Gondor protested a lack of security on the roads, citing a number of recent ransom-motivated kidnapping of drivers in the region. [size=no report]
3 January 2020: Peaceful protests were held by Muslim protesters in Bahir Dar denouncing the burning of mosques and muslim-owned businesses in Mota town a week prior. [size=no report]
On the weekend of 5 January 2020: A road construction manager was shot and killed by unidentified armed men in Soreka city, Metema Woreda, of Gonder zone.

7 January 2020: Unidentified armed men shot and killed two children in Amaro special region of SNNPR zone. Perpetrators were said to have crossed from Guji, Oromia, leading authorities to believe that the attack could have been part of a larger conflict.

10 January 2020: Security forces fired on protesting students at Bule Hora university, killing one and injuring at least 12 others. Protesters were demonstrating against action taken by military forces in West Wollega. [size=at least 13]
10 January 2020: A student was killed during a riot at Hawassa university. No reason for the riot was reported. [size=no report]
On 21 January 2020, 5 civilian men were shot and killed execution-style by federal troops in Dolla, near Mugi, west Wollega.

15-18 January 2020: Demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda. [size=no report]
16 January 2020: Taxi drivers in Addis Ababa conducted a strike and protest, demonstrating against high traffic violation fees. [size=no report]

15-18 January 2020: Demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda. [size=no report]
16 January 2020: Protesters in Damobya woreda, Kembata zone marched in the street, demanding that road construction efforts link their district to the Halaba/Sheshamene road. [size=no report]

15-18 January 2020: Demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda. [size=no report]

15-18 January 2020: Demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda. [size=no report]
Circa 20 January 2020: Government forces clashed with unidentified armed groups in Seba Boru woreda, Guji zone (Oromia), displacing hundreds. No further info.

20 January 2020: Rioters clashed in Dira Dawa city during a part of the Timket celebration, leaving several injured and one killed. Clashes were instigated over the tri-color Ethiopian flag, a point of contention for many Oromo living in the city. Many of the injured were police officers attempting to separate the clashing groups. At least 7 of the injured were reported as having gunshot wounds. Oromia media network reported that some of its reporters were attacked while covering the event. [size=no report]

21 January 2020: Rioters clashed in Harar city during the Timket (baptism) celebration, causing at least 19 injuries. Many of the injured were police officers, who intervened in the situation before it got out of hand. 20 arrests were later made. During the riot, political offices of the Oromo Federal Congress were ransacked. [size=no report]
22 January 2020: Police forces shot and killed one person after rioters clashed with police in Gonder city during Timket celebrations. [size=no report]
23 January 2020: Afar militants attacked Somali herders at Masule border town in the Somali region, sparking clashes that resulted in at least one injury.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: 23 January 2020: Liyu police forces (Somali) opened fire on protesters in Dhobaweyn, Korahe district, Somali zone, killing one person and injuring several more. Protests were sparked after police arrested a prominate Shaykh. [size=no report]
23 January 2020: In Abomsa town, Arsi zone, clashes erupted between groups of rioters during the Temket celebration, leading to the death of 4 people. [size=no report]

24 January 2020: Government officials at the Kebele level accused the Gumuz People Democratic Party (GPDR) of instigating an attack on civilians in Kong Kabele, Wenbera woreda, killing at least 8. Arrests were later made. An addtonal 14 people are still missing and feared dead.

25 January 2020: Students at Gondor university protested the kidnap and dissapearance of several ethnically Amhara students from Dembi Dolo several weeks ago. Police intervened and arrested several of the protesters. [size=no report]

25 January 2020: Two ethnic Amhara brothers were killed by unidentified armed gunmen in Teppi city, Debub Bench, SNNPR. Government offices were later closed and a curfew imposed by the gunmen, who made threats via social media.
25 January 2020: Oromo militias clashed with Somali militiamen in Tulu Guled area of Somali/Oromia border region, causing at least one injury.
25 January 2020: Oromo youth rioters clashed with Ethiopian police in Ejaji, West Shewa, following a holiday celebration. 4 police officers and 2 youth were wounded. [size=no report]

26 January 2020: Armed Oromo militiamen attacked Somali pastoralists in Tulu Guled (Fafan, Somali), prompting armed clashes between the two groups. Ethiopian federal troops later took control of the area. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

26 January 2020: 3 Afar communal militiamen were shot and wounded by Somali ethnic forces in Garbo Ciise (Adaytu), on the border of Afar and Somali zones. Clashes over grazing areas, water, and other resources are common in the area.
27 January 2020: Authorities conducted mass arrests of OLF political supporters in Finchawa, and Shambu town of Horo-Guduru Wallaga Zone.
27 January 2020: Authorities conducted mass arrests of OLF political supporters in Finchawa, and Shambu town of Horo-Guduru Wallaga Zone.
On 28 January 2020, federal soldiers shot and killed a civilian man near Mugi town, West Wollegga.

28 January 2020: Hundreds of thousands demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar. [size=hundreds of thousands]

28 January 2020: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar. [size=hundreds of thousands]

28 January 2020: hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar. [size=hundreds of thousands]

30 January 2020: Protesters in East Hararghe (city not specified) demonstrated against government violence against civilians in Wolegga, West Oromiya region. [size=no report]

30 January 2020: Rioters threw stones at police and blocked roads with burning tires, denouncing recent government violence against civilians in Harar town (Hundene, Harari People). Riots lasted three days in the city. [size=no report]

31 January 2020: Rioters threw stones at police and blocked roads with burning tires, denouncing recent government violence against civilians in Harar town (Hundene, Harari People). Riots lasted three days in the city. [size=no report]
