1 February 2020: Ethiopian federal troops arrested a man in Hawa Galan, East Wollega, in the morning. His dead body was found in a forested area several hours later.

1 February 2020: Ethiopian federal troops shot and killed two brothers in Najjo, Wolegga, during counter-insurgency operations targeting OLF splinter factions in the area. The brothers are reported to have been unarmed.
1 February 2020: Ethiopian federal troops shot and killed a civilian man in Buno Bedele, while conducting operations against OLF splinter forces in the area.

1 February 2020: Rioters threw stones at police and blocked roads with burning tires, denouncing recent government violence against civilians in Harar town (Hundene, Harari People). Riots lasted three days in the city. [size=no report]
4 February 2020: Oromo militiamen attacked the Somali town of Tuur Caanood, located near Tulu Guled town, sparking fierce clashes. At least two Oromo militiamen were killed and a third wounded.

4 February 2020: 8 people were killed and 12 others injured during a shootout between unidentified armed militants and federal security forces in Teppi city, SNNPR. The clash was instigated when unidentified armed men stabbed a federal military soldier, sparking clashes.
5 February 2020: Police forces forcibly removed people campaining for a church to be built in an empty lot in 22 area of Addis Ababa, shooting and killing 2 in the process. [size=no report]

5 February 2020: Protesters gathered in 22 section of Addis Ababa, protesting the killing of 2 persons a few hours prior in a vacant lot. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]

6 February 2020: Oromo ethnic militias attacked the Somali town of Tulu Guled, in Fafan district, prompting clashes with armed Somali militias who came to defend the town. At least one person (Somali) was killed, and 5 wounded before the attackers retreated.

9 February 2020: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets in Jimma, Oromia, protesting remarks made by the leader of the Oromo Federal Congress (OFC) in a recent conference. [size=tens of thousands]
10 February 2020: Ethiopian federal troops were accused of detaining and then torturing a civilian individual in Werder town, Dollo zone of Somali region.
11 February 2020: Afari militants attacked the Somali town of Danlahelay in the Sitti zone area (Somali), sparking armed clashes with armed locals. Two Somalis were wounded in the attack.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: 14 February 2020: Several popular Oromo musicians were arrested and beaten by Oromia state police in Burayyu town after being accused of working with the OLF.

Around 15 February 2020, intra-communal violence was reported in the Nuer zone area, SNNPR, resulted in 12 fatalities and some 21 injured. Violence erupted after the killing of a local administrator (included in the fatality count).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: 16 February 2020: Oromia Special police forces state attacked OLF supporters celebrating an office opening in Wolanchiti, East Shewa, killing one and injuring several others. Vehicles were damaged during the attack.
17 February 2020: Riots and general ""unrest"" in Gurafarda woreda, Bench Maji zone, led to the arrest of several woreda officials. Further details about this event are unclear. [size=no report]

18 February 2020: Afar militiamen launched a series of attacks into ethnically Somali villages, firing on unarmed civilians. One person was killed, and a second injured in the attack. These attacks took place in Masulu town, near Danlaheylay (could not be located).

column8: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)
column17: In late February 2020, Governement troops battled OLF splinter faction soldiers led by Jal Marro (Kumsa Diriba) in the West Wollegga, Anfilo woreda region, taking control of territory held by the OLF. No info on casualties.

20 February 2020: Supporters of the Prosperity Party (PP) clashed with people opposed to PM Abiy Ahmed during a march/demonstration in Aweday, Oromia region. Police forces intervened to stop the violence, firing weapons in the air to disperse rioters. Several people were hospitalized. [size=at least several]

In late February 2020, government federal troops arrested and beat a civilian man in Guliso, Nekemte, on suspicions of being associated with the OLF. He was severely injured in the attack and can no longer walk.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: 21 February 2020: the police commissioner of Borayyu city and the the head of the Oromia state special police force were ambushed by unidentified gunmen while eating at a cafe in Borayyu. The police commissioner was killed while the head of Oromia special forces was seriously injured.

21 February 2020: Thousands of people gathered in Hawassa (Sidama, Southern Nations), demonstrating their support of PM Abiy Ahmed and his Prosperity Party in addition to the successful referrendum and creation of Sidama state. [size=thousands]

On 23 February 2020, an unidentified assailant threw a grenade into a rally in support of Abiy Ahmed and the Prosperity Party in Ambo. Many people and horses were injured in the attack, no fatalities reported.
On 24 February 2020, Oromo militias attacked the Somali town of Tuliguuleed in a night time raid, sparking clashes with local militiamen. At least one Somali was killed.

On 25 February 2020, a hand grenade was thrown by unidentified attackers at a police station in Ginchi, Oromia region. 2 officers were later treated for smoke inhalation, but no major injuries were reported.
On 26 February 2020, salt mine workers in Afar zone, Afdera woreda protested after a company executive recently accused of a violation was dropped from a prosecution list. [size=no report]

On 28 February 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Tum town, Bench Maji woreda, killing 6. Protesters had flooded the streets, demonstrating against the recent arrest of woreda officials by federal troops. [size=at least 6]

On 29 February 2020, people who came to meet Oromo Federal Congress officials for a discussion in Adama city (Nazreth) protested after being denied entry to the venue by police forces. [size=no report]

Between 16 Februarary and 20 March 2020, unarmed civilians were reportedly shot by Ethiopian military forces in Mugi, Anfilo Woreda, resulting in dozens of fatalities. The vicitims were usually young Oromo men suspected of being associated with the OLF.
On 2 March 2020, unidentified attackers stabbed the director of the Dhegahbur Hospital, located in Dhegahbur zone of Somali regional state. The victim survived.

column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
column17: On 2 March 2020, unknown persons attacked a police inspecting vehicle with a bomb in Sanja town, Tach Armachaho zone, North Gondor, killing a police officer and the person driving the car. Following the explosion, a civil servant, and a member of Amhara region's special (liyu) police were killed in an exchange of gunfire (source unclear where gunfire originated).
On 2 March 2020, Afari militants crossed the regional border and attacked ethnic Somali livestock herders in Masalu town in Sitti zone (Somali), killing one.

On 2 March 2020, Oromo armed men shot and injured three ethnic Somali civilians in the town of Sheikh Sayid Cumar near Tulu Guleed (Fafan, Somali). All three were hospitalized in Tulu Guleed following the attack.
On 3 March 2020, unidentified men armed with sticks and clubs attacked three regional judges in Durbete, Amhara region. The judges were later hospitalized, two with serious injuries.

On 3 March 2020, a man wearing a bomb detonated it during prayers at the Anjabara Orthodox church in Anjabara town, Amhara region. The bomber and his wife were killed, with 8 others injured. Motives behind the attack are unknown, and do not appear to be linked to jihadism.

On 6 March 2020, armed men opened fire on a park ranger patrol in the Babile Elephant sanctuary (East Harerghe, Oromia), killing 1 ranger and injuring 3 others. 3 members of the armed forces were also injured in the shootout.
On 10 March 2020, an IED exploded in a field in Mahal Meda town, North Shewa, killing 3 people and injuring several others. The wounded were taken to a hospital in nearby Debre Birhan.

On 11 March 2020, rioting youth attacked a church at Anawari Ketama in North Shewa (Amhara), burning equipment on allegations that they were hosting several openly gay foreign doctors to provide eye surgeries. Several people were injured by the rioting youth and taken to the hospital. [size=no report]

Around 12 March 2020, At least 11 people were killed during armed confrontations between Oromo and Afar pasturalists in the Bordeda (Mieso) area. Clashes are attributed to a dispute over water and pasture.
On 14 March 2020, residents held a protest in Sokota town, Wag Hamra, denouncing the delay of the trial of an official accused of corruption. [size=no report]
On 18 March 2020, militias sponsored by the Ogadan district administration attacked ONLF offices in Ogadan district and tore down the flag.
On 19 March 2020, locals held a demonstration in Borana zone, Borbor woreda, demanding that the woreda administrator be removed from power. [size=no report]
On 19 March 2020, government troops attacked ""Fano"" (Amhara Youth) camps in Gondar, sparking an exchange of gunfire and clashes that left at least three people dead.
On 19 March 2020, Oromo militants attacked Somali pastoralists in Tuluguleed, sparking clashes. One Somali pastoralist was killed in the clash.

On 20 March 2020, Oromo militants attacked pastoralists in Dharcaseeye and Gabagab, situated on the outskirts of Tuliguuleed, sparking clashes. One Somali pastoralist was wounded in the exchange of gunfire.

Assumed on 21 March 2020, foreigners of unidentified origin were reportedly attacked with stones and chased by crowds in Addis Ababa, on suspicion that they were carrying coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 25 March 2020, unidentified armed men shot and killed the former head of admin and security bureau of Nekemt city (retired, not armed), at his house in Nekemt city (E. WOLLEGA). Motive is unknown.

On 25 March 2020, recent air transport arrivals who were being quarantined because of coronavirus clashed with police over provisions in Bole (Addis Ababa). No injuries were reported. [size=no report]
On 26 March 2020, Oromo militiamen shot and killed one woman civilian and wounded a second civilian during a cross-border raid into the town of Daraami, located near Tulu Guled (Somali).

On 26 March 2020, students from the Hawassa university's extension in Yirga Alem protested after university officials cancelled transportation assistance after the university was shut down due to coronavirus. As many as 50 students were treated for injuries after police forces intervened to break up the protest and at least one student was shot. No fatalities. [size=at least 50]

On 29 March 2020, police officers shot and killed a young man inside a bar in the Tigray region following a proclamation banning public gatherings due to coronavirus. Some reports claim that the young man was drunk and attacked police officers (no weapon), prompting the killing.

On 1 April 2020, the KDF Engineers Brigade conducted an operation in Moyale border town targeting members of a Garre ethnic militia in response to a targeted attack by Garre Ethnic militias on construction crews digging anti-smuggling trenches. No fatalities were reported.

On 1 April 2020, Garre ethnic militias from Ethiopia attacked construction crews digging a trench on the Ethiopia/Kenya border in Moyale town. The attacks appear to have taken place on the Ethiopian side of the border. No fatalities were reported by the source.
On 4 April 2020, armed men shot and killed two civilians near Wato Burer village in Goro Dola district, East Guji zone.
On 6 April 2020, clashes were fought between Oromo and Somali ethnic militias in the Tulu Guled area (Fafan). No fatalities or injuries were reported.

On 8 April 2020, clashes were reported between Afar and Somali ethnic militias near the border between the two regions in Alaale in Shiniile province, commonly referred to as Sitti. Casualties unknown.

On 8 April 2020, security forces (assumed police) opened fire on a gathering of FANO leaders during a meeting in Lalibela (North Wollo, Amhara) killing three. Subsequent clashes led to at least 10 security officers being wounded.
On 11 April 2020, unidentified armed gunmen shot and killed three civilians in the Genji area (West Wellega, Oromia) as they prepared to travel toward Nekemt.
On 12 April 2020, Afar militants attacked Somali civilians in Garbo Cise, Somli region, firing bullets at civilians. At least 3 people were wounded in the attack. No fatalities were reported
On 15 April 2020, a young cafe worker was beaten to death in Warabe Woreada (Silte, Southern Nations) by several men after asking them to sit further apart due to coronavirus. [size=several]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: On 24 April 2020, Oromia regional special forces arrested and beat a local education bureau employee in Chekorsa (Jimma, Oromia) under suspicion that he was hiding weapons.
On 28 April 2020, police forces shot and injured 2 young men in Addis Ababa city (near Russian Embassy, Yeka Subcity), killing one and seriously injuring the second. No further info.

On 28 April 2020, armed Afari gunmen shot and killed 5 merchants from the Amhara region as they drove toward Afar region in the Bati woreda. Several others were injured and taken to hospital. Ethnic conflict between Afar and Amhara ethnic groups has occurred in the area in the past.

column9: ONLF: Ogaden National Liberation Front; Prisoners (Ethiopia)
column17: On 28 April 2020, Ethiopian security forces arrested and beat an ONLF (Ogadan National Liberation Front) leader in Warder, Somali region.

On 29 April 2020, police officers fought with market vendors at the Jan Meda market grounds (Yeka subcity, Addis Ababa city) in an attempt to enforce coronavirus bans to public gathering. Several people were injured and taken to hospital. Fatalities were reported by some sources and denied by others. [size=no report]
On 30 April 2020, at least one person was killed during inter-clan clashes occurring in the Salahad area (Salaxaad), Fik zone in Somali region, Ethiopia.
Around 2 May 2020, clan-based clashes erruped in and around Salahad (Salaxaad, Somali region), leaving ""dozens"" dead and more injured. Fatalities coded as 12.

On 2 May 2020, unidentified armed men opened fire on a peace conference being held in Shewa Robit, killing 1 person and injuring 2 others. The conference was a bid to reduce hostilities occurring between Amhara and Afari ethnic groups in the area.
On 3 May 2020, police forces shot and killed a civilian in Goday, Shabelle Zone (Somali region). The reasons behind the shooting are unknown.
On 3 May 2020, inter-clan violence erupted in Afdere zone (Somali region), leaving at least 5 people dead.
Around 7 May 2020 (week of), a young man was arrested by security forces in Ganji district, East Wollegga and killed while in costody at the Ganji district prison.
On 11 May 2020, 289 Turkish made pistols, 2 Kalashnikovs and 4806 various types of bullets were seized from a person who was transporting them in Genda Wuha near Metema (North Gonder).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 11 May 2020, a student was killed by police in Debre Libanos (North Shewa) for alleged links with the OLF.

On 11 May 2020, Afar militants attacked Somali pastoralist communities, sparking armed clashes in Madaane town, Sitti District (Somali zone). Ethiopian national soldiers intervened with shelling and gunfire. At least 8 fatalities occurred on the Somali side, while Somali sources claim to have killed an unspecified number of Afar militiamen. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column8: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)

Unknown fatalities in a non-combat zone coded as 3. Estimated fatalities spread across 3 locations (Shakiso, Goro Dilla, Saba Boru).

column17: Around 12 May 2020 (week of), clashes between Oromia Regional Special forces and splinter groups of the Oromo Liberation front battled in Shakiso, Guro Dilla, and Saba Boru woredas (Guji Zone), leading to an unknown number of fatalities. column17: Around 12 May 2020 (week of) clashes between Oromia Regional Special forces and splinter groups of the Oromo Liberation front battled in Shakiso, Guro Dilla, and Saba Boru woredas (Guji Zone), leading to an unknown number of fatalities. Unknown fatalities in a non-combat zone coded as 3. Estimated fatalities spread across 3 locations (Shakiso, Goro Dilla, Saba Boru).
On 12 May 2020, a Somali civilian man was shot and killed by Oromo militiamen as he traveled from Jinacsani to Tuluguled.

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Amhara Regional Special Forces
column17: On 13 May 2020, Sudanese armed forces opened fire on Amhara region special forces (liyu) and some local militias in the Mirab Armachaho district (location unspecified), North Gondar zone (Amhara region). No info on casualties.
On 13 May 2020, armed Oromo militiamen attacked Somali civilians in Tulu Guled (Fafan), killing 2 and burning several houses.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column8: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)
column17: Around 14 May 2020 (week of), 12 Oromia regional special police forces (LIYU) were killed during clashes with OLF splinter group militias in Gumi Eldelo Woreda, Gujji Zone (Oromia). An additional unknown number of OLF militants were confirmed to have been killed.

On 17 May 2020, ethnic clashes erupted between Amahara and Beni-Shangul groups in the Awi Zone, Zigem Woreda (Amhara), leading to at least 8 fatalities. Cattle were stolen during raids and many homes were burned during the clashes.

On 18 May 2020, ethnic clashes that erupted between Amahara and Beni-Shangul groups during the previous day in Zigem woreda, spread into the Guangua area (Awi Zone), leading to 3 fatalities. Cattle were stolen during raids and many homes were burned during the clashes.

On 19 May 2020, at least 5 people were killed by federal troops when they staged raids on Lalo Asabi town and surrounding villages, including Wanjo, Kalay, and Jarso. Homes and small businesses were burned by advancing troops. Clashes have occurred in the area between OLF splinter factions and federal troops previously. Fatalities spread between four events.

On 19 May 2020, at least 5 people were killed by federal troops when they staged raids on Lalo Asabi town and surrounding villages, including Wanjo near Dongoro (West Wellega, Oromia), Kalay, and Jarso. Homes and small businesses were burned by advancing troops. Clashes have occurred in the area between OLF splinter factions and federal troops previously. Fatalities spread between four events.

On 19 May 2020, at least 5 people were killed by federal troops when they staged raids on Lalo Asabi town and surrounding villages, including Wanjo, Kalay near Gembela (West Wellega, Oromia), and Jarso. Homes and small businesses were burned by advancing troops. Clashes have occurred in the area between OLF splinter factions and federal troops previously. Fatalities spread between four events.

On 19 May 2020, at least 5 people were killed by federal troops when they staged raids on Lalo Asabi town and surrounding villages, including Wanjo, Kalay near Gembela, and Jarso (West Shewa, Oromia). Homes and small businesses were burned by advancing troops. Clashes have occurred in the area between OLF splinter factions and federal troops previously. Fatalities spread between four events.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: On 21 May 2020, Oromia regional special forces shot and killed a woman near her farm in Lali Asabi woreda, West Wollega (Oromia).

On 21 May 2020, South Sudanese students held a demonstration outside of the South Sudanese embassy in Addis Ababa (Bole Subcity) after embassy staff failed to pay student stipends. Ethiopian police forces intervened to break up the demonstration, injuring at least 7 of the students. [size=at least 7]

Around 26 May 2020 (week of), several protests were reported across the Tigray region (locations unspecified). Protesters denounced the lack of jobs, regional governance, and boundaries. [size=no report]

On 27 May 2020, residents protested in Hintalo Awajirat district (Tigray) against the local governance and decisions to close roads and re-organize local governance boundaries. Protests were peaceful and no clashes or interventions were reported. [size=no report]

column6: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)
column17: On 29 May 2020, 4 government officials were killed and 3 injured in Nejo, West Wollega, after their vehicle was attacked by suspected armed Oromia Liberation Front (Shane) gunmen.

On 31 May 2020, the security chief of police and a woreda administrative official of Raya Kobo Woreda (Amhara, North Wollo) were killed by unidentified gunmen during a traffic stop as they attempted to enforce social distancing rules related to coronavirus.

On 1 June 2020, demonstrators organized by the ""Fenqel"" political movement in Qorarit town (Wolkeyt, Tigray) demonstrated against local administration and proposed boundary divisions in Welkait, Tigray region. Demonstrators also demanded payment for land taken around 7 years ago during boundary restructure. Police forces intervened and arrested 45 people after youth blocked roads and threw rocks at police forces. [size=at least 45]

On 2 June 2020, demonstrators, organized by the ""Fenqel"" political movement in Qorarit town (Wolkeyt, Tigray), demonstrated for a second day against local admin and proposed boundary divisions in Welkait, Tigray region. Demonstrators also demanded payment for land taken around 7 years ago during boundary restructure. Police forces intervened and arrested 45 people after the youth blocked roads and threw rocks at police forces. [size=at least 45]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 2 June 2020, Liyu police killed a young man in Babile (East Harerghe). The motive behind the attack was unknown but anti-government campaigners have often been targeted in this area.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: Around 3 June 2020 (week of), Oromia regional state police officers killed the parents of a man suspected to be a member of the armed Oromia Liberation Front (Shane) in West Wellega for allegedly not disclosing his location.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: Around 3 June 2020 (week of), a father and his son were killed by police in Guji area (Oromia) for allegedly supporting the OLF.

column6: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)
column7: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Abba Torbee Splinter Faction)
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 3 June 2020, gunmen associated with the Abba Torbaa splinter faction of the armed Oromia Liberation Front (OLF) (Shaane) shot and killed an Oromia state police officer in Nekemt (Oromia). 2 additional officers were wounded in the attack.

On 4 June 2020, at least 3 people were killed during armed clashes between federal police forces and local communal militias in Bambasi woreda, Assossa zone (Beni-shangul/Gumz). Earlier reports indicated that 4 people had been killed.

On 6 June 2020, two groups of South Sudanese refugees clashed in Pugnido refugee camp in Gog woreda of Anyuak zone (Gambela region), with three wounded (including a child). The specific cause of the clash is unclear, although is reported to have followed a series of similar incidents. Police have been deployed. [size=no report]
On 9 June 2020, police and several other local security officers fatally shot a young man in Dinsho (Bale, Oromia). 12 suspects appeared before the local court.

On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held against the Prosperity Party and the regional president of the Somali region in Kebri Dehar (Somali), over dissatisfaction with the government. [size=no report]
Around 10 June 2020 (week of), at least 20 houses of local people have been burnt down by police in in Goro Dola district, Balambel Kebele (Goro Dola, Guji). No fatalities were reported.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 10 June 2020, Oromia regional state police killed a 7 years old boy in West Wellega (Oromia). The reason for the killing is not known but according to reports the relatives of OLF members are being targeted by local police and military.
On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration against the Prosperity Party was held in Gawo Kebe (West Wellega), over dissatisfaction with the government. [size=no report]

On 11 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held against the Prosperity Party and the regional president of the Somali region in Jijiga (Somali), over dissatisfaction with the government. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: Around 13 June 2020 (as reported), Oromia regional state police officers have burnt down the house of a man in Guji area (Oromia).

column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 13 June 2020, Oromia regional state police forces used tear gas to disperse rioters who closed roads in Dinsho (Bale) after the killing of a young man earlier in the week. [size=no report]

Around 15 June 2020 (between 13 June - 18 June), armed clashes were reported between Afar and Oromo communal militias in Bati town, Oromia special zone. Houses were burned - no fatalities were mentioned.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), security operations by government troops against unidentified armed groups operating in Saba Boru, Liban, and Gumi Eldelo (Guji Zone) intensified, with reported loss of life and properties. Unspecified fatalities in a conflict zone coded as 10 and spread across three locations.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), security operations by government troops against unidentified armed groups operating in Saba Boru, Liban, and Gumi Eldelo (Guji Zone) intensified, with reported loss of life and properties. Unspecified fatalities in a conflict zone coded as 10 and spread across three locations.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), security operations by government troops against unidentified armed groups operating in Saba Boru, Liban, and Gumi Eldelo (Guji Zone) intensified, with reported loss of life and properties. Unspecified fatalities in a conflict zone coded as 10 and spread across three locations.
On 16 June 2020, police forces shot and killed a young Oromo man in Haramaya (alias Alemaya), East Hararghe (Oromia) during coronavirus-related restriction enforcement.
On 23 June 2020, unidentified armed gunmen opened fire on police officers and health officials as they traveled through Dewa Harawa Woreda in Oromo special zone (Amhara region), wounding 4.
On 29 June 2020, unidentified armed men shot and killed a popular Oromo musician near the Gelan Condominium site in Akaki/Kaliti (Addis Ababa). This incident led to civil unrest in the area.

On 30 June 2020, federal police in Ambo city (Oromia) fired live rounds into crowds of demonstrators. Figures from a local hospital indicate at least 9 fatalities occurred as a result of the event, with 10 additional wounded in critical condition. Demonstrators demanded that the body of a popular Oromo musician, killed the day before, be buried in the capital city of Addis Ababa. [size=at least 19]
On 30 June 2020, federal police in Ambo city (Oromia) shot and killed the uncle of a popular Oromo musician during a dispute about where the musicians body would be buried.
On 30 June 2020, armed groups of Oromo youth attacked the Orthodox Christian church (Holy Savior Orthodox church) in Kokosa, West Arsi, burning it completely down.

On 30 June 2020, rioters burned tires and blocked roads and pulled down statues in the city of Harar (Hundene, Harari People) following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, clashing with police and setting barricades. One person was reported killed during the riots, with further details currently unknown. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, at least 2 protesters were killed by federal police in Chiro town, Oromia region, following the death of a popular Oromo musician. Additional details around the deaths of the protesters are unknown. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, Oromo youth militia (Qerroo) attacked ethnic Amhara students in West Hararghe (coded as Chiro), in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, killing at least one person.
On 30 June 2020, demonstrators gathered to protest outside of the US embassy (Gullele, Addis Ababa) during unrest over the killing of a popular Oromo artist. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, rioting youth filled the streets of Addis Ababa, burning tires and blocking roads after the assassination of a popular Oromo Musician. Rioters refused to allow police forces to transport the body of the killed musician out of the capital, insisting that he be buried in Addis Ababa. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, at least 19 people (ethnic Amhara) from Arsi Dera arrived by ambulance to hospitals in Adama city (Nazreth) with severe burn wounds. The victims were attacked by Qeerroo youth militia in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. No fatalities were reported.
On 30 June 2020, Oromo youth rioted in the streets of Jima (Jimma, Oromia), following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, burning tires and blocking roads. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 30 June 2020, Oromia regional state police clashed with federal Liyu (special) forces in the Oromo Cultural center in Addis Ababa as the latter attempted to arrest several Oromo opposition members. The standoff ended when members of the Oromo Federal Congress and owners of the Oromia Media Network were taken into custody. One Liyu police officer was killed in the incident.

On 30 June 2020, at least 5 demonstrators were killed and 75 injured by federal police in Adama city (Nazreth), Oromia region, following the death of a popular Oromo musician. An additional 4 bodies were received by the hospital in Adama on the same day. Fatalities coded as 9. [size=at least 80]
On 30 June 2020, Qerroo youth militia attacked ethnic Amhara living in Ziway, in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, killing at least 4 people.

On 30 June 2020, Qerroo youth militia attacked ethnic Amhara living in Shashamene, in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, beating several people and burning hotels and other businesses. No fatalities were reported.

On 30 June 2020, Qerroo youth militia attacked ethnic Amhara living in Arsi Negele, killing at least 6 people and injuring many others in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. Businesses, schools, and other buildings associated with ethnic Amhara residents were burned.

column9: Civilians (Ethiopia); Amhara Ethnic Group (Ethiopia); Labour Group (Ethiopia)
column17: On 1 July 2020, Oromo youth rioted and clashed with police after burning Amhara-owned businesses and beating several ethnic Amhara in the town of Asosa, in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. No fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, at least 2 police officers were killed during clashes between security forces and rioters in Dire Dawa city, in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. An additional 8 people were admitted into the Dire Dawa hospital with gunshot wounds. [size=at least 8]

On 1 July 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters demanding that leaders of the Oromo Federalist Congress be released in Holeta town, Oromia. The source did not mention fatalities. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, rioters beat and killed a young man in Arsi Dera, Arsi Zone, Oromia region during unrest following the death of a popular Oromo musician. The victim was reportedly a member of another ethnic group (unidentified) than the attackers (assumed Oromo). 6 other deaths were reported the same day. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, Qeerroo youth militia clashed with police, burning Amhara-owned businesses and beating several ethnic Amhara in the town of Dodola. Police intervened, killing an unspecified number of youths. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 1 July 2020, unidentified men armed with sticks, knives, and guns killed three people in Qersa Munesa (near Assella, Arsi zone, Oromia). Two additional people were admitted to the hospital with serious injuries. The victims were reportedly from a different ethnic group (unidentified), than the attackers (assumed Oromo).

On 1 July 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Neqemt, demonstrating in the aftermath of the killing of a popular Oromo musician. 3 protesters were killed and several more injured. [size=at least several]

On 1 July 2020, at least 15 people were killed during unrest, riots, and clashes with police in Bale Robe (Bale, Oromia), in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. [size=at least 15]

On 1 July 2020, security forces clashed with rioters in Awaday (Hararghe), in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, leading to at least three fatalities. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, an unknown number of protesters were killed when security forces opened fire on demonstrators in Iteya (Oromia), protesting in the aftermath of the killing of a popular Oromo musician. At least 70 were confirmed injured in the attack. Unknown fatalities coded as 3. [size=at least 70]
On 1 July 2020, security forces clashed with rioters in Haramaya (Oromia), during violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician, leading to at least one fatality. [size=no report]

column7: Balderas Movement; NaMA: National Movement of Amhara; Oromo Ethnic Group (Ethiopia)
column17: On 1 July 2020, rioting was reported through parts of the city of Addis Ababa (including Addisu Gebeya, Lam Beret, CMC, Summit, and Yeka Abadu), clashing with one another and police, in a bout of violence following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. 10 fatalities were later confirmed, including 2 police officers, with the rest of the fatalities coming from unknown persons who had been shot by police, killed by beatings, or killed by one of three explosions that occurred during the riots. Leaders of the Baldaras council, and the National Movement of Amhara (NaMA) were arrested, accused of instigating the violence. [size=no report]

On 2 July 2020, at least 2 people were shot and killed by police forces in Ambo (West Shewa, Oromia) as they attempted to restricted demonstrators from attending the funeral of a popular Oromo musician who was killed in Addis Ababa a few days earlier. 7 others were injured in the event. [size=at least 9]

On 2 July 2020, unidentified armed attackers reportedly killed 4 people in the Kersa Munesa Woreda (Near Assella, Arsi Zone, Oromia), going house-to-house with sticks, knives and guns. The victims were reportedly from a different ethnic group (unidentified), than the attackers (assumed Oromo)

On 2 July 2020, rioters burned businesses and private homes belonging to local Orthodox Christian residents in Arsi Dera (Oromia) during unrest following the death of a popular Oromo Musician. Several Orthdox Christians were beaten during the riots and fled to hide in the church. [size=no report]
Around 2 July 2020 (between 1 July - 2 July), police reportedly assaulted two key leaders of the Baldaras Council in an undisclosed location in Addis Ababa.

On 2 July 2020, violent riots continued throughout Oromia region, leading to at least 166 confirmed fatalities since the killing of a popular Oromo musician in Addis Ababa a few days prior. Specific event locations and fatalities could not be verified due to complete internet blackout imposed by the government. 77 fatalities could be attributed to specific locations and events from 30 June to the 2 July 2020, while the remaining 89 fatalities could only be confirmed to have occurred in the Oromia region (capital city, Adama/Nazreth). Most fatalities are attributed to police action against rioters, with additional fatalities occurring as rioter violence against ethnic Amhara living in the Oromia region. [size=no report]

On 3 July 2020, several high-ranking OLF leaders were arrested by federal police in the capital Addis Ababa following wide-spread unrest in Oromo region. Over a thousand additional people were arrested in connection with the unrest, including various political and traditional leaders.
On 7 July 2020, police forces arrested and assaulted court judges in Adami Tulu/Jido Kombolcha (Oromia Region).

On 8 July 2020, demonstrators clashed with security forces in West Wollega, Miko Woreda, leading to one death. Demonstrators were expressing grief at the death of an Oromo musician who was killed a week earlier, and demanding the release of several Oromo leaders who had been arrested the week prior. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 14 July 2020, Liyu police officers opened fire on civilians in Bayaxow, Shabelle zone (Somali) after they refused to leave an area slated for oil exploration, killing 3.

On 24 July 2020, communal/ethnic-based clashes erupted between residents in Ale Special Woreda (Oromia) and residents in Konso zone (SNNPR, Konso) over a land dispute. 6 people were killed in Ale special woreda and 11 in Konso during the clashes.

On 24 July 2020, communal/ethnic-based clashes erupted between residents in Ale Special Woreda (Oromia) and residents in Konso zone (SNNPR, Konso) over a land dispute. 6 people were killed in Ale special woreda and 11 in Konso during the clashes.
On 27 July 2020, unidentified armed men attacked Amhara ethnic civilians in Guba Wereda of Metekel zone in Benishangul Gumuz regional state, killing 14 people.

On 31 July 2020, unidentified armed attackers attacked ethnic Amhara farmers in Guba woreda, Benishangul, burning homes and destroying houses. Around 2,000 ethnic Amhara fled to nearby towns. No fatalities were mentioned.
On 1 August 2020, federal security forces shot and killed a teacher in Boke, West Hararghe (Oromia), after they accused him of organizing demonstrations in the area.

On 1 August 2020, unidentified armed gunmen kidnapped 3 civilians in Guba woreda, Benishangul/Gumz region. The kidnappings come a week after militants killed 14 people in the region, reportedly from a minority ethnic group.

Around 3 August 2020 (as reported), 13 unidentified gunmen were killed and 30 others arrested by Ethiopian federal troops operating in Guba woreda, Benishangul/Gumz region. Troops were stationed in the area following the targeting of ethnic minorities by gunmen one week before.
On 4 August 2020, unidentified armed attackers killed 2 civilians in the Guba woreda of Benishangul/Gomz region.
On 6 August 2020, residents of Hintalo Wajirat, Tigray regional state, staged a protest against local administration. Reason for the protest was unreported. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2020, federal troops opened fire at protesters in Bodeti (Soddo, SNNPR), killing 6. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2020, federal troops opened fire at protesters in Areka Soddo (SNNPR) killing 1. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), killing 4 and wounding 18. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. [size=no report]
On 9 August 2020, 8 soldiers were killed and 5 others injured during an ambush by unidentified gunmen in Guba woreda, Benishangul/Gumz. 12 civilians were also reportedly killed in the same attack.

On 10 August 2020, 2 people were killed when federal troops opened fire on protesters in Sodo city (Wolayta, SNNPR). Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. [size=no report]

On 10 August 2020, military forces shot and killed 8 people in Liban and Gumi woldelo woredas (coded as Hay Dima, nearest location) in Guji zone (Oromia). Further details around why the persons were killed is unclear. Fatalities spread across two events.

On 10 August 2020, military forces shot and killed 8 people in Liban and Gumi woldelo woredas (coded as Hay Dima, nearest location) in Guji zone (Oromia). Further details around why the persons were killed is unclear. Fatalities spread across two events.
On 10 August 2020, heavily armed Argoba militias attacked local farmers in Fantale woreda (East Shewa, Oromia), killing one person.
